It&#x27;s possible that the claim might be misleading or a misunderstanding of another type of opportunity or program. It&#x27;s always good to be cautious and seek information directly from official sources when you come across offers that seem unusually generous or too good to be true. If Google were offering such a program, it would likely be widely reported and detailed on their official website or through reputable news outlets."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [100260]}, "citations": [], "gizmo_id": null, "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4", "pad": "AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA", "parent_id": "224ed376-327e-445f-9481-1e51bac3d46a", "request_id": "86d6307a29aa0e5e-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "224ed376-327e-445f-9481-1e51bac3d46a", "children": ["270048d9-6170-4439-bf7e-557519b4eacf"]}, "270048d9-6170-4439-bf7e-557519b4eacf": {"id": "270048d9-6170-4439-bf7e-557519b4eacf", "message": {"id": "270048d9-6170-4439-bf7e-557519b4eacf", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1711949510.53718, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Is there a way to one click apply a style sgeet to a document? "]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"request_id": "86d631f7aabe0e5e-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "f2c9aa85-a32f-4b1b-81be-9dc7b1e7f899", "children": ["419b26ed-4205-41d1-a095-b756f9893318"]}, "419b26ed-4205-41d1-a095-b756f9893318": {"id": "419b26ed-4205-41d1-a095-b756f9893318", "message": {"id": "419b26ed-4205-41d1-a095-b756f9893318", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1711949553.889542, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Yes, you can apply a stylesheet to a document with a single click through various methods, depending on the context and the type of document you are working with. Here are some common scenarios:\n\n### 1. Web Development\nFor HTML documents, you can switch stylesheets using JavaScript. While you can&#x27;t literally apply a new stylesheet with a &quot;single physical click&quot; without first writing the script that does so, once set up, changing styles can be as easy as clicking a button. Here&#x27;s a basic example:\n\n```html\n&lt;!DOCTYPE html&gt;\n&lt;html&gt;\n&lt;head&gt;\n    &lt;link rel=&quot;stylesheet&quot; type=&quot;text/css&quot; href=&quot;default.css&quot; id=&quot;theme-style&quot;&gt;\n&lt;/head&gt;\n&lt;body&gt;\n    &lt;button onclick=&quot;changeStyle(&#x27;alternate.css&#x27;)&quot;&gt;Change Style&lt;/button&gt;\n\n    &lt;script&gt;\n        function changeStyle(sheet) {\n            document.getElementById(&#x27;theme-style&#x27;).setAttribute(&#x27;href&#x27;, sheet);\n        }\n    &lt;/script&gt;\n&lt;/body&gt;\n&lt;/html&gt;\n```\n\nIn this example, clicking the button calls the `changeStyle` function, which changes the stylesheet applied to the page by altering the `href` attribute of the `&lt;link&gt;` tag with the `id` of &quot;theme-style&quot;.\n\n### 2. Word Processors (e.g., Microsoft Word, Google Docs)\nMost modern word processing software allows for the application of pre-defined styles or templates, which can change the look of a document instantly. However, applying these with a &quot;single click&quot; typically means having a toolbar or menu open from which you can select your new style. For example, in Google Docs:\n\n- You can create or import a set of styles.\n- Use the `Styles` menu to select your desired style, which is then applied to the document.\n\n### 3. Text Editors and IDEs (e.g., Visual Studio Code, Sublime Text)\nFor coding projects or plain text documents, many text editors and Integrated Development Environments (IDEs) support extensions or plugins that allow quick switching between different syntax highlighting themes or styles. Once a theme is installed, switching between themes can often be done with just a few clicks or a keyboard shortcut.\n\n### 4. CSS Preprocessors (Sass, Less)\nFor more advanced web development projects, CSS preprocessors like Sass or Less can make it easier to manage styles. They allow you to define variables, functions, and mixins that can be reused across stylesheets. While this approach doesn&#x27;t apply a stylesheet with a click, it significantly simplifies the process of changing styles across a site by altering a few variables.\n\nIn each case, the precise method to &quot;one-click apply&quot; a style sheet will depend on the tools and platforms you&#x27;re using."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [100260]}, "citations": [], "gizmo_id": null, "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4", "pad": "AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA", "parent_id": "270048d9-6170-4439-bf7e-557519b4eacf", "request_id": "86d631f7aabe0e5e-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "270048d9-6170-4439-bf7e-557519b4eacf", "children": ["5576dfe1-728f-4a24-b218-7ac63b63ea83"]}, "5576dfe1-728f-4a24-b218-7ac63b63ea83": {"id": "5576dfe1-728f-4a24-b218-7ac63b63ea83", "message": {"id": "5576dfe1-728f-4a24-b218-7ac63b63ea83", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1711949617.018258, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Well i mean for a resume"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"request_id": "86d63490ac200e5e-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "419b26ed-4205-41d1-a095-b756f9893318", "children": ["4b369803-aa90-4a50-b764-4f0de9adda1d"]}, "4b369803-aa90-4a50-b764-4f0de9adda1d": {"id": "4b369803-aa90-4a50-b764-4f0de9adda1d", "message": {"id": "4b369803-aa90-4a50-b764-4f0de9adda1d", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1711949653.509294, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Applying a style sheet to a resume with a single click suggests you&#x27;re looking for a way to quickly change the design or format of your resume. This functionality is often found in online resume builders and word processing software, where templates act as style sheets. Here&#x27;s how it works in common scenarios:\n\n### Online Resume Builders:\nMany online resume builders allow you to apply different templates to your resume content with a single click. Once you&#x27;ve entered your information into the builder&#x27;s interface, you can usually preview and apply different styles or templates from their collection. This changes the appearance of your resume instantly without altering the content. Websites like LinkedIn, Canva, and Zety offer such features.\n\n### Microsoft Word or Google Docs:\nIf you&#x27;re using a word processor like Microsoft Word or Google Docs, the concept is similar but slightly less dynamic:\n\n- **Microsoft Word**: You can create different styles for headings, body text, etc., and save these styles as a template. You can also download resume templates where the styles are predefined. Applying a template to an existing document might require copying the content into the new template file.\n- **Google Docs**: Similar to Microsoft Word, Google Docs offers various templates. You can open a template and paste your resume content into it, effectively applying the template&#x27;s style to your content with a few clicks.\n\n### LaTeX:\nFor academic and technical resumes, LaTeX is a popular tool that separates content from style. You define your resume content once and can apply different LaTeX resume templates (style sheets) to this content. Changing the template can dramatically alter the appearance of the resume. This process might involve a bit more than one click but is highly effective for applying different styles.\n\n### Design Software:\nIf your resume is more design-oriented, software like Adobe InDesign allows you to create and apply master pages (templates) that define styles for various elements of your document. While applying a new master page or template might require a few clicks, it&#x27;s a powerful way to change the look of your resume.\n\nIn each of these scenarios, the key is having your content separated from the formatting so you can quickly apply new formats or styles without having to redo your resume each time. This approach saves time and allows you to customize your resume for different applications easily."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [100260]}, "citations": [], "gizmo_id": null, "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4", "pad": "AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA", "parent_id": "5576dfe1-728f-4a24-b218-7ac63b63ea83", "request_id": "86d63490ac200e5e-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "5576dfe1-728f-4a24-b218-7ac63b63ea83", "children": ["eeec931e-0402-4519-bb2d-60ae55a12319"]}, "eeec931e-0402-4519-bb2d-60ae55a12319": {"id": "eeec931e-0402-4519-bb2d-60ae55a12319", "message": {"id": "eeec931e-0402-4519-bb2d-60ae55a12319", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1711949694.544973, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Yes"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"request_id": "86d636758d840e5e-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "4b369803-aa90-4a50-b764-4f0de9adda1d", "children": ["aea54e4b-bdc7-4098-b87c-1e984adfc3e9"]}, "aea54e4b-bdc7-4098-b87c-1e984adfc3e9": {"id": "aea54e4b-bdc7-4098-b87c-1e984adfc3e9", "message": {"id": "aea54e4b-bdc7-4098-b87c-1e984adfc3e9", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1711949703.394754, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Great! The top reason for homeschooling is a concern about school environment.\n\nAccording to National Center for Education Statistics (IES) homeschooling facts, the top reason for homeschooling is a concern about school environment, such as safety, drugs, and negative peer pressure. (4)\n\nReasons for Homeschooling Percentage   \nSafe environment concerns 25% of parents   \nBad academic quality 14.5% of parents   \nTo provide religious instruction 13% of parents   \nTo provide moral instruction 6.6% of parents   \nHealth problems 3.6% of parents\u00a0  \nSpecial needs 7.3% of parents   \nTo provide nontraditional education 7.7% of parents   \nEmphasis on family 8.3% of parents   \nOther reasons 14% of parents  \n\nThe second most popular reason was dissatisfaction with the academic instruction at schools, followed by a desire to provide religious instruction.\n\nBut not all parents want to homeschool their children.\u00a0\n\nAccording to EdChoice statistics against homeschooling, socialization is the most common reason why parents have not yet homeschooled their children. (5)\n\nReasons Not to Homeschool Percentage   \nChild will not be prepared socially for real-life 16% of parents   \nCoordinating with work schedule 15% of parents   \nTime management 14% of parents   \nNote sure if realistically doable 13% of parents   \nDon\u2019t want to disrupt child\u2019s relationships 12% of parents   \nDon\u2019t want to disrupt child\u2019s current schooling 12% of parents   \nOther reasons 18% of parents  \n\nThe second most common reason not to homeschool is the problem with coordinating homeschool with work schedule followed by time management.\n\n### 4. Homeschool students outperform institutional school students academically.\n\nAccording to National Home Education Research Institute (NHERI) homeschooling success statistics, 78% of peer-reviewed studies on academic achievements show that homeschool students perform statistically significantly better than students in institutional schools. (6)\n\nHere are some brief summaries of studies on homeschooling.\n\nAuthor(s)Results of the Studies   \nMurphy, 2012; Ray, 2013, 2017 Homeschooled score 15 to 30 percentile points above public-school students on standardized academic achievement tests. The public school average is the 50th percentile; scores range from 1 to 99.  \nRay, 2015 Black homeschool students scored 23 to 42 percentile points above Black public school students.  \nMartin-Chang et al., 2011 Researchers found that children from structured homeschool settings outperformed their conventional school peers (by 0.06 to 0.15 effect sizes).  \nRudner, 1999 Median scores for home school students fell between the 70th and 80th percentile. The study concluded that those parents choosing to make a commitment to homeschooling are able to provide a very successful academic environment.  \nMurphy, 2012; Ray, 2017 Home-educated students typically score above average on the college admission SAT and ACT tests.  \nCogan, 2010 College students who were homeschooled earn higher first-year and fourth-year GPAs when controlling for demographic, pre-college, engagement, and first-term academic factors.  \n\nThe majority of peer-reviewed research papers on homeschooling found a positive effect of homeschooling compared to institutional schooling. The same positive outcomes were also revealed regarding social and emotional development. (6)\n\nThe positive effect was real and measurable also for homeschooled students who later became adults compared to those who had been in conventional schools.\n\n### 5. The highest homeschooling rate is among students with a grade equivalent of 6 to 8.\n\nAccording to National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) latest homeschooled kids statistics, the highest homeschooling rate is among students with a grade equivalent of 6 to 8. (7)\n\nGrade Equivalent Homeschooled   \n2019 Homeschooled   \n2016 Homeschooled   \n2012   \nKindergarten 8%11%12%  \nGrades 1 to 3 22%18%20%  \nGrades 4 to 5 18%17%15%  \nGrades 6 to 8 29%24%24%  \nGrades 9 to 12 22%31%29%  \n\nInterestingly enough, the dominant grade equivalent of 6-8 has shifted from grades 9-12 since 2012. (7)\n\nOverall, the grade distribution is roughly even across all grade levels above kindergarten.\n\n### 6. 48% of homeschooling households have three or more children.\n\nAccording to National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) homeschool demographics data, a surprising 48% of homeschooling households have three or more children. (7)\n\n3+ Children 2 Children 1 Child   \n48% of households 33% of households 19% of households  \n\nInterestingly enough, the homeschool data shows that only 19% of homeschooling households have 1 child and 33% have 2 children.\n\nOne can argue anecdotally, that in a household with three or more children, there\u2019s already a significantly higher focus on kids. So perhaps it can be easier to homeschool all of them together.\n\nWhite Black Hispanic Asian Other   \n70%6%17%2%6%  \n\nThe NCES data also shows that 7 in 10 homeschool students are white. (7)\n\nThe second most common ethnicity of homeschooled children is Hispanic, followed by Black, Asian, and other ethnicities.\u00a0\n\n2 Parents 1 Parent Non-parental   \n83% of homeschoolers 14% of homeschoolers 3% of homeschoolers  \n\nAccording to NCES homeschool families data, 83% of homeschool students live in two-parent households, followed by 14% in 1 parent, and 3% in non-parental households. (7)\n\n### 7. The average cost of homeschooling is $700-$1,800 per student annually.\n\nAccording to Time4Learning homeschooling cost statistics, the average cost of homeschooling is $700-$1,800 per student annually. (8)\n\nCategory Price range   \nCurriculum$350 \u2013 $750   \nSupplies &amp; materials$150 \u2013 $300   \nField trips$100 \u2013 $250   \nExtracurriculars$100 \u2013 $500   \nTotal$700 \u2013 $1,800  \n\nFor a family with two school-aged children, homeschooling may cost on average between $1,400 to $3,600 per year. (8)\n\nIt\u2019s difficult to pinpoint the average cost of homeschooling for everyone as every family has a unique situation.\n\nThe final cost depends on how many children are homeschooled, are there any special needs or health problems, and how logistically accessible libraries, museums, and so on are.\n\n### 8. 1 in 3 homeschooling households has an annual income of over $100,000.\n\nAccording to National Home Education Research Institute (NHERI) homeschool studies, 34% of homeschooling households have an annual income over $100,000. (7)\n\nAnnual Income Homeschooling Households  \n$20,000 or less 10%  \n$20,001 to $50,000 20%  \n$50,001 to $75,000 21%  \n$75,001 to $100,000 15%  \nOver $100,000 34%  \n\nInterestingly enough, the highest income bracket of over $100,000 has the highest share of households. (7)\n\nSecond highest annual income is $50,001 to $75,000 with 21% of households, followed by $20,001 to $50,000 and 20% of households.\n\nEducation Level Homeschooling Parents   \nHigh school diploma or less 23%  \nVocational/technical, associate\u2019s degree, or some college 26%  \nBachelor\u2019s degree/some graduate school 31%  \nGraduate/professional degree 21%  \n\nNHERI data also reveals that 31% of homeschooling parents own a bachelor\u2019s or some graduate school degree. (7)\n\nCan this be correlated with higher annual income? We don\u2019t know, as there\u2019s no formal evidence on this.\n\n### 9. Homeschooling saves about $56 billion of taxpayer money annually.\n\nAccording to National Home Education Research Institute (NHERI), homeschooling saves about $56 billion of taxpayer money annually. (2)\n\nTaxpayer Savings Homeschool Students Public School Cost  \n$56 billion 3.721 million$15,240 per student  \n\nThe reality is that public schools aren\u2019t free. Taxpayers spend on average $15,240 per student annually for public schools.\n\nThe more homeschooled students there are, the bigger savings there will be for the federal government on taxpayers\u2019 money. This is $56 billion of taxpayers\u2019 money that can be used for other causes.\n\n## FAQ\n\n### How much does homeschooling cost?\n\nThe average cost of homeschooling is $700-$1,800 per student annually.\n\n### What is homeschooling?\n\nHomeschooling is a parent-led home-based education form that is the fastest-growing in the U.S.\n\n### How many homeschool students are in the U.S.?\n\nThere are 3.7 million homeschool students in the U.S. Homeschool students make up 6.73% of all school-aged children.\n\n### Do homeschool students perform better?\n\nYes, homeschool students outperform institutional school students academically.\n\n### What percentage of students are homeschooled?\n\n6.73% (3.7 million) of all school-aged children in the U.S. are homeschooled.\n\n### Will homeschooling increase after the pandemic?\n\nYes, homeschooling rates doubled after the lockdowns in the U.S.\n\n## References\n\n  1. The top reason for homeschooling is a concern about school environment.\n\nAccording to National Center for Education Statistics (IES) homeschooling facts, the top reason for homeschooling is a concern about school environment, such as safety, drugs, and negative peer pressure. (4)\n\nReasons for Homeschooling Percentage   \nSafe environment concerns 25% of parents   \nBad academic quality 14.5% of parents   \nTo provide religious instruction 13% of parents   \nTo provide moral instruction 6.6% of parents   \nHealth problems 3.6% of parents\u00a0  \nSpecial needs 7.3% of parents   \nTo provide nontraditional education 7.7% of parents   \nEmphasis on family 8.3% of parents   \nOther reasons 14% of parents  \n\nThe second most popular reason was dissatisfaction with the academic instruction at schools, followed by a desire to provide religious instruction.\n\nBut not all parents want to homeschool their children.\u00a0\n\nAccording to EdChoice statistics against homeschooling, socialization is the most common reason why parents have not yet homeschooled their children. (5)\n\nReasons Not to Homeschool Percentage   \nChild will not be prepared socially for real-life 16% of parents   \nCoordinating with work schedule 15% of parents   \nTime management 14% of parents   \nNote sure if realistically doable 13% of parents   \nDon\u2019t want to disrupt child\u2019s relationships 12% of parents   \nDon\u2019t want to disrupt child\u2019s current schooling 12% of parents   \nOther reasons 18% of parents  \n\nThe second most common reason not to homeschool is the problem with coordinating homeschool with work schedule followed by time management.\n\n### 4. Homeschool students outperform institutional school students academically.\n\nAccording to National Home Education Research Institute (NHERI) homeschooling success statistics, 78% of peer-reviewed studies on academic achievements show that homeschool students perform statistically significantly better than students in institutional schools. (6)\n\nHere are some brief summaries of studies on homeschooling.\n\nAuthor(s)Results of the Studies   \nMurphy, 2012; Ray, 2013, 2017 Homeschooled score 15 to 30 percentile points above public-school students on standardized academic achievement tests. The public school average is the 50th percentile; scores range from 1 to 99.  \nRay, 2015 Black homeschool students scored 23 to 42 percentile points above Black public school students.  \nMartin-Chang et al., 2011 Researchers found that children from structured homeschool settings outperformed their conventional school peers (by 0.06 to 0.15 effect sizes).  \nRudner, 1999 Median scores for home school students fell between the 70th and 80th percentile. The study concluded that those parents choosing to make a commitment to homeschooling are able to provide a very successful academic environment.  \nMurphy, 2012; Ray, 2017 Home-educated students typically score above average on the college admission SAT and ACT tests.  \nCogan, 2010 College students who were homeschooled earn higher first-year and fourth-year GPAs when controlling for demographic, pre-college, engagement, and first-term academic factors.  \n\nThe majority of peer-reviewed research papers on homeschooling found a positive effect of homeschooling compared to institutional schooling. The same positive outcomes were also revealed regarding social and emotional development. (6)\n\nThe positive effect was real and measurable also for homeschooled students who later became adults compared to those who had been in conventional schools.\n\n### 5. The highest homeschooling rate is among students with a grade equivalent of 6 to 8.\n\nAccording to National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) latest homeschooled kids statistics, the highest homeschooling rate is among students with a grade equivalent of 6 to 8. (7)\n\nGrade Equivalent Homeschooled   \n2019 Homeschooled   \n2016 Homeschooled   \n2012   \nKindergarten 8%11%12%  \nGrades 1 to 3 22%18%20%  \nGrades 4 to 5 18%17%15%  \nGrades 6 to 8 29%24%24%  \nGrades 9 to 12 22%31%29%  \n\nInterestingly enough, the dominant grade equivalent of 6-8 has shifted from grades 9-12 since 2012. (7)\n\nOverall, the grade distribution is roughly even across all grade levels above kindergarten.\n\n### 6. 48% of homeschooling households have three or more children.\n\nAccording to National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) homeschool demographics data, a surprising 48% of homeschooling households have three or more children. (7)\n\n3+ Children 2 Children 1 Child   \n48% of households 33% of households 19% of households  \n\nInterestingly enough, the homeschool data shows that only 19% of homeschooling households have 1 child and 33% have 2 children.\n\nOne can argue anecdotally, that in a household with three or more children, there\u2019s already a significantly higher focus on kids. So perhaps it can be easier to homeschool all of them together.\n\nWhite Black Hispanic Asian Other   \n70%6%17%2%6%  \n\nThe NCES data also shows that 7 in 10 homeschool students are white. (7)\n\nThe second most common ethnicity of homeschooled children is Hispanic, followed by Black, Asian, and other ethnicities.\u00a0\n\n2 Parents 1 Parent Non-parental   \n83% of homeschoolers 14% of homeschoolers 3% of homeschoolers  \n\nAccording to NCES homeschool families data, 83% of homeschool students live in two-parent households, followed by 14% in 1 parent, and 3% in non-parental households. (7)\n\n### 7. The average cost of homeschooling is $700-$1,800 per student annually.\n\nAccording to Time4Learning homeschooling cost statistics, the average cost of homeschooling is $700-$1,800 per student annually. (8)\n\nCategory Price range   \nCurriculum$350 \u2013 $750   \nSupplies &amp; materials$150 \u2013 $300   \nField trips$100 \u2013 $250   \nExtracurriculars$100 \u2013 $500   \nTotal$700 \u2013 $1,800  \n\nFor a family with two school-aged children, homeschooling may cost on average between $1,400 to $3,600 per year. (8)\n\nIt\u2019s difficult to pinpoint the average cost of homeschooling for everyone as every family has a unique situation.\n\nThe final cost depends on how many children are homeschooled, are there any special needs or health problems, and how logistically accessible libraries, museums, and so on are.\n\n### 8. 1 in 3 homeschooling households has an annual income of over $100,000.\n\nAccording to National Home Education Research Institute (NHERI) homeschool studies, 34% of homeschooling households have an annual income over $100,000. (7)\n\nAnnual Income Homeschooling Households  \n$20,000 or less 10%  \n$20,001 to $50,000 20%  \n$50,001 to $75,000 21%  \n$75,001 to $100,000 15%  \nOver $100,000 34%  \n\nInterestingly enough, the highest income bracket of over $100,000 has the highest share of households. (7)\n\nSecond highest annual income is $50,001 to $75,000 with 21% of households, followed by $20,001 to $50,000 and 20% of households.\n\nEducation Level Homeschooling Parents   \nHigh school diploma or less 23%  \nVocational/technical, associate\u2019s degree, or some college 26%  \nBachelor\u2019s degree/some graduate school 31%  \nGraduate/professional degree 21%  \n\nNHERI data also reveals that 31% of homeschooling parents own a bachelor\u2019s or some graduate school degree. They frequently participate in events like field excursions, scouting, 4-H, political campaigns, church ministries, sports teams, and volunteer work in the community. The majority of the data to date indicates that home-school students might experience less damage (such as abuse, neglect, or mortality) than students in traditional schools.\n\nThe market for homeschooling is expected to expand from USD 5.41 billion in 2019 to USD 10.14 billion in 2029, at a CAGR of 9.8% over the course of the projection period.\n\n[Image 3: The Global Home-schooling Market 2019-2029 (USD Billion)]\n\nThis market is growing as a result of both the choice for homeschooling over traditional education and the increased need for individualised instruction.\n\nThe lack of understanding of this idea and the scarcity of qualified home-schooling teachers are two factors limiting the growth of the global home-schooling sector. Another significant barrier to the expansion of this sector is the high expense of homeschooling. Meanwhile, the industry is anticipated to increase significantly due to the rising popularity of online home-schooling platforms and the availability of government funding.\n\nThe key players in the market are Abeka, BrainPOP, Duolingo, Sonlight, MEL Science, PITSCO, Compass, Khan Academy Classroom, IXL, RightStart Mathematics, KinderIQ, and eTAP. Today, more and more parents are choosing to \u301041\u2020educate their children at home\u3011, fueling the rise of homeschooling in the U.S.\n\nAccording to a new \u301042\u2020joint analysis\u2020news.stanford.edu\u3011 by the Associated Press and researchers from Stanford University, a whopping 1.2 million K-12 schoolchildren remain missing from public schools since the COVID-19 pandemic first hit in 2020. The study, which examined 22 jurisdictions, found that roughly 26% of these students switched to homeschooling. The question is, what is leading to this rise in homeschooling?\n\nThe beginning of the pandemic was a scary, uncertain time. According to U.S. Census Bureau reporting, many parents wanted to keep their children at home, not just to ensure social distancing but also to meet their socio-emotional needs. The Bureau\u2019s Household Pulse Survey found that from April to October 2020, the number of households with school-age children reporting them as homeschooled rose from 5.4% to 11.1%. Now that the pandemic\u2019s various closures are over in the U.S., it\u2019s clear these sentiments are persisting; many parents no longer trust the public school system. Thanks to \u301043\u2020underfunded schools\u2020www.theguardian.com\u3011 and crowded classrooms, many parents believe their children are no longer getting the attention they deserve. This is especially true for students who need \u301044\u2020special care\u2020apnews.com\u3011 and attention. At home, though, parents hypothetically can control all of these various needs in a personalized way.\n\nHow are educators responding to this rise in homeschooling across the U.S.? Educator and philanthropist \u301045\u2020Diane Lewis\u2020www.linkedin.com\u3011, who founded \u301046\u2020Firefly Tutors\u2020www.fireflytutors.com\u3011 two years ago with the aim to impart high-quality yet affordable education to her students, had this to say.\n\n### Diane\u2019s Thoughts\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a growing trend of parents choosing to homeschool in the US. Nearly 7% of parents homeschool one or more of their children. In California, where I reside, it\u2019s more than 9%, and numbers are rising. Why?\n\nDue to a variety of reasons, parents are bridging the gaps in education for their children. A child may not be receiving adequate instruction at a brick-and-mortar school. This doesn\u2019t mean that the teachers are terrible or that the schools are bad! Unfortunately, our education system needs reform to better fund and serve students with special needs, those that are gifted, and those with unique learning differences.\n\nMany great private schools offer specialized learning programs, but most parents can\u2019t afford the tuition. Homeschool offers a simple, affordable alternative for parents who want customized learning. Each student is unique. Homeschooling allows for targeted blends of sensory integration into the learning process, which promotes greater comprehension and retention that helps each student to reach their highest potential.\u201d\n\nFollow us on social media for the latest updates in B2B!\n\n\u301047\u2020 \u2020www.linkedin.com\u3011 \u301048\u2020 \u2020twitter.com\u3011 \u301049\u2020 \u2020www.instagram.com\u3011 \n\n\u301050\u2020 \u2020company.marketscale.com\u3011 \n\n### Latest\n\n\u301051\u2020 \u3011 \n\n#####  \u301051\u2020Revolutionize Truck Driver Engagement in Logistics: Integrate Texting and Social Media for Stronger Relationships and Increased Efficiency\u3011 \n\nMarch 29, 2024\n\nThe logistics and supply chain sector is undergoing a significant transformation, driven by the need for more efficient communication channels between companies and frontline workers, particularly truck drivers. This shift is not just about adopting new technologies; it\u2019s about finding practical solutions that cater to the real-world usage habits of these critical players What [\u2026]\n\n\u301051\u2020Read More\u3011 \n\n\u301052\u2020 \u3011 \n\n#####  \u301052\u2020Population Health is Becoming Precision Community Health\u3011 \n\nMarch 29, 2024\n\nThe concept of population health is evolving rapidly, with a significant shift towards a more targeted approach known as Precision Community Health. Driving this change is the realization that broad health initiatives often overlook the nuanced needs of specific communities, particularly those in rural areas or experiencing generational poverty. With 80% of health outcomes [\u2026]\n\n\u301052\u2020Read More\u3011 \n\n\u301053\u2020 \u3011 \n\n#####  \u301053\u2020ICOM at IWCE 2024: IP730 is the Solution to Scalable and Effective Communication Systems for Critical Services\u3011 \n\nMarch 28, 2024\n\nAt the International Wireless Communication Expo (IWCE) 2024 trade show in Orlando, the spotlight was on the latest advancements in communication technology, crucial for sectors like the military, emergency services, and public transportation. This event is a vital meeting point for professionals seeking innovative solutions to enhance their operational communication capabilities across vast distances. This episode of Just Thinking, with host Kevin Dougherty, examines this pressing issue with Dr. Sam Nix, the Chief of Schools for the Duncanville Independent School District. Homeschooling allows for targeted blends of sensory integration into the learning process, which promotes greater comprehension and retention that helps each student to reach their highest potential.\u201d\n\nFollow us on social media for the latest updates in B2B!\n\n\u301047\u2020 \u2020www.linkedin.com\u3011 \u301048\u2020 \u2020twitter.com\u3011 \u301049\u2020 \u2020www.instagram.com\u3011 \n\n\u301050\u2020 \u2020company.marketscale.com\u3011 \n\n### Latest\n\n\u301051\u2020 \u3011 \n\n#####  \u301051\u2020Revolutionize Truck Driver Engagement in Logistics: Integrate Texting and Social Media for Stronger Relationships and Increased Efficiency\u3011 \n\nMarch 29, 2024\n\nThe logistics and supply chain sector is undergoing a significant transformation, driven by the need for more efficient communication channels between companies and frontline workers, particularly truck drivers. Effective Grant Management in Education with Cory Green\u3011 \n\nMarch 25, 2024\n\nGrant management in education takes center stage in a compelling discussion on Just Thinking, where host Kevin Dougherty engages with Cory Green, the Associate Commissioner for Grant Compliance and Administration at the Texas Education Agency (TEA). The homeschooling market is expanding, driven by various factors including concerns over school environments, a desire for personalized instruction, and dissatisfaction with traditional schooling methods. The homeschooling sector in the United States alone has seen a compound annual growth rate of 9.8% from 2019 to 2029, with projections indicating the market could reach USD 10.14 billion by 2029\u30106\u2020source\u3011\u30105\u2020source\u3011.\n\nA considerable portion of this growth stems from parents&#x27; concerns over school safety, academic quality, and the desire to provide religious or moral instruction, among other reasons. Additionally, there&#x27;s a high level of interest in homeschooling for middle school-aged students (grades 6 to 8), which represents the highest rate of homeschooling among all grade levels. It&#x27;s also notable that a significant portion of homeschooling households have three or more children, and many of these households fall into higher income brackets\u30105\u2020source\u3011.\n\nThe shift towards homeschooling has been further fueled by the COVID-19 pandemic, with many parents continuing to choose homeschooling due to dissatisfaction with the public school system and a desire for a more tailored educational experience for their children. This trend is supported by a variety of educational resources and platforms, with a wide range of teaching methods such as the Classical Method, Charlotte Mason Method, Montessori Method, and Unit Studies being popular among homeschooling families\u30107\u2020source\u3011\u30106\u2020source\u3011.\n\nGiven these insights, creating courses that cater to the diverse needs of homeschooling families can be quite promising. Course creators should consider developing curriculums that are adaptable to different teaching methods, offer personalized learning experiences, and cater to a wide range of subjects across various grade levels. Additionally, focusing on subjects where parents feel less confident in teaching, such as advanced science or math, could fulfill an important niche in the homeschooling market. \n\nWith the growing prevalence of online homeschooling platforms and the continuous search for high-quality educational content, there&#x27;s a significant opportunity to contribute to this expanding market by offering courses that address these needs and preferences."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [100260]}, "citations": [{"start_ix": 531, "end_ix": 541, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "Home-schooling Market Share", "url": "https://www.adroitmarketresearch.com/industry-reports/home-schooling-market", "text": "\nHome-schooled students frequently participate in social and educational activities with persons who are not part of their immediate family outside of their homes. They frequently participate in events like field excursions, scouting, 4-H, political campaigns, church ministries, sports teams, and volunteer work in the community. The majority of the data to date indicates that home-school students might experience less damage (such as abuse, neglect, or mortality) than students in traditional schools.\n\nThe market for homeschooling is expected to expand from USD 5.41 billion in 2019 to USD 10.14 billion in 2029, at a CAGR of 9.8% over the course of the projection period.\n\n[Image 3: The Global Home-schooling Market 2019-2029 (USD Billion)]\n\nThis market is growing as a result of both the choice for homeschooling over traditional education and the increased need for individualised instruction.\n\nThe lack of understanding of this idea and the scarcity of qualified home-schooling teachers are two factors limiting the growth of the global home-schooling sector. Another significant barrier to the expansion of this sector is the high expense of homeschooling. Meanwhile, the industry is anticipated to increase significantly due to the rising popularity of online home-schooling platforms and the availability of government funding.\n\nThe key players in the market are Abeka, BrainPOP, Duolingo, Sonlight, MEL Science, PITSCO, Compass, Khan Academy Classroom, IXL, RightStart Mathematics, KinderIQ, and eTAP. To increase their market share in the worldwide home-schooling market, these competitors have used a variety of growth methods, including joint ventures, agreements, mergers and acquisitions, expansions, partnerships, product launches and advancements, and collaborations.\n\nRecent Developments of the Home-schooling Market\n\n  * 2019 saw the opening of a brand-new public online school in Colorado by K12 Inc. and Galileo Learning. Students in grades K\u20138 will be able to get personalised instruction at the school.\n  * Toto gives its pupils a more comprehensive K\u20138 reading solution, Connections Academy, a major provider The top reason for homeschooling is a concern about school environment.\n\nAccording to National Center for Education Statistics (IES) homeschooling facts, the top reason for homeschooling is a concern about school environment, such as safety, drugs, and negative peer pressure. (4)\n\nReasons for Homeschooling Percentage   \nSafe environment concerns 25% of parents   \nBad academic quality 14.5% of parents   \nTo provide religious instruction 13% of parents   \nTo provide moral instruction 6.6% of parents   \nHealth problems 3.6% of parents\u00a0  \nSpecial needs 7.3% of parents   \nTo provide nontraditional education 7.7% of parents   \nEmphasis on family 8.3% of parents   \nOther reasons 14% of parents  \n\nThe second most popular reason was dissatisfaction with the academic instruction at schools, followed by a desire to provide religious instruction.\n\nBut not all parents want to homeschool their children.\u00a0\n\nAccording to EdChoice statistics against homeschooling, socialization is the most common reason why parents have not yet homeschooled their children. (5)\n\nReasons Not to Homeschool Percentage   \nChild will not be prepared socially for real-life 16% of parents   \nCoordinating with work schedule 15% of parents   \nTime management 14% of parents   \nNote sure if realistically doable 13% of parents   \nDon\u2019t want to disrupt child\u2019s relationships 12% of parents   \nDon\u2019t want to disrupt child\u2019s current schooling 12% of parents   \nOther reasons 18% of parents  \n\nThe second most common reason not to homeschool is the problem with coordinating homeschool with work schedule followed by time management.\n\n### 4. Homeschool students outperform institutional school students academically.\n\nAccording to National Home Education Research Institute (NHERI) homeschooling success statistics, 78% of peer-reviewed studies on academic achievements show that homeschool students perform statistically significantly better than students in institutional schools. (6)\n\nHere are some brief summaries of studies on homeschooling.\n\nAuthor(s)Results of the Studies   \nMurphy, 2012; Ray, 2013, 2017 Homeschooled score 15 to 30 percentile points above public-school students on standardized academic achievement tests. The public school average is the 50th percentile; scores range from 1 to 99.  \nRay, 2015 Black homeschool students scored 23 to 42 percentile points above Black public school students.  \nMartin-Chang et al., 2011 Researchers found that children from structured homeschool settings outperformed their conventional school peers (by 0.06 to 0.15 effect sizes).  \nRudner, 1999 Median scores for home school students fell between the 70th and 80th percentile. The study concluded that those parents choosing to make a commitment to homeschooling are able to provide a very successful academic environment.  \nMurphy, 2012; Ray, 2017 Home-educated students typically score above average on the college admission SAT and ACT tests.  \nCogan, 2010 College students who were homeschooled earn higher first-year and fourth-year GPAs when controlling for demographic, pre-college, engagement, and first-term academic factors.  \n\nThe majority of peer-reviewed research papers on homeschooling found a positive effect of homeschooling compared to institutional schooling. The same positive outcomes were also revealed regarding social and emotional development. (6)\n\nThe positive effect was real and measurable also for homeschooled students who later became adults compared to those who had been in conventional schools.\n\n### 5. The highest homeschooling rate is among students with a grade equivalent of 6 to 8.\n\nAccording to National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) latest homeschooled kids statistics, the highest homeschooling rate is among students with a grade equivalent of 6 to 8. (7)\n\nGrade Equivalent Homeschooled   \n2019 Homeschooled   \n2016 Homeschooled   \n2012   \nKindergarten 8%11%12%  \nGrades 1 to 3 22%18%20%  \nGrades 4 to 5 18%17%15%  \nGrades 6 to 8 29%24%24%  \nGrades 9 to 12 22%31%29%  \n\nInterestingly enough, the dominant grade equivalent of 6-8 has shifted from grades 9-12 since 2012. (7)\n\nOverall, the grade distribution is roughly even across all grade levels above kindergarten.\n\n### 6. 48% of homeschooling households have three or more children.\n\nAccording to National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) homeschool demographics data, a surprising 48% of homeschooling households have three or more children. (7)\n\n3+ Children 2 Children 1 Child   \n48% of households 33% of households 19% of households  \n\nInterestingly enough, the homeschool data shows that only 19% of homeschooling households have 1 child and 33% have 2 children.\n\nOne can argue anecdotally, that in a household with three or more children, there\u2019s already a significantly higher focus on kids. So perhaps it can be easier to homeschool all of them together.\n\nWhite Black Hispanic Asian Other   \n70%6%17%2%6%  \n\nThe NCES data also shows that 7 in 10 homeschool students are white. (7)\n\nThe second most common ethnicity of homeschooled children is Hispanic, followed by Black, Asian, and other ethnicities.\u00a0\n\n2 Parents 1 Parent Non-parental   \n83% of homeschoolers 14% of homeschoolers 3% of homeschoolers  \n\nAccording to NCES homeschool families data, 83% of homeschool students live in two-parent households, followed by 14% in 1 parent, and 3% in non-parental households. (7)\n\n### 7. The average cost of homeschooling is $700-$1,800 per student annually.\n\nAccording to Time4Learning homeschooling cost statistics, the average cost of homeschooling is $700-$1,800 per student annually. (8)\n\nCategory Price range   \nCurriculum$350 \u2013 $750   \nSupplies &amp; materials$150 \u2013 $300   \nField trips$100 \u2013 $250   \nExtracurriculars$100 \u2013 $500   \nTotal$700 \u2013 $1,800  \n\nFor a family with two school-aged children, homeschooling may cost on average between $1,400 to $3,600 per year. (8)\n\nIt\u2019s difficult to pinpoint the average cost of homeschooling for everyone as every family has a unique situation.\n\nThe final cost depends on how many children are homeschooled, are there any special needs or health problems, and how logistically accessible libraries, museums, and so on are.\n\n### 8. 1 in 3 homeschooling households has an annual income of over $100,000.\n\nAccording to National Home Education Research Institute (NHERI) homeschool studies, 34% of homeschooling households have an annual income over $100,000. (7)\n\nAnnual Income Homeschooling Households  \n$20,000 or less 10%  \n$20,001 to $50,000 20%  \n$50,001 to $75,000 21%  \n$75,001 to $100,000 15%  \nOver $100,000 34%  \n\nInterestingly enough, the highest income bracket of over $100,000 has the highest share of households. (7)\n\nSecond highest annual income is $50,001 to $75,000 with 21% of households, followed by $20,001 to $50,000 and 20% of households.\n\nEducation Level Homeschooling Parents   \nHigh school diploma or less 23%  \nVocational/technical, associate\u2019s degree, or some college 26%  \nBachelor\u2019s degree/some graduate school 31%  \nGraduate/professional degree 21%  \n\nNHERI data also reveals that 31% of homeschooling parents own a bachelor\u2019s or some graduate school degree. (7)\n\nCan this be correlated with higher annual income? We don\u2019t know, as there\u2019s no formal evidence on this.\n\n### 9. Homeschooling saves about $56 billion of taxpayer money annually.\n\nAccording to National Home Education Research Institute (NHERI), homeschooling saves about $56 billion of taxpayer money annually. (2)\n\nTaxpayer Savings Homeschool Students Public School Cost  \n$56 billion 3.721 million$15,240 per student  \n\nThe reality is that public schools aren\u2019t free. Taxpayers spend on average $15,240 per student annually for public schools.\n\nThe more homeschooled students there are, the bigger savings there will be for the federal government on taxpayers\u2019 money. This is $56 billion of taxpayers\u2019 money that can be used for other causes.\n\n## FAQ\n\n### How much does homeschooling cost?\n\nThe average cost of homeschooling is $700-$1,800 per student annually.\n\n### What is homeschooling?\n\nHomeschooling is a parent-led home-based education form that is the fastest-growing in the U.S.\n\n### How many homeschool students are in the U.S.?\n\nThere are 3.7 million homeschool students in the U.S. Homeschool students make up 6.73% of all school-aged children.\n\n### Do homeschool students perform better?\n\nYes, homeschool students outperform institutional school students academically.\n\n### What percentage of students are homeschooled?\n\n6.73% (3.7 million) of all school-aged children in the U.S. are homeschooled.\n\n### Will homeschooling increase after the pandemic?\n\nYes, homeschooling rates doubled after the lockdowns in the U.S.\n\n## References\n\n  1. The average cost of homeschooling is $700-$1,800 per student annually.\n\nAccording to Time4Learning homeschooling cost statistics, the average cost of homeschooling is $700-$1,800 per student annually. (8)\n\nCategory Price range   \nCurriculum$350 \u2013 $750   \nSupplies &amp; materials$150 \u2013 $300   \nField trips$100 \u2013 $250   \nExtracurriculars$100 \u2013 $500   \nTotal$700 \u2013 $1,800  \n\nFor a family with two school-aged children, homeschooling may cost on average between $1,400 to $3,600 per year. (8)\n\nIt\u2019s difficult to pinpoint the average cost of homeschooling for everyone as every family has a unique situation.\n\nThe final cost depends on how many children are homeschooled, are there any special needs or health problems, and how logistically accessible libraries, museums, and so on are.\n\n### 8. 1 in 3 homeschooling households has an annual income of over $100,000.\n\nAccording to National Home Education Research Institute (NHERI) homeschool studies, 34% of homeschooling households have an annual income over $100,000. (7)\n\nAnnual Income Homeschooling Households  \n$20,000 or less 10%  \n$20,001 to $50,000 20%  \n$50,001 to $75,000 21%  \n$75,001 to $100,000 15%  \nOver $100,000 34%  \n\nInterestingly enough, the highest income bracket of over $100,000 has the highest share of households. (7)\n\nSecond highest annual income is $50,001 to $75,000 with 21% of households, followed by $20,001 to $50,000 and 20% of households.\n\nEducation Level Homeschooling Parents   \nHigh school diploma or less 23%  \nVocational/technical, associate\u2019s degree, or some college 26%  \nBachelor\u2019s degree/some graduate school 31%  \nGraduate/professional degree 21%  \n\nNHERI data also reveals that 31% of homeschooling parents own a bachelor\u2019s or some graduate school degree. (7)\n\nCan this be correlated with higher annual income? We don\u2019t know, as there\u2019s no formal evidence on this.\n\n### 9. Homeschooling saves about $56 billion of taxpayer money annually.\n\nAccording to National Home Education Research Institute (NHERI), homeschooling saves about $56 billion of taxpayer money annually. (2)\n\nTaxpayer Savings Homeschool Students Public School Cost  \n$56 billion 3.721 million$15,240 per student  \n\nThe reality is that public schools aren\u2019t free. Taxpayers spend on average $15,240 per student annually for public schools.\n\nThe more homeschooled students there are, the bigger savings there will be for the federal government on taxpayers\u2019 money. This is $56 billion of taxpayers\u2019 money that can be used for other causes.\n\n## FAQ\n\n### How much does homeschooling cost?\n\nThe average cost of homeschooling is $700-$1,800 per student annually.\n\n### What is homeschooling?\n\nHomeschooling is a parent-led home-based education form that is the fastest-growing in the U.S.\n\n### How many homeschool students are in the U.S.?\n\nThere are 3.7 million homeschool students in the U.S. Homeschool students make up 6.73% of all school-aged children.\n\n### Do homeschool students perform better?\n\nYes, homeschool students outperform institutional school students academically.\n\n### What percentage of students are homeschooled?\n\n6.73% (3.7 million) of all school-aged children in the U.S. are homeschooled.\n\n### Will homeschooling increase after the pandemic?\n\nYes, homeschooling rates doubled after the lockdowns in the U.S.\n\n## References\n\n  1. Today, more and more parents are choosing to \u301041\u2020educate their children at home\u3011, fueling the rise of homeschooling in the U.S.\n\nAccording to a new \u301042\u2020joint analysis\u2020news.stanford.edu\u3011 by the Associated Press and researchers from Stanford University, a whopping 1.2 million K-12 schoolchildren remain missing from public schools since the COVID-19 pandemic first hit in 2020. The study, which examined 22 jurisdictions, found that roughly 26% of these students switched to homeschooling. The question is, what is leading to this rise in homeschooling?\n\nThe beginning of the pandemic was a scary, uncertain time. According to U.S. Census Bureau reporting, many parents wanted to keep their children at home, not just to ensure social distancing but also to meet their socio-emotional needs. The Bureau\u2019s Household Pulse Survey found that from April to October 2020, the number of households with school-age children reporting them as homeschooled rose from 5.4% to 11.1%. Now that the pandemic\u2019s various closures are over in the U.S., it\u2019s clear these sentiments are persisting; many parents no longer trust the public school system. Thanks to \u301043\u2020underfunded schools\u2020www.theguardian.com\u3011 and crowded classrooms, many parents believe their children are no longer getting the attention they deserve. This is especially true for students who need \u301044\u2020special care\u2020apnews.com\u3011 and attention. At home, though, parents hypothetically can control all of these various needs in a personalized way.\n\nHow are educators responding to this rise in homeschooling across the U.S.? Educator and philanthropist \u301045\u2020Diane Lewis\u2020www.linkedin.com\u3011, who founded \u301046\u2020Firefly Tutors\u2020www.fireflytutors.com\u3011 two years ago with the aim to impart high-quality yet affordable education to her students, had this to say.\n\n### Diane\u2019s Thoughts\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a growing trend of parents choosing to homeschool in the US. Nearly 7% of parents homeschool one or more of their children. In California, where I reside, it\u2019s more than 9%, and numbers are rising. Why?\n\nDue to a variety of reasons, parents are bridging the gaps in education for their children. A child may not be receiving adequate instruction at a brick-and-mortar school. This doesn\u2019t mean that the teachers are terrible or that the schools are bad! Unfortunately, our education system needs reform to better fund and serve students with special needs, those that are gifted, and those with unique learning differences.\n\nMany great private schools offer specialized learning programs, but most parents can\u2019t afford the tuition. Homeschool offers a simple, affordable alternative for parents who want customized learning. Each student is unique. Homeschooling allows for targeted blends of sensory integration into the learning process, which promotes greater comprehension and retention that helps each student to reach their highest potential.\u201d\n\nFollow us on social media for the latest updates in B2B!\n\n\u301047\u2020 \u2020www.linkedin.com\u3011 \u301048\u2020 \u2020twitter.com\u3011 \u301049\u2020 \u2020www.instagram.com\u3011 \n\n\u301050\u2020 \u2020company.marketscale.com\u3011 \n\n### Latest\n\n\u301051\u2020 \u3011 \n\n#####  \u301051\u2020Revolutionize Truck Driver Engagement in Logistics: Integrate Texting and Social Media for Stronger Relationships and Increased Efficiency\u3011 \n\nMarch 29, 2024\n\nThe logistics and supply chain sector is undergoing a significant transformation, driven by the need for more efficient communication channels between companies and frontline workers, particularly truck drivers. They frequently participate in events like field excursions, scouting, 4-H, political campaigns, church ministries, sports teams, and volunteer work in the community. The majority of the data to date indicates that home-school students might experience less damage (such as abuse, neglect, or mortality) than students in traditional schools.\n\nThe market for homeschooling is expected to expand from USD 5.41 billion in 2019 to USD 10.14 billion in 2029, at a CAGR of 9.8% over the course of the projection period.\n\n[Image 3: The Global Home-schooling Market 2019-2029 (USD Billion)]\n\nThis market is growing as a result of both the choice for homeschooling over traditional education and the increased need for individualised instruction.\n\nThe lack of understanding of this idea and the scarcity of qualified home-schooling teachers are two factors limiting the growth of the global home-schooling sector. Another significant barrier to the expansion of this sector is the high expense of homeschooling. Meanwhile, the industry is anticipated to increase significantly due to the rising popularity of online home-schooling platforms and the availability of government funding.\n\nThe key players in the market are Abeka, BrainPOP, Duolingo, Sonlight, MEL Science, PITSCO, Compass, Khan Academy Classroom, IXL, RightStart Mathematics, KinderIQ, and eTAP. To increase their market share in the worldwide home-schooling market, these competitors have used a variety of growth methods, including joint ventures, agreements, mergers and acquisitions, expansions, partnerships, product launches and advancements, and collaborations.\n\nRecent Developments of the Home-schooling Market\n\n  * 2019 saw the opening of a brand-new public online school in Colorado by K12 Inc. and Galileo Learning. (USD Billion)\n\nNorth America\n\n  * The U.S\n  * Canada\n\nEurope\n\n  * Germany\n  * France\n  * The UK\n  * Rest of Europe\n\nThe Asia Pacific\n\n  * China\n  * India\n  * Japan\n  * Rest of Asia Pacific\n\nSouth America\n\n  * Mexico\n  * Brazil\n  * Rest of South America\n\nThe Middle East and South Africa\n\n[Image 4: This Report Includes] [Image 5: Why Choose Us] \n\n##### Frequently Asked \u301095\u2020 What are the application of home-schooling market? \u3011 \n\nThe application of the home-schooling market K4-K5, Grades 1-6, Grades 7-8, Grades 9-12 and other. \n\n####  \u301096\u2020 To get a customized report, please share your exact research requirements. *\n\nSubmit Request\n\nFull Name *\n\nCountry *  Select Country Afghanistan Aland Albania Algeria American"}, {"matched_text": "\u30105\u2020source\u3011", "start_idx": 541, "end_idx": 551, "alt": null, "type": "webpage_extended", "title": "Homeschooling Statistics in 2024 (Latest U.S. Data) | Parenting Mode", "url": "https://parentingmode.com/homeschooling/", "pub_date": null, "snippet": "\n### 3. The top reason for homeschooling is a concern about school environment.\n\nAccording to National Center for Education Statistics (IES) homeschooling facts, the top reason for homeschooling is a concern about school environment, such as safety, drugs, and negative peer pressure. (4)\n\nReasons for Homeschooling Percentage   \nSafe environment concerns 25% of parents   \nBad academic quality 14.5% of parents   \nTo provide religious instruction 13% of parents   \nTo provide moral instruction 6.6% of parents   \nHealth problems 3.6% of parents\u00a0  \nSpecial needs 7.3% of parents   \nTo provide nontraditional education 7.7% of parents   \nEmphasis on family 8.3% of parents   \nOther reasons 14% of parents  \n\nThe second most popular reason was dissatisfaction with the academic instruction at schools, followed by a desire to provide religious instruction.\n\nBut not all parents want to homeschool their children.\u00a0\n\nAccording to EdChoice statistics against homeschooling, socialization is the most common reason why parents have not yet homeschooled their children. (5)\n\nReasons Not to Homeschool Percentage   \nChild will not be prepared socially for real-life 16% of parents   \nCoordinating with work schedule 15% of parents   \nTime management 14% of parents   \nNote sure if realistically doable 13% of parents   \nDon\u2019t want to disrupt child\u2019s relationships 12% of parents   \nDon\u2019t want to disrupt child\u2019s current schooling 12% of parents   \nOther reasons 18% of parents  \n\nThe second most common reason not to homeschool is the problem with coordinating homeschool with work schedule followed by time management.\n\n### 4. Homeschool students outperform institutional school students academically.\n\nAccording to National Home Education Research Institute (NHERI) homeschooling success statistics, 78% of peer-reviewed studies on academic achievements show that homeschool students perform statistically significantly better than students in institutional schools. (6)\n\nHere are some brief summaries of studies on homeschooling.\n\nAuthor(s)Results of the Studies   \nMurphy, 2012; Ray, 2013, 2017 Homeschooled score 15 to 30 percentile points above public-school students on standardized academic achievement tests. The public school average is the 50th percentile; scores range from 1 to 99.  \nRay, 2015 Black homeschool students scored 23 to 42 percentile points above Black public school students.  \nMartin-Chang et al., 2011 Researchers found that children from structured homeschool settings outperformed their conventional school peers (by 0.06 to 0.15 effect sizes).  \nRudner, 1999 Median scores for home school students fell between the 70th and 80th percentile. The study concluded that those parents choosing to make a commitment to homeschooling are able to provide a very successful academic environment.  \nMurphy, 2012; Ray, 2017 Home-educated students typically score above average on the college admission SAT and ACT tests.  \nCogan, 2010 College students who were homeschooled earn higher first-year and fourth-year GPAs when controlling for demographic, pre-college, engagement, and first-term academic factors.  \n\nThe majority of peer-reviewed research papers on homeschooling found a positive effect of homeschooling compared to institutional schooling. The same positive outcomes were also revealed regarding social and emotional development. (6)\n\nThe positive effect was real and measurable also for homeschooled students who later became adults compared to those who had been in conventional schools.\n\n### 5. The highest homeschooling rate is among students with a grade equivalent of 6 to 8.\n\nAccording to National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) latest homeschooled kids statistics, the highest homeschooling rate is among students with a grade equivalent of 6 to 8. (7)\n\nGrade Equivalent Homeschooled   \n2019 Homeschooled   \n2016 Homeschooled   \n2012   \nKindergarten 8%11%12%  \nGrades 1 to 3 22%18%20%  \nGrades 4 to 5 18%17%15%  \nGrades 6 to 8 29%24%24%  \nGrades 9 to 12 22%31%29%  \n\nInterestingly enough, the dominant grade equivalent of 6-8 has shifted from grades 9-12 since 2012. (7)\n\nOverall, the grade distribution is roughly even across all grade levels above kindergarten.\n\n### 6. 48% of homeschooling households have three or more children.\n\nAccording to National Center for Education Statistics (NCES) homeschool demographics data, a surprising 48% of homeschooling households have three or more children. (7)\n\n3+ Children 2 Children 1 Child   \n48% of households 33% of households 19% of households  \n\nInterestingly enough, the homeschool data shows that only 19% of homeschooling households have 1 child and 33% have 2 children.\n\nOne can argue anecdotally, that in a household with three or more children, there\u2019s already a significantly higher focus on kids. So perhaps it can be easier to homeschool all of them together.\n\nWhite Black Hispanic Asian Other   \n70%6%17%2%6%  \n\nThe NCES data also shows that 7 in 10 homeschool students are white. (7)\n\nThe second most common ethnicity of homeschooled children is Hispanic, followed by Black, Asian, and other ethnicities.\u00a0\n\n2 Parents 1 Parent Non-parental   \n83% of homeschoolers 14% of homeschoolers 3% of homeschoolers  \n\nAccording to NCES homeschool families data, 83% of homeschool students live in two-parent households, followed by 14% in 1 parent, and 3% in non-parental households. (7)\n\n### 7. The average cost of homeschooling is $700-$1,800 per student annually.\n\nAccording to Time4Learning homeschooling cost statistics, the average cost of homeschooling is $700-$1,800 per student annually. (8)\n\nCategory Price range   \nCurriculum$350 \u2013 $750   \nSupplies &amp; materials$150 \u2013 $300   \nField trips$100 \u2013 $250   \nExtracurriculars$100 \u2013 $500   \nTotal$700 \u2013 $1,800  \n\nFor a family with two school-aged children, homeschooling may cost on average between $1,400 to $3,600 per year. (8)\n\nIt\u2019s difficult to pinpoint the average cost of homeschooling for everyone as every family has a unique situation.\n\nThe final cost depends on how many children are homeschooled, are there any special needs or health problems, and how logistically accessible libraries, museums, and so on are.\n\n### 8. 1 in 3 homeschooling households has an annual income of over $100,000.\n\nAccording to National Home Education Research Institute (NHERI) homeschool studies, 34% of homeschooling households have an annual income over $100,000. (7)\n\nAnnual Income Homeschooling Households  \n$20,000 or less 10%  \n$20,001 to $50,000 20%  \n$50,001 to $75,000 21%  \n$75,001 to $100,000 15%  \nOver $100,000 34%  \n\nInterestingly enough, the highest income bracket of over $100,000 has the highest share of households. (7)\n\nSecond highest annual income is $50,001 to $75,000 with 21% of households, followed by $20,001 to $50,000 and 20% of households.\n\nEducation Level Homeschooling Parents   \nHigh school diploma or less 23%  \nVocational/technical, associate\u2019s degree, or some college 26%  \nBachelor\u2019s degree/some graduate school 31%  \nGraduate/professional degree 21%  \n\nNHERI data also reveals that 31% of homeschooling parents own a bachelor\u2019s or some graduate school degree. (7)\n\nCan this be correlated with higher annual income? We don\u2019t know, as there\u2019s no formal evidence on this.\n\n### 9. Homeschooling saves about $56 billion of taxpayer money annually.\n\nAccording to National Home Education Research Institute (NHERI), homeschooling saves about $56 billion of taxpayer money annually. (2)\n\nTaxpayer Savings Homeschool Students Public School Cost  \n$56 billion 3.721 million$15,240 per student  \n\nThe reality is that public schools aren\u2019t free. Taxpayers spend on average $15,240 per student annually for public schools.\n\nThe more homeschooled students there are, the bigger savings there will be for the federal government on taxpayers\u2019 money. This is $56 billion of taxpayers\u2019 money that can be used for other causes.\n\n## FAQ\n\n### How much does homeschooling cost?\n\nThe average cost of homeschooling is $700-$1,800 per student annually.\n\n### What is homeschooling?\n\nHomeschooling is a parent-led home-based education form that is the fastest-growing in the U.S.\n\n### How many homeschool students are in the U.S.?\n\nThere are 3.7 million homeschool students in the U.S. Homeschool students make up 6.73% of all school-aged children.\n\n### Do homeschool students perform better?\n\nYes, homeschool students outperform institutional school students academically.\n\n### What percentage of students are homeschooled?\n\n6.73% (3.7 million) of all school-aged children in the U.S. are homeschooled.\n\n### Will homeschooling increase after the pandemic?\n\nYes, homeschooling rates doubled after the lockdowns in the U.S.\n\n## References\n\n  1. National Home Education Research Institute. 2021. How Many Homeschool Students Are There in the United States? Today, more and more parents are choosing to \u301041\u2020educate their children at home\u3011, fueling the rise of homeschooling in the U.S.\n\nAccording to a new \u301042\u2020joint analysis\u2020news.stanford.edu\u3011 by the Associated Press and researchers from Stanford University, a whopping 1.2 million K-12 schoolchildren remain missing from public schools since the COVID-19 pandemic first hit in 2020. The study, which examined 22 jurisdictions, found that roughly 26% of these students switched to homeschooling. The question is, what is leading to this rise in homeschooling?\n\nThe beginning of the pandemic was a scary, uncertain time. According to U.S. Census Bureau reporting, many parents wanted to keep their children at home, not just to ensure social distancing but also to meet their socio-emotional needs. The Bureau\u2019s Household Pulse Survey found that from April to October 2020, the number of households with school-age children reporting them as homeschooled rose from 5.4% to 11.1%. Now that the pandemic\u2019s various closures are over in the U.S., it\u2019s clear these sentiments are persisting; many parents no longer trust the public school system. Thanks to \u301043\u2020underfunded schools\u2020www.theguardian.com\u3011 and crowded classrooms, many parents believe their children are no longer getting the attention they deserve. This is especially true for students who need \u301044\u2020special care\u2020apnews.com\u3011 and attention. At home, though, parents hypothetically can control all of these various needs in a personalized way.\n\nHow are educators responding to this rise in homeschooling across the U.S.? Educator and philanthropist \u301045\u2020Diane Lewis\u2020www.linkedin.com\u3011, who founded \u301046\u2020Firefly Tutors\u2020www.fireflytutors.com\u3011 two years ago with the aim to impart high-quality yet affordable education to her students, had this to say.\n\n### Diane\u2019s Thoughts\n\n\u201cThere\u2019s a growing trend of parents choosing to homeschool in the US. Nearly 7% of parents homeschool one or more of their children. In California, where I reside, it\u2019s more than 9%, and numbers are rising. Why?\n\nDue to a variety of reasons, parents are bridging the gaps in education for their children. A child may not be receiving adequate instruction at a brick-and-mortar school. This doesn\u2019t mean that the teachers are terrible or that the schools are bad! Unfortunately, our education system needs reform to better fund and serve students with special needs, those that are gifted, and those with unique learning differences.\n\nMany great private schools offer specialized learning programs, but most parents can\u2019t afford the tuition. Homeschool offers a simple, affordable alternative for parents who want customized learning. Each student is unique. Homeschooling allows for targeted blends of sensory integration into the learning process, which promotes greater comprehension and retention that helps each student to reach their highest potential.\u201d\n\nFollow us on social media for the latest updates in B2B!\n\n\u301047\u2020 \u2020www.linkedin.com\u3011 \u301048\u2020 \u2020twitter.com\u3011 \u301049\u2020 \u2020www.instagram.com\u3011 \n\n\u301050\u2020 \u2020company.marketscale.com\u3011 \n\n### Latest\n\n\u301051\u2020 \u3011 \n\n#####  \u301051\u2020Revolutionize Truck Driver Engagement in Logistics: Integrate Texting and Social Media for Stronger Relationships and Increased Efficiency\u3011 \n\nMarch 29, 2024\n\nThe logistics and supply chain sector is undergoing a significant transformation, driven by the need for more efficient communication channels between companies and frontline workers, particularly truck drivers. The majority of the data to date indicates that home-school students might experience less damage (such as abuse, neglect, or mortality) than students in traditional schools.\n\nThe market for homeschooling is expected to expand from USD 5.41 billion in 2019 to USD 10.14 billion in 2029, at a CAGR of 9.8% over the course of the projection period.\n\n[Image 3: The Global Home-schooling Market 2019-2029 (USD Billion)]\n\nThis market is growing as a result of both the choice for homeschooling over traditional education and the increased need for individualised instruction.\n\nThe lack of understanding of this idea and the scarcity of qualified home-schooling teachers are two factors limiting the growth of the global home-schooling sector.
