LinkedIn Live isn\u2019t available to every user; you must meet certain requirements to get access. The platform also offers no monetization options.\n\nWho should stream on LinkedIn? Any professionals who want to promote an event, take others behind the scenes of their companies, recruit new employees, establish industry authority by interviewing experts, or demonstrate expertise with tutorials and seminars.\n\nFeatures \n\n  * Live chat and moderation tools \n  * Analytics \n  * Create an event on LinkedIn and stream directly to it \n  * Save previous live streams as recordings \n  * Gather questions from event attendees before the stream starts \n  * Need a third-party streaming tool to go live on LinkedIn \n\nPros \n\n  * Access to a young and affluent audience \n  * Previous live streams appear on your profile as regular posts \n  * LinkedIn pages can require viewer registration for live streamed events \n\nCons \n\n  * Must have 150 followers and be active on LinkedIn to live stream \n  * No monetization options\n\n\u00a0Get started on LinkedIn with our \u301033\u2020full guide to LinkedIn Live streaming\u3011.\u00a0\n\n### 8. X (Twitter)\n\nX (Twitter) might not be as large as Facebook or YouTube, but live streamers still have access to \u301034\u2020353.9 million worldwide users\u2020www.oberlo.com\u3011. You can live stream on X through the app and on desktop, but you\u2019ll need to use X\u2019s Media Studio Producer with live streaming encoding software for the latter. You can also \u301035\u2020connect with Restream\u2020support.restream.io\u3011. When you go live on X, you can share a link directly to the stream, making it much easier for your audience to find it.\u00a0\n\nFeatures \n\n  * Go live through the mobile app and on desktop \n  * Live videos posted as a tweet on your profile \n  * Live chat \n  * Monetization options \n  * Invite a friend to co-host the stream with you \n  * Tag a location when streaming \n  * Stream from desktop with Media Studio Producer or a third-party tool like Restream \n\nPros \n\n  * Option to save your stream on your mobile device after it\u2019s over \n  * Add a custom starting point so viewers don\u2019t have to rewatch the entire stream \n  * Send a link directly to your stream \n  * Past live streams appear on your profile as video tweets \n\nCons \n\n  * All streams are public \u2014 no streaming to select audience available \n  * Limited monetization options \n\nGet started streaming on X with our \u301036\u2020ultimate guide to X (Twitter) live streaming\u3011.\n\n### 9. IBM Video Streaming\n\n\u301037\u2020IBM Video Streaming\u2020www.ibm.com\u3011 is a live streaming and VOD-hosting platform that lets you broadcast to multiple content delivery networks (CDNs). It\u2019s scalable, letting you host internal employee meetings or massive virtual events. IBM\u2019s video streaming service is for professional and enterprise use cases and comes with features like HD broadcasting, dedicated support, password-protected channels and video recording.\n\nIBM\u2019s streaming platform isn\u2019t free to use but you can sign up for a 30-day free trial. Also, the pricing tiers are based on viewer hours and if you surpass your allotted monthly hours, you could be charged an extra fee.\n\nFeatures \n\n  * Live chat with polling and Q&amp;A \n  * On-demand captioning \n  * 720p broadcasting \n  * VOD storage \n  * Customizable channel page \n  * Save recordings of live videos \n  * Videos are viewable on mobile devices \n  * Video analytics \n\nPros \n\n  * Can support a large audience \n  * Create a central repository for videos \n  * Optional event registration feature \n  * Stores video on a separate cloud to free up space \n\nCons \n\n  * Higher number of users can lead to increased wait times to join a stream \n  * Live chat is less useful for large events \n  * Not free to use \n\nPricing \n\nIBM doesn\u2019t list its pricing and you have to contact the company to find out the exact fees. There are three tiers:\n\n  * Silver: 100 viewer hours, 5 channels, 1 TB video storage and other features \n  * Gold: 2,000 viewer hours, 10 channels, 2 TB video storage and other features \n  * Platinum: 5,000 viewer hours, 20 channels, 5 TB video storage and other features \n\nYou can also create a custom plan if you have high-volume needs.\n\n### 10. Livestream by Vimeo \n\nVimeo acquired the \u301038\u2020Livestream\u2020livestream.com\u3011 platform in 2017 and today offers live video streaming and video hosting to businesses of all sizes. Video hosting with Vimeo is free but to access the live streaming functionality, you\u2019ll need one of its paid plans. Vimeo has also developed proprietary streaming hardware and software that integrates seamlessly with its live streaming platform, offering users a more all-in-one experience. If you want to start your own paid subscription channel, you can use Vimeo\u2019s over-the-top (OTT) media features. Some of the most common ones for streamers are:\n\n  * StreamElements for one-time donations and tips. This platform integrates easily with Twitch, YouTube, Facebook Gaming and Trovo, and it offers different payment options.\n  * Patreon for regular donations/subscriptions. With the ability to let patrons set monthly pledges, Patreon is the closest you can get to a subscription system without going through a streaming platform\u2019s program.\n  * GoFundMe or Kickstarter for project-based funding. If you have a project to complete and you\u2019re looking for funding, set up pages on these websites and use your live streams to promote it.\n\nIf you stream with \u30101\u2020Restream\u3011, you can easily add a Patreon or GoFundMe \u301016\u2020link as a QR code\u2020support.restream.io\u3011 that you can display as an overlay on your stream.\n\nFor most of these services, you should consider creating special rewards and content for the people who support you. Decide carefully which content goes behind the paywall and which stays free, though. You can\u2019t keep all your best stuff locked behind a subscription; some of it has to stay free to attract new viewers.\n\n## 3. Paid subscriptions from viewers \n\nGetting an occasional tip from your viewers is great, but regular payments are better. These payments will usually net you a couple of dollars each, but if you can get enough of them, they add up. You\u2019ll need to meet certain requirements to enable this kind of support, as platforms reserve it for members of their content creator programs.\n\nHere\u2019s an overview of recurring payment features on the major platforms:\n\n  * YouTube has a \u301024\u2020channel membership program\u2020creatoracademy.youtube.com\u3011 that allows users to subscribe to its channels with monthly payments. To open your YouTube channel (where you group your videos) to this opportunity, you need to be in the \u301025\u2020YouTube Partner Program\u2020support.google.com\u3011 and meet additional eligibility requirements.\n  * Twitch has a \u301026\u2020paid subscription program\u2020www.twitch.tv\u3011 that lets you earn from paid subscriptions if you\u2019re an \u301020\u2020Affiliate\u3011 or Partner. Your viewers get one subscription for free through Twitch Prime, or they can pay for them using PayPal, Amazon Pay, or credit cards.\n  * Facebook Gaming \u301027\u2020extended its Fan Subscriptions feature\u2020www.facebook.com\u3011 to Level Up gaming content creators. You must achieve a certain number of returning weekly viewers, and the feature is only available in certain regions.\n\nIf the platform allows it, you should make content that\u2019s exclusive to your subscribers. It\u2019s a nice way to show your most loyal viewers that you appreciate their support. Also, remember to give a shoutout to people when they subscribe and a mention on their subscription anniversaries.\n\nYou can also use third-party services like Patreon to set up recurring payments or subscriptions from fans.\n\n## 4. Revenue from ads \n\nAdvertising revenue powers half the internet, including Google services and Facebook. Why not you too? If you join the right streaming platform or social network, you can start earning some decent ad money.\n\nWhen you start broadcasting live videos on a specific platform, like YouTube or Facebook, you may be able to take advantage of their advertising programs. Here\u2019s a breakdown of the different types of in-stream ads that are usually available:\n\n  * Pre-roll ads: These ads play as soon as a viewer clicks on your stream. They have to view the ad before they can start watching your content.\n  * Mid-roll ads: Mid-roll ads play in the middle of your live stream. Your stream continues in a smaller window while the ad takes up most of the screen.\n  * Display and overlay ads: These types of ads usually pop up as banners or small cards on top of your stream.\n\nIf you want to generate revenue with ads, join these platforms:\n\n  * \u301028\u2020YouTube\u2020support.google.com\u3011 offers pre-roll and mid-roll ads, as well as display and overlay ads.\n  * \u301029\u2020Facebook\u2020www.facebook.com\u3011 offers mid-roll ads if you meet the viewership number criteria.\n  * \u301030\u2020Twitch\u2020www.twitch.tv\u3011 offers in-stream ads, as well as display and native ad opportunities.\n\nAdvertising in live streaming is a hot topic and a regular cause of controversy. Try to exercise as much control as you can over the advertisements displayed during your streams or on your channel. Also, remember that viewers can use ad-blocking software to prevent some ads from showing. Therefore, using ads as the sole method to monetize your live streaming may not be the best idea.\n\n## 5. Brand deals and sponsorships \n\nBrand deals and sponsorships are another way you can earn money while streaming by engaging with businesses in a mutually beneficial arrangement. If you have a large following on streaming platforms, brands will reach out to you with offers. If they don\u2019t, you can reach out to them.\n\nWhen dealing with brands, it pays to be professional and detail-oriented. You make money when brands agree to pay you. You\u2019ll want to negotiate every part of the deal, to be 100% sure you\u2019re on the same page regarding your commitment.\n\nSome of the ways you can make money include:\n\n  * Sponsorships, where whole streams are sponsored by a brand.\n  * Banners and other types of advertisements you can display during your streams or on your channel or profile page.\n  * Sponsored content, like when a game developer pays you to play their game.\n\nYour audience is what will get a brand\u2019s attention. You should have a decent number of viewers and a clear understanding of who they are, their interests, and the types of problems they need solved. Be mindful of cutting deals that make you look like a sellout. Your audiences might not like that, and if you lose your audience, you lose the sponsors.\n\n## 6. Affiliate programs \n\nWith a membership in an affiliate program, you can earn a commission every time a shopper clicks on your affiliate link and makes a purchase. Sometimes you don\u2019t even have to post a link, because all you need is a promo or coupon code viewers can use when they shop at the place you\u2019re promoting. The link or code is provided to you once you join the affiliate program.\n\nIn the past, you had to place the affiliate link or the code in your stream description. You could also mention the coupon code once or twice during the stream. Now, you can add your affiliate link as a \u301016\u2020QR code\u2020support.restream.io\u3011 when you go live with Restream. Your audience doesn\u2019t have to go searching for the product link; they can scan with their smartphone directly from your live stream.\n\nKeep in mind that, unless the streaming platform has a deal with the affiliate program, the platform isn\u2019t profiting from your affiliate sales. So keep your content to the point and make the products or services you recommend relevant to your topic.\n\nIf you&#x27;re unsure where to start, give the Restream Referral Program a try. You can earn up to a 30% recurring commission on every subscription that comes from your link.\n\n\u301031\u2020 Learn more\u3011\n\n## 7. Create and sell your own merch \n\nMerchandise is an important revenue stream for many people who broadcast live video content. Streaming platforms have recognized this and give users plenty of advice, offering them some truly useful tools to help boost merch sales.\n\nEven with these tools, however, you\u2019ll still have plenty to figure out on your own if you decide to sell merch. What kind of products do you want to sell? T-shirts, mugs, and plush toys are all good choices. You can also sell digital products, such as music or e-books.\n\nYou\u2019ll need to think about the design, production, inventory, and shipping of your merch as well. There are a few ways you can do this, including:\n\n  * Building your own online store. Handle production, store inventory, and shipping all on your own.\n  * Overseeing the design but letting one of the platform-approved merch companies produce, store, and ship the merch for a cut of the profits.\n  * Partnering with stores that let you take advantage of special opportunities on select platforms, such as the \u301032\u2020YouTube Merch shelf\u2020support.google.com\u3011.\n\nEach of these solutions offers different profit margins and requires different levels of involvement. Whatever you choose, you can easily \u301033\u2020tie your merchandise business to your live streaming\u2020support.restream.io\u3011 by adding your product links as QR codes on your broadcast. You can even display an image of the product and the price alongside the QR code.\n\nRead more: \u301034\u2020Marketing tips for live video influencers\u3011\n\n## 8. Develop pay-per-view content \n\nProducing live content and selling tickets for it has become hugely popular. It\u2019s no longer just gaming content that gets live viewers. People with all kinds of interests and hobbies are turning to live streams to learn and exchange opinions with like-minded individuals. If you can create content that\u2019s appealing to these viewers, you can make money by selling tickets for your live stream.\n\nFirst, you need to create content that people will want to pay to watch. It should have some level of exclusivity or a way to stand out from content that is already available for free. You also have to use a platform that lets you sell tickets to live streams. Services like Streamtick let you sell admission to live broadcasts on YouTube, Facebook, or Twitter as well. With killer content and a ticketing service, you have everything you need to develop pay-per-view content.\n\n## 9. Twitch takes it one step further and gives you the option to add customized panels.\n\n### Add a Twitch Tip Panel\n\nIn the upper-right corner, click your profile icon.\n\n[Image 12: Twitch profile icon]\n\nSelect Channel from the drop-down menu.\n\n[Image 13: Twitch channel menu]\n\nClick the About section on the next screen.\n\n[Image 14: Twitch about]\n\nToggle the Edit Panels option in the top left section of the screen.\n\n[Image 15: Twitch edit panels]\n\nScroll down and click the box with a large plus sign in it and then click &quot;Add a Text or Image Panel&quot;.\n\n[Image 16: Twitch Add a Text or Image Panel]\n\nNow you can add a title to your panel, the link to your Streamlabs Tip Page, a Description, and an image.\n\n[Image 17: Twitch Panel title]\n\n### Need an Image?\n\nWe\u2019ve recently rolled out a new feature giving streamers the ability to add professionally designed panels from a selection of over 50 different templates.\n\nVisit our\u00a0\u301087\u2020Panel Maker page on the Streamlabs Dashboard\u3011\u00a0to start designing your own panels today.\n\n[Image 18: Streamlabs Panel maker] \n\n## Subscriptions\n\nUnlike tips or donations, subscriptions provide you with a more reliable source of income. If you want to become a full-time streamer, you\u2019ll need this supplemental revenue to assist you along the way.\n\nIn this section, we will be discussing how you can monetize your live stream through subscriptions. We\u2019ll specifically discuss the benefits and differences between Twitch subscriptions, YouTube Channel Memberships, and Facebook Fan Subscriptions. We will also discuss how to persuade your viewers to invest in your content and what benefits you can provide to convince them to stay subscribed.\n\n[Image 19: Streamlabs Subscriptions] \n\n## Subscriptions at a Glance\n\nTwitch Subscriptions YouTube Channel Membership Facebook Fan Subscription  \n\nCost\n\n$4.99, $9.99, $24.99\n\nStarting at 4.99, with the ability to \u301088\u2020customize price points\u2020support.google.com\u3011\n\n$4.99  \n\nCommission\n\n50%\n\n30%\n\nAs of August 2020 and for the next year, Facebook will not be taking any fees from Fan Subscriptions.  \n\nRequirements\n\nTwitch streamers must be either a Twitch Affiliate or a Twitch Partner.\n\nVisit our \u301089\u2020guide\u3011 for tips to help you become an affiliate\n\n30,000 subscribers; Gaming channels must have at least 1,000\n\nMember of YouTube Partner Program\n\n10,000 followers or 250+ Return Viewers and one of the following in the last 60 days:\n\n- 50,000 Post Engagements\n\n- 180,000 watch minutes  \n\n## Twitch Subscriber Benefits\n\nThere are a few &quot;built-in\u201d perks, but many streamers add a few bonus ones for those who support them monetarily. These are as follows:\n\n  * Ad-Free Viewing\u00a0\u2013 As a subscriber, Twitch will not force you to watch ads before you start watching a stream (with limited exceptions).\n  * Sub-Badges\u00a0\u2013 Custom badges are unlocked when you subscribe to a streamer. Badges are displayed next to a viewer&#x27;s name when they participate in the channel&#x27;s chat. Streamers can customize badges, and viewers will generally receive new badges the longer they stay subscribed. You start with the 1-month badge and get new badges for three months, six months, etc.\n  * Emotes\u00a0\u2013 Once a streamer reaches affiliate status, custom emotes become available. It is a fantastic way to reinforce your branding as a streamer because viewers can use them across all Twitch channels. The number of subscribers a streamer has dictates the number of emotes a streamer can have.\n  * Sub-Only Chat/Streams\u00a0\u2013 Occasionally, a streamer will host a sub-only stream. Hosting a stream for your most dedicated viewers is a great way to encourage viewers to sub. During these streams, only subscribers can view the broadcast. Streamers can also set their chat to &quot;subscribers only.&quot;\n\n[Image 20: Twitch Subscriptions at a Glance]\n\n## Facebook Fan Subscription Benefits\n\nThere are a few &quot;built-in\u201d perks, but many streamers add a few bonus ones for those who support them monetarily. These are as follows:\n\n  * Exclusive content:\u00a0Publish posts, videos, and other content exclusively to your most loyal supporters. Exclusive content generally includes:\n  * Supporter-only polls or Q&amp;As:\u00a0give supporters more ways to engage and interact with you.\n  * Behind-the-scenes:\u00a0Give viewers a look at the production and day to day activity of your live stream.\n  * Exclusive live videos:\u00a0Private live videos can provide an opportunity to answer questions and gain feedback from your community.\n  * Discounts:\u00a0Provide discount codes for merch, events, or other products through supporter only messages or posts.\n\nIn addition to these benefits, you can also provide supporters with:\n\n  * Recognition with\u00a0\u301090\u2020shout outs\u2020www.facebook.com\u3011\u00a0in public posts.\n  * Early access to your content with supporter-only Premieres or Watch Parties that later go public.\n\n[Image 21: Facebook Fan Subscription Benefits]\n\n## YouTube Channel Membership Benefits\n\nDifferent perks are available based on the various membership levels available. Streamers can offer multiple membership levels, which all have different prices. Remember, perks build on each other. The highest-priced membership levels will have access to the perks offered at lower-priced levels.\n\n  * Members-only Community posts\u00a0- Use the community tab to share content only with members. You can also share Community posts with members at specific levels.\n  * Members-only video\u00a0- Set videos that can only be seen by your members. Anyone can find a members-only video, but only members at the right level(s) can watch it.\n  * Members-only live streams\u00a0- Share a live stream exclusively with your members. Members will be notified when you post a link to the live stream with a members-only post in Community.\n  * Members-only live chat\u00a0- Make the chat members-only during public live streams. Everyone can still view the live stream, but only members will be able to post chats.\n  * Custom channel badges\u00a0- Members will stand out in live chat, comments, and the Community tab via exclusive members-only badges\n  * Custom emoji\u00a0- Members will gain access to one or more exclusive custom emoji that can be sent via YouTube in video comments. It can also be sent in any of your live chats.\n\n[Image 22: YouTube Channel Membership Benefits]\n\n## How to Convince Viewers to Subscribe\n\nSetting unique perks for viewers is a great way to convince others to invest in your content. These will vary from channel to channel, but some of the most common perks include:\n\n  * Exclusive Chatroom on Discord\u00a0\u2013 Many streamers create exclusive discord servers for their subscribers and members.\n  * Play with Viewers\u00a0\u2013 some streamers set aside days where they play games with their subscribers.\n  * Competitions/Giveaways\u00a0\u2013 Streamers can create special contests or giveaways for their subscribers. These are their way of giving back to their supportive community.\n  * Custom Subscriber Alerts\u00a0\u2013 Create unique alerts that only play when someone subscribes to your channel. Streamlabs makes setting up alerts easy, so be sure to\u00a0\u301091\u2020read our guide\u3011\u00a0to learn how to start creating unique alerts.\n\n## Products and Services\n\nFor most content creators, tips ", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"evidence_text": "source", "cited_message_idx": 5, "search_result_idx": null}}}, {"start_ix": 756, "end_ix": 766, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "9 Ways You Can Make Money With Live Streaming \u2013 Restream Blog", "url": "https://restream.io/blog/ways-you-can-make-money-live-streaming/", "text": "\nIf you don\u2019t want to use the tipping system within the streaming platform \u2014 or you don\u2019t meet the requirements to use it \u2014 you can use a third-party platform. Some of the most common ones for streamers are:\n\n  * StreamElements for one-time donations and tips. This platform integrates easily with Twitch, YouTube, Facebook Gaming and Trovo, and it offers different payment options.\n  * Patreon for regular donations/subscriptions. With the ability to let patrons set monthly pledges, Patreon is the closest you can get to a subscription system without going through a streaming platform\u2019s program.\n  * GoFundMe or Kickstarter for project-based funding. If you have a project to complete and you\u2019re looking for funding, set up pages on these websites and use your live streams to promote it.\n\nIf you stream with \u30101\u2020Restream\u3011, you can easily add a Patreon or GoFundMe \u301016\u2020link as a QR code\u2020support.restream.io\u3011 that you can display as an overlay on your stream.\n\nFor most of these services, you should consider creating special rewards and content for the people who support you. Decide carefully which content goes behind the paywall and which stays free, though. You can\u2019t keep all your best stuff locked behind a subscription; some of it has to stay free to attract new viewers.\n\n## 3. Paid subscriptions from viewers \n\nGetting an occasional tip from your viewers is great, but regular payments are better. These payments will usually net you a couple of dollars each, but if you can get enough of them, they add up. You\u2019ll need to meet certain requirements to enable this kind of support, as platforms reserve it for members of their content creator programs.\n\nHere\u2019s an overview of recurring payment features on the major platforms:\n\n  * YouTube has a \u301024\u2020channel membership program\u2020creatoracademy.youtube.com\u3011 that allows users to subscribe to its channels with monthly payments. To open your YouTube channel (where you group your videos) to this opportunity, you need to be in the \u301025\u2020YouTube Partner Program\u2020support.google.com\u3011 and meet additional eligibility requirements.\n  * Twitch has a \u301026\u2020paid subscription program\u2020www.twitch.tv\u3011 that lets you earn from paid subscriptions if you\u2019re an \u301020\u2020Affiliate\u3011 or Partner. Your viewers get one subscription for free through Twitch Prime, or they can pay for them using PayPal, Amazon Pay, or credit cards.\n  * Facebook Gaming \u301027\u2020extended its Fan Subscriptions feature\u2020www.facebook.com\u3011 to Level Up gaming content creators. You must achieve a certain number of returning weekly viewers, and the feature is only available in certain regions.\n\nIf the platform allows it, you should make content that\u2019s exclusive to your subscribers. It\u2019s a nice way to show your most loyal viewers that you appreciate their support. Also, remember to give a shoutout to people when they subscribe and a mention on their subscription anniversaries.\n\nYou can also use third-party services like Patreon to set up recurring payments or subscriptions from fans.\n\n## 4. Revenue from ads \n\nAdvertising revenue powers half the internet, including Google services and Facebook. Why not you too? If you join the right streaming platform or social network, you can start earning some decent ad money.\n\nWhen you start broadcasting live videos on a specific platform, like YouTube or Facebook, you may be able to take advantage of their advertising programs. Here\u2019s a breakdown of the different types of in-stream ads that are usually available:\n\n  * Pre-roll ads: These ads play as soon as a viewer clicks on your stream. They have to view the ad before they can start watching your content.\n  * Mid-roll ads: Mid-roll ads play in the middle of your live stream. Your stream continues in a smaller window while the ad takes up most of the screen.\n  * Display and overlay ads: These types of ads usually pop up as banners or small cards on top of your stream.\n\nIf you want to generate revenue with ads, join these platforms:\n\n  * \u301028\u2020YouTube\u2020support.google.com\u3011 offers pre-roll and mid-roll ads, as well as display and overlay ads.\n  * \u301029\u2020Facebook\u2020www.facebook.com\u3011 offers mid-roll ads if you meet the viewership number criteria.\n  * \u301030\u2020Twitch\u2020www.twitch.tv\u3011 offers in-stream ads, as well as display and native ad opportunities.\n\nAdvertising in live streaming is a hot topic and a regular cause of controversy. Try to exercise as much control as you can over the advertisements displayed during your streams or on your channel. Also, remember that viewers can use ad-blocking software to prevent some ads from showing. Therefore, using ads as the sole method to monetize your live streaming may not be the best idea.\n\n## 5. Brand deals and sponsorships \n\nBrand deals and sponsorships are another way you can earn money while streaming by engaging with businesses in a mutually beneficial arrangement. If you have a large following on streaming platforms, brands will reach out to you with offers. If they don\u2019t, you can reach out to them.\n\nWhen dealing with brands, it pays to be professional and detail-oriented. You make money when brands agree to pay you. You\u2019ll want to negotiate every part of the deal, to be 100% sure you\u2019re on the same page regarding your commitment.\n\nSome of the ways you can make money include:\n\n  * Sponsorships, where whole streams are sponsored by a brand.\n  * Banners and other types of advertisements you can display during your streams or on your channel or profile page.\n  * Sponsored content, like when a game developer pays you to play their game.\n\nYour audience is what will get a brand\u2019s attention. You should have a decent number of viewers and a clear understanding of who they are, their interests, and the types of problems they need solved. Be mindful of cutting deals that make you look like a sellout. Your audiences might not like that, and if you lose your audience, you lose the sponsors.\n\n## 6. Affiliate programs \n\nWith a membership in an affiliate program, you can earn a commission every time a shopper clicks on your affiliate link and makes a purchase. Sometimes you don\u2019t even have to post a link, because all you need is a promo or coupon code viewers can use when they shop at the place you\u2019re promoting. The link or code is provided to you once you join the affiliate program.\n\nIn the past, you had to place the affiliate link or the code in your stream description. You could also mention the coupon code once or twice during the stream. Now, you can add your affiliate link as a \u301016\u2020QR code\u2020support.restream.io\u3011 when you go live with Restream. Your audience doesn\u2019t have to go searching for the product link; they can scan with their smartphone directly from your live stream.\n\nKeep in mind that, unless the streaming platform has a deal with the affiliate program, the platform isn\u2019t profiting from your affiliate sales. So keep your content to the point and make the products or services you recommend relevant to your topic.\n\nIf you&#x27;re unsure where to start, give the Restream Referral Program a try. You can earn up to a 30% recurring commission on every subscription that comes from your link.\n\n\u301031\u2020 Learn more\u3011\n\n## 7. Create and sell your own merch \n\nMerchandise is an important revenue stream for many people who broadcast live video content. Streaming platforms have recognized this and give users plenty of advice, offering them some truly useful tools to help boost merch sales.\n\nEven with these tools, however, you\u2019ll still have plenty to figure out on your own if you decide to sell merch. What kind of products do you want to sell? T-shirts, mugs, and plush toys are all good choices. You can also sell digital products, such as music or e-books.\n\nYou\u2019ll need to think about the design, production, inventory, and shipping of your merch as well. There are a few ways you can do this, including:\n\n  * Building your own online store. Handle production, store inventory, and shipping all on your own.\n  * Overseeing the design but letting one of the platform-approved merch companies produce, store, and ship the merch for a cut of the profits.\n  * Partnering with stores that let you take advantage of special opportunities on select platforms, such as the \u301032\u2020YouTube Merch shelf\u2020support.google.com\u3011.\n\nEach of these solutions offers different profit margins and requires different levels of involvement. Whatever you choose, you can easily \u301033\u2020tie your merchandise business to your live streaming\u2020support.restream.io\u3011 by adding your product links as QR codes on your broadcast. You can even display an image of the product and the price alongside the QR code.\n\nRead more: \u301034\u2020Marketing tips for live video influencers\u3011\n\n## 8. Develop pay-per-view content \n\nProducing live content and selling tickets for it has become hugely popular. It\u2019s no longer just gaming content that gets live viewers. People with all kinds of interests and hobbies are turning to live streams to learn and exchange opinions with like-minded individuals. If you can create content that\u2019s appealing to these viewers, you can make money by selling tickets for your live stream.\n\nFirst, you need to create content that people will want to pay to watch. It should have some level of exclusivity or a way to stand out from content that is already available for free. You also have to use a platform that lets you sell tickets to live streams. Services like Streamtick let you sell admission to live broadcasts on YouTube, Facebook, or Twitter as well. With killer content and a ticketing service, you have everything you need to develop pay-per-view content.\n\n## 9. With an \u301027\u2020expected 1.4 billion monthly active users by 2024\u2020www.statista.com\u3011 (nearly 30% of global internet users), Instagram is a good choice for video content creators. When you go live on Instagram, your followers receive a notification so they can tune in. When the live video is over, you can choose to download it and post it to your Instagram feed so anyone can watch the replay.\n\nOne thing to keep in mind with Instagram Live is that users with personal accounts can only stream from a mobile device via the Instagram app. \u301028\u2020Instagram Live Producer\u2020about.instagram.com\u3011 allows you to stream from a computer using streaming software such Restream Studio or OBS Studio but only users with Professional accounts have access to it.\n\nFeatures \n\n  * Live chat \n  * Inviting other creators to your live stream \n  * Broadcasting exclusively to paid subscribers\n  * \u201cAsk a Question\u201d sticker can make stream more engaging \n  * Live chat moderation and hiding offensive comments \n  * Monetization options \n\nPros \n\n  * Beginner-friendly \n  * Easy to use \n  * Your followers get a notification when you go live \n  * You can live stream on Stories \n  * Add fun filters and overlays to your stream \n\nCons \n\n  * Likes and comments on live video disappear when you post the replay to your feed\n\n\u00a0Learn more by reading our guide on \u301029\u2020how to go live on Instagram\u3011.\n\n### 7. LinkedIn Live \n\nLinkedIn is no longer just a professional networking site; it\u2019s now a full-fledged content creation platform. You can find articles, videos, and live videos from influencers, brands and other professionals in your industry.\u301030\u2020 \u2020business.linkedin.com\u3011With \u301031\u2020one billion members\u2020about.linkedin.com\u3011, LinkedIn isn\u2019t as large as other social media platforms, but it does \u301032\u2020drive more leads\u2020kinsta.com\u3011. LinkedIn Live isn\u2019t available to every user; you must meet certain requirements to get access. The platform also offers no monetization options.\n\nWho should stream on LinkedIn? Any professionals who want to promote an event, take others behind the scenes of their companies, recruit new employees, establish industry authority by interviewing experts, or demonstrate expertise with tutorials and seminars.\n\nFeatures \n\n  * Live chat and moderation tools \n  * Analytics \n  * Create an event on LinkedIn and stream directly to it \n  * Save previous live streams as recordings \n  * Gather questions from event attendees before the stream starts \n  * Need a third-party streaming tool to go live on LinkedIn \n\nPros \n\n  * Access to a young and affluent audience \n  * Previous live streams appear on your profile as regular posts \n  * LinkedIn pages can require viewer registration for live streamed events \n\nCons \n\n  * Must have 150 followers and be active on LinkedIn to live stream \n  * No monetization options\n\n\u00a0Get started on LinkedIn with our \u301033\u2020full guide to LinkedIn Live streaming\u3011.\u00a0\n\n### 8. X (Twitter)\n\nX (Twitter) might not be as large as Facebook or YouTube, but live streamers still have access to \u301034\u2020353.9 million worldwide users\u2020www.oberlo.com\u3011. You can live stream on X through the app and on desktop, but you\u2019ll need to use X\u2019s Media Studio Producer with live streaming encoding software for the latter. You can also \u301035\u2020connect with Restream\u2020support.restream.io\u3011. When you go live on X, you can share a link directly to the stream, making it much easier for your audience to find it.\u00a0\n\nFeatures \n\n  * Go live through the mobile app and on desktop \n  * Live videos posted as a tweet on your profile \n  * Live chat \n  * Monetization options \n  * Invite a friend to co-host the stream with you \n  * Tag a location when streaming \n  * Stream from desktop with Media Studio Producer or a third-party tool like Restream \n\nPros \n\n  * Option to save your stream on your mobile device after it\u2019s over \n  * Add a custom starting point so viewers don\u2019t have to rewatch the entire stream \n  * Send a link directly to your stream \n  * Past live streams appear on your profile as video tweets \n\nCons \n\n  * All streams are public \u2014 no streaming to select audience available \n  * Limited monetization options \n\nGet started streaming on X with our \u301036\u2020ultimate guide to X (Twitter) live streaming\u3011.\n\n### 9. IBM Video Streaming\n\n\u301037\u2020IBM Video Streaming\u2020www.ibm.com\u3011 is a live streaming and VOD-hosting platform that lets you broadcast to multiple content delivery networks (CDNs). It\u2019s scalable, letting you host internal employee meetings or massive virtual events. IBM\u2019s video streaming service is for professional and enterprise use cases and comes with features like HD broadcasting, dedicated support, password-protected channels and video recording.\n\nIBM\u2019s streaming platform isn\u2019t free to use but you can sign up for a 30-day free trial. Also, the pricing tiers are based on viewer hours and if you surpass your allotted monthly hours, you could be charged an extra fee.\n\nFeatures \n\n  * Live chat with polling and Q&amp;A \n  * On-demand captioning \n  * 720p broadcasting \n  * VOD storage \n  * Customizable channel page \n  * Save recordings of live videos \n  * Videos are viewable on mobile devices \n  * Video analytics \n\nPros \n\n  * Can support a large audience \n  * Create a central repository for videos \n  * Optional event registration feature \n  * Stores video on a separate cloud to free up space \n\nCons \n\n  * Higher number of users can lead to increased wait times to join a stream \n  * Live chat is less useful for large events \n  * Not free to use \n\nPricing \n\nIBM doesn\u2019t list its pricing and you have to contact the company to find out the exact fees. There are three tiers:\n\n  * Silver: 100 viewer hours, 5 channels, 1 TB video storage and other features \n  * Gold: 2,000 viewer hours, 10 channels, 2 TB video storage and other features \n  * Platinum: 5,000 viewer hours, 20 channels, 5 TB video storage and other features \n\nYou can also create a custom plan if you have high-volume needs.\n\n### 10. Livestream by Vimeo \n\nVimeo acquired the \u301038\u2020Livestream\u2020livestream.com\u3011 platform in 2017 and today offers live video streaming and video hosting to businesses of all sizes. Video hosting with Vimeo is free but to access the live streaming functionality, you\u2019ll need one of its paid plans. Vimeo has also developed proprietary streaming hardware and software that integrates seamlessly with its live streaming platform, offering users a more all-in-one experience. If you want to start your own paid subscription channel, you can use Vimeo\u2019s over-the-top (OTT) media features. OTT simply refers to any type of video media provided over the internet, rather than via cable, broadcast or satellite television.\n\nFeatures \n\n  * Adaptive bitrate streaming \n  * Custom registration forms for online events \n  * Live video graphics like lower thirds, transitions and logos \n  * Live chat with moderation, polling and Q&amp;A features \n  * Simulcast to multiple platforms \n  * 1080p live streaming \n  * Video archiving and management \n  * Live event monetization \n  * Live video analytics \n\nPros \n\n  * Beginner-friendly \n  * Ad-free ", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"evidence_text": "source", "cited_message_idx": 7, "search_result_idx": null}}}, {"start_ix": 1589, "end_ix": 1599, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "The 15 Best Live Streaming Platforms in 2024 \u2013 Restream Blog", "url": "https://restream.io/blog/best-live-streaming-platforms/", "text": "  * More lenient moderation policies \n\nPros \n\n  * 95-5 revenue split in favor of streamers \n  * Lower threshold to join affiliate program compared to Twitch \n  * More opportunities for small streamers to get started \n\nCons \n\n  * Less discoverability than other major platforms \n  * Concerts over content regulation \n  * Uncertain future \n\nWant to see if Kick is the right streaming platform to build your audience? Some of the most common ones for streamers are:\n\n  * StreamElements for one-time donations and tips. This platform integrates easily with Twitch, YouTube, Facebook Gaming and Trovo, and it offers different payment options.\n  * Patreon for regular donations/subscriptions. With the ability to let patrons set monthly pledges, Patreon is the closest you can get to a subscription system without going through a streaming platform\u2019s program.\n  * GoFundMe or Kickstarter for project-based funding. If you have a project to complete and you\u2019re looking for funding, set up pages on these websites and use your live streams to promote it.\n\nIf you stream with \u30101\u2020Restream\u3011, you can easily add a Patreon or GoFundMe \u301016\u2020link as a QR code\u2020support.restream.io\u3011 that you can display as an overlay on your stream.\n\nFor most of these services, you should consider creating special rewards and content for the people who support you. Decide carefully which content goes behind the paywall and which stays free, though. You can\u2019t keep all your best stuff locked behind a subscription; some of it has to stay free to attract new viewers.\n\n## 3. Paid subscriptions from viewers \n\nGetting an occasional tip from your viewers is great, but regular payments are better. These payments will usually net you a couple of dollars each, but if you can get enough of them, they add up. You\u2019ll need to meet certain requirements to enable this kind of support, as platforms reserve it for members of their content creator programs.\n\nHere\u2019s an overview of recurring payment features on the major platforms:\n\n  * YouTube has a \u301024\u2020channel membership program\u2020creatoracademy.youtube.com\u3011 that allows users to subscribe to its channels with monthly payments. To open your YouTube channel (where you group your videos) to this opportunity, you need to be in the \u301025\u2020YouTube Partner Program\u2020support.google.com\u3011 and meet additional eligibility requirements.\n  * Twitch has a \u301026\u2020paid subscription program\u2020www.twitch.tv\u3011 that lets you earn from paid subscriptions if you\u2019re an \u301020\u2020Affiliate\u3011 or Partner. Your viewers get one subscription for free through Twitch Prime, or they can pay for them using PayPal, Amazon Pay, or credit cards.\n  * Facebook Gaming \u301027\u2020extended its Fan Subscriptions feature\u2020www.facebook.com\u3011 to Level Up gaming content creators. You must achieve a certain number of returning weekly viewers, and the feature is only available in certain regions.\n\nIf the platform allows it, you should make content that\u2019s exclusive to your subscribers. It\u2019s a nice way to show your most loyal viewers that you appreciate their support. Also, remember to give a shoutout to people when they subscribe and a mention on their subscription anniversaries.\n\nYou can also use third-party services like Patreon to set up recurring payments or subscriptions from fans.\n\n## 4. Revenue from ads \n\nAdvertising revenue powers half the internet, including Google services and Facebook. Why not you too? If you join the right streaming platform or social network, you can start earning some decent ad money.\n\nWhen you start broadcasting live videos on a specific platform, like YouTube or Facebook, you may be able to take advantage of their advertising programs. Here\u2019s a breakdown of the different types of in-stream ads that are usually available:\n\n  * Pre-roll ads: These ads play as soon as a viewer clicks on your stream. They have to view the ad before they can start watching your content.\n  * Mid-roll ads: Mid-roll ads play in the middle of your live stream. Your stream continues in a smaller window while the ad takes up most of the screen.\n  * Display and overlay ads: These types of ads usually pop up as banners or small cards on top of your stream.\n\nIf you want to generate revenue with ads, join these platforms:\n\n  * \u301028\u2020YouTube\u2020support.google.com\u3011 offers pre-roll and mid-roll ads, as well as display and overlay ads.\n  * \u301029\u2020Facebook\u2020www.facebook.com\u3011 offers mid-roll ads if you meet the viewership number criteria.\n  * \u301030\u2020Twitch\u2020www.twitch.tv\u3011 offers in-stream ads, as well as display and native ad opportunities.\n\nAdvertising in live streaming is a hot topic and a regular cause of controversy. Try to exercise as much control as you can over the advertisements displayed during your streams or on your channel. Also, remember that viewers can use ad-blocking software to prevent some ads from showing. Therefore, using ads as the sole method to monetize your live streaming may not be the best idea.\n\n## 5. Brand deals and sponsorships \n\nBrand deals and sponsorships are another way you can earn money while streaming by engaging with businesses in a mutually beneficial arrangement. If you have a large following on streaming platforms, brands will reach out to you with offers. If they don\u2019t, you can reach out to them.\n\nWhen dealing with brands, it pays to be professional and detail-oriented. You make money when brands agree to pay you. You\u2019ll want to negotiate every part of the deal, to be 100% sure you\u2019re on the same page regarding your commitment.\n\nSome of the ways you can make money include:\n\n  * Sponsorships, where whole streams are sponsored by a brand.\n  * Banners and other types of advertisements you can display during your streams or on your channel or profile page.\n  * Sponsored content, like when a game developer pays you to play their game.\n\nYour audience is what will get a brand\u2019s attention. You should have a decent number of viewers and a clear understanding of who they are, their interests, and the types of problems they need solved. Be mindful of cutting deals that make you look like a sellout. Your audiences might not like that, and if you lose your audience, you lose the sponsors.\n\n## 6. Affiliate programs \n\nWith a membership in an affiliate program, you can earn a commission every time a shopper clicks on your affiliate link and makes a purchase. Sometimes you don\u2019t even have to post a link, because all you need is a promo or coupon code viewers can use when they shop at the place you\u2019re promoting. The link or code is provided to you once you join the affiliate program.\n\nIn the past, you had to place the affiliate link or the code in your stream description. You could also mention the coupon code once or twice during the stream. Now, you can add your affiliate link as a \u301016\u2020QR code\u2020support.restream.io\u3011 when you go live with Restream. Your audience doesn\u2019t have to go searching for the product link; they can scan with their smartphone directly from your live stream.\n\nKeep in mind that, unless the streaming platform has a deal with the affiliate program, the platform isn\u2019t profiting from your affiliate sales. So keep your content to the point and make the products or services you recommend relevant to your topic.\n\nIf you&#x27;re unsure where to start, give the Restream Referral Program a try. You can earn up to a 30% recurring commission on every subscription that comes from your link.\n\n\u301031\u2020 Learn more\u3011\n\n## 7. Create and sell your own merch \n\nMerchandise is an important revenue stream for many people who broadcast live video content. Streaming platforms have recognized this and give users plenty of advice, offering them some truly useful tools to help boost merch sales.\n\nEven with these tools, however, you\u2019ll still have plenty to figure out on your own if you decide to sell merch. What kind of products do you want to sell? T-shirts, mugs, and plush toys are all good choices. You can also sell digital products, such as music or e-books.\n\nYou\u2019ll need to think about the design, production, inventory, and shipping of your merch as well. There are a few ways you can do this, including:\n\n  * Building your own online store. Handle production, store inventory, and shipping all on your own.\n  * Overseeing the design but letting one of the platform-approved merch companies produce, store, and ship the merch for a cut of the profits.\n  * Partnering with stores that let you take advantage of special opportunities on select platforms, such as the \u301032\u2020YouTube Merch shelf\u2020support.google.com\u3011.\n\nEach of these solutions offers different profit margins and requires different levels of involvement. Whatever you choose, you can easily \u301033\u2020tie your merchandise business to your live streaming\u2020support.restream.io\u3011 by adding your product links as QR codes on your broadcast. You can even display an image of the product and the price alongside the QR code.\n\nRead more: \u301034\u2020Marketing tips for live video influencers\u3011\n\n## 8. Develop pay-per-view content \n\nProducing live content and selling tickets for it has become hugely popular. It\u2019s no longer just gaming content that gets live viewers. People with all kinds of interests and hobbies are turning to live streams to learn and exchange opinions with like-minded individuals. If you can create content that\u2019s appealing to these viewers, you can make money by selling tickets for your live stream.\n\nFirst, you need to create content that people will want to pay to watch. It should have some level of exclusivity or a way to stand out from content that is already available for free. You also have to use a platform that lets you sell tickets to live streams. Services like Streamtick let you sell admission to live broadcasts on YouTube, Facebook, or Twitter as well. With killer content and a ticketing service, you have everything you need to develop pay-per-view content.\n\n## 9. Coach/teach/offer lessons \n\nShare your knowledge through live seminars, workshops, or classes. If that sounds too academic for your taste, consider becoming someone\u2019s mentor, coach, or teacher. These are as follows:\n\n  * Ad-Free Viewing\u00a0\u2013 As a subscriber, Twitch will not force you to watch ads before you start watching a stream (with limited exceptions).\n  * Sub-Badges\u00a0\u2013 Custom badges are unlocked when you subscribe to a streamer. Badges are displayed next to a viewer&#x27;s name when they participate in the channel&#x27;s chat. Streamers can customize badges, and viewers will generally receive new badges the longer they stay subscribed. You start with the 1-month badge and get new badges for three months, six months, etc.\n  * Emotes\u00a0\u2013 Once a streamer reaches affiliate status, custom emotes become available. It is a fantastic way to reinforce your branding as a streamer because viewers can use them across all Twitch channels. The number of subscribers a streamer has dictates the number of emotes a streamer can have.\n  * Sub-Only Chat/Streams\u00a0\u2013 Occasionally, a streamer will host a sub-only stream. Hosting a stream for your most dedicated viewers is a great way to encourage viewers to sub. During these streams, only subscribers can view the broadcast. Streamers can also set their chat to &quot;subscribers only.&quot;\n\n[Image 20: Twitch Subscriptions at a Glance]\n\n## Facebook Fan Subscription Benefits\n\nThere are a few &quot;built-in\u201d perks, but many streamers add a few bonus ones for those who support them monetarily. These are as follows:\n\n  * Exclusive content:\u00a0Publish posts, videos, and other content exclusively to your most loyal supporters. Exclusive content generally includes:\n  * Supporter-only polls or Q&amp;As:\u00a0give supporters more ways to engage and interact with you.\n  * Behind-the-scenes:\u00a0Give viewers a look at the production and day to day activity of your live stream.\n  * Exclusive live videos:\u00a0Private live videos can provide an opportunity to answer questions and gain feedback from your community.\n  * Discounts:\u00a0Provide discount codes for merch, events, or other products through supporter only messages or posts.\n\nIn addition to these benefits, you can also provide supporters with:\n\n  * Recognition with\u00a0\u301090\u2020shout outs\u2020www.facebook.com\u3011\u00a0in public posts.\n  * Early access to your content with supporter-only Premieres or Watch Parties that later go public.\n\n[Image 21: Facebook Fan Subscription Benefits]\n\n## YouTube Channel Membership Benefits\n\nDifferent perks are available based on the various membership levels available. Streamers can offer multiple membership levels, which all have different prices. Remember, perks build on each other. The highest-priced membership levels will have access to the perks offered at lower-priced levels.\n\n  * Members-only Community posts\u00a0- Use the community tab to share content only with members. You can also share Community posts with members at specific levels.\n  * Members-only video\u00a0- Set videos that can only be seen by your members. Anyone can find a members-only video, but only members at the right level(s) can watch it.\n  * Members-only live streams\u00a0- Share a live stream exclusively with your members. Members will be notified when you post a link to the live stream with a members-only post in Community.\n  * Members-only live chat\u00a0- Make the chat members-only during public live streams. Everyone can still view the live stream, but only members will be able to post chats.\n  * Custom channel badges\u00a0- Members will stand out in live chat, comments, and the Community tab via exclusive members-only badges\n  * Custom emoji\u00a0- Members will gain access to one or more exclusive custom emoji that can be sent via YouTube in video comments. It can also be sent in any of your live chats.\n\n[Image 22: YouTube Channel Membership Benefits]\n\n## How to Convince Viewers to Subscribe\n\nSetting unique perks for viewers is a great way to convince others to invest in your content. These are their way of giving back to their supportive community.\n  * Custom Subscriber Alerts\u00a0\u2013 Create unique alerts that only play when someone subscribes to your channel. TikTok LIVE \n\nAs a social media platform that\u2019s geared toward viral videos, TikTok presents a great opportunity for live streamers. Although short video clips dominate TikTok, there\u2019s still space for live video creators to find an audience with longer content of up to 60 minutes. If your content is for Gen Z, then a presence on TikTok LIVE can be hugely beneficial.\n\nYou can go live from the app on a mobile device or use TikTok\u2019s new live studio software for streaming on desktop. Only some TikTok users are allowed to go live on TikTok. Only accounts with 1,000 or more followers have the capability. Also, monetization options aren\u2019t available unless you are 18 or older.\n\nFeatures \n\n  * Dueting tool that allows users to use parts of existing videos from other users \n  * Primarily Gen Z audience\n  * \u201cFor You\u201d recommendation algorithm that suggests new videos to users \n  * Picture-in-picture streaming \n  * Add more than one person to a stream \n  * Q&amp;A feature to let viewers ask questions \n  * Add a moderator to your live stream and keyword filters for live chat \n  * Monetization options \n\nPros \n\n  * Viral growth possibility \n  * Free to use \n  * Live streaming can make you stand out \n  * Create live videos of up to 60 minutes \n\nCons \n\n  * Only accounts with 1,000 or more followers can go live \n\nStart streaming on TikTok LIVE with our \u301026\u2020ultimate guide to TikTok live streaming\u3011.\n\n### 6. Instagram Live \n\nInstagram is no longer just for sharing photos with your friends. You can find on-demand and live videos from your favorite brands and influencers on the platform, too. With an \u301027\u2020expected 1.4 billion monthly active users by 2024\u2020www.statista.com\u3011 (nearly 30% of global internet users), Instagram is a good choice for video content creators. When you go live on Instagram, your followers receive a notification so they can tune in. When the live video is over, you can choose to download it and post it to your Instagram feed so anyone can watch the replay.\n\nOne thing to keep in mind with Instagram Live is that users with personal accounts can only stream from a mobile device via the Instagram app. \u301028\u2020Instagram Live Producer\u2020about.instagram.com\u3011 allows you to stream from a computer using streaming software such Restream Studio or OBS Studio but only users with Professional accounts have access to it.\n\nFeatures \n\n  * Live chat \n  * Inviting other creators to your live stream \n  * Broadcasting exclusively to paid subscribers\n  * \u201cAsk a Question\u201d sticker can make stream more engaging \n  * Live chat moderation and hiding offensive comments \n  * Monetization options \n\nPros \n\n  * Beginner-friendly \n  * Easy to use \n  * Your followers get a notification when you go live \n  * You can live stream on Stories \n  * Add fun filters and overlays to your stream \n\nCons \n\n  * Likes and comments on live video disappear when you post the replay to your feed\n\n\u00a0Learn more by reading our guide on \u301029\u2020how to go live on Instagram\u3011.\n\n### 7. LinkedIn Live \n\nLinkedIn is no longer just a professional networking site; it\u2019s now a full-fledged content creation platform. You can find articles, videos, and live videos from influencers, brands and other professionals in your industry.\u301030\u2020 \u2020business.linkedin.com\u3011With \u301031\u2020one billion members\u2020about.linkedin.com\u3011, LinkedIn isn\u2019t as large as other social media platforms, but it does \u301032\u2020drive more leads\u2020kinsta.com\u3011. LinkedIn Live isn\u2019t available to every user; you must meet certain requirements to get access. The platform also offers no monetization options.\n\nWho should stream on LinkedIn? Any professionals who want to promote an event, take others behind the scenes of their companies, recruit new employees, establish industry authority by interviewing experts, or demonstrate expertise with tutorials and seminars.\n\nFeatures \n\n  * Live chat and moderation tools \n  * Analytics \n  * Create an event on LinkedIn and stream directly to it \n  * Save previous live streams as recordings \n  * Gather questions from event attendees before the stream starts \n  * Need a third-party streaming tool to go live on LinkedIn \n\nPros \n\n  * Access to a young and affluent audience \n  * Previous live streams appear on your profile as regular posts \n  * LinkedIn pages can require viewer registration for live streamed events \n\nCons \n\n  * Must have 150 followers and be active on LinkedIn to live stream \n  * No monetization options\n\n\u00a0Get started on LinkedIn with our \u301033\u2020full guide to LinkedIn Live streaming\u3011.\u00a0\n\n### 8. X (Twitter)\n\nX (Twitter) might not be as large as Facebook or YouTube, but live streamers still have access to \u301034\u2020353.9 million worldwide users\u2020www.oberlo.com\u3011. You can live stream on X through the app and on desktop, but you\u2019ll need to use X\u2019s Media Studio Producer with live streaming encoding software for the latter. You can also \u301035\u2020connect with Restream\u2020support.restream.io\u3011. When you go live on X, you can share a link directly to the stream, making it much easier for your audience to find it.\u00a0\n\nFeatures \n\n  * Go live through the mobile app and on desktop \n  * Live videos posted as a tweet on your profile \n  * Live chat \n  * Monetization options \n  * Invite a friend to co-host the stream with you \n  * Tag a location when streaming \n  * Stream from desktop with Media Studio Producer or a third-party tool like Restream \n\nPros \n\n  * Option to save your stream on your mobile device after it\u2019s over \n  * Add a custom starting point so viewers don\u2019t have to rewatch the entire stream \n  * Send a link directly to your stream \n  * Past live streams appear on your profile as video tweets \n\nCons \n\n  * All streams are public \u2014 no streaming to select audience available \n  * Limited monetization options \n\nGet started streaming on X with our \u301036\u2020ultimate guide to X (Twitter) live streaming\u3011.\n\n### 9. IBM Video Streaming\n\n\u301037\u2020IBM Video Streaming\u2020www.ibm.com\u3011 is a live streaming and VOD-hosting platform that lets you broadcast to multiple content delivery networks (CDNs). It\u2019s scalable, letting you host internal employee meetings or massive virtual events. IBM\u2019s video streaming service is for professional and enterprise use cases and comes with features like HD broadcasting, dedicated support, password-protected channels and video recording.\n\nIBM\u2019s streaming platform isn\u2019t free to use but you can sign up for a 30-day free trial. Also, the pricing tiers are based on viewer hours and if you surpass your allotted monthly hours, you could be charged an extra fee.\n\nFeatures \n\n  * Live chat with polling and Q&amp;A \n  * On-demand captioning \n  * 720p broadcasting \n  * VOD storage \n  * Customizable channel page \n  * Save recordings of live videos \n  * Videos are viewable on mobile devices \n  * Video analytics \n\nPros \n\n  * Can support a large audience \n  * Create a central repository for videos \n  * Optional event registration feature \n  * Stores video on a separate cloud to free up space \n\nCons \n\n  * Higher number of users can lead to increased wait times to join a stream \n  * Live chat is less useful for large events \n  * Not free to use \n\nPricing \n\nIBM doesn\u2019t list its pricing and you have to contact the company to find out the exact fees. There are three tiers:\n\n  * Silver: 100 viewer hours, 5 channels, 1 TB video storage and other features \n  * Gold: 2,000 viewer hours, 10 channels, 2 TB video storage and other features \n  * Platinum: 5,000 viewer hours, 20 channels, 5 TB video storage and other features \n\nYou can also create a custom plan if you have high-volume needs.\n\n### 10. Livestream by Vimeo \n\nVimeo acquired the \u301038\u2020Livestream\u2020livestream.com\u3011 platform in 2017 and today offers live video streaming and video hosting to businesses of all sizes. Video hosting with Vimeo is free but to access the live streaming functionality, you\u2019ll need one of its paid plans. Vimeo has also developed proprietary streaming hardware and software that integrates seamlessly with its live streaming platform, offering users a more all-in-one experience. If you want to start your own paid subscription channel, you can use Vimeo\u2019s over-the-top (OTT) media features. OTT simply refers to any type of video media provided over the internet, rather than via cable, broadcast or satellite television.\n\nFeatures \n\n  * Adaptive bitrate streaming \n  * Custom registration forms for online events \n  * Live video graphics like lower thirds, transitions and logos \n  * Live chat with moderation, polling and Q&amp;A features \n  * Simulcast to multiple platforms \n  * 1080p live streaming \n  * Video archiving and management \n  * Live event monetization \n  * Live video analytics \n\nPros \n\n  * Beginner-friendly \n  * Ad-free "}, {"matched_text": "\u30107\u2020source\u3011", "start_idx": 1279, "end_idx": 1289, "alt": null, "type": "webpage_extended", "title": "The 15 Best Live Streaming Platforms in 2024 \u2013 Restream Blog", "url": "https://restream.io/blog/best-live-streaming-platforms/", "pub_date": null, "snippet": "  * More lenient moderation policies \n\nPros \n\n  * 95-5 revenue split in favor of streamers \n  * Lower threshold to join affiliate program compared to Twitch \n  * More opportunities for small streamers to get started \n\nCons \n\n  * Less discoverability than other major platforms \n  * Concerts over content regulation \n  * Uncertain future \n\nWant to see if Kick is the right streaming platform to build your audience? ["The Science of Feeling Good\n\nEveryone wants to feel good. Pleasure is a key aspect of life, and human beings seek out what gives them pleasure. We are naturally attracted to what makes us feel good. \n\n\nTake my favorite food, cheese, for instance. Scientific studies have revealed that cheese contains a chemical called casein, known for its ability to induce feelings of pleasure. This chemical is so powerful that it triggers the same brain regions as opioids, potentially leading to addictive behaviors. Yet, my intention is not addiction, but rather, to experience the joy that comes from feeling good. Hence, my love for cheese. \n\nBut it&#x27;s not just about the cheese. I often find myself pondering\u2014what truly brings us that feeling of goodness?  What are the essential elements that guarantee a delightful human experience? Is it all about chemical receptors in the brain? Is happiness just a pill or does it encompass something deeper? Is the true science of feeling good science or just a philosophy or attitude that keeps the human mood in optimal condition? Let\u2019s explore what we know about the science of feeling good and its intersections with behavioral philosophy and psychology to get the bottom of the mystery humans have pondered and sought for millennia: How to feel good all the time and lead a happy and meaningful life. \n______\n\n\nFinish writing the blog post/article above supplementing it with scientific, psychology, and philosophic ["{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Effect of feeling good on helping: cookies and kindness.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Two experiments with adult subjects investigated the effects of a person&#x27;s positive affective state on his or her subsequent helpfulness to others. \\&quot;Feeling good\\&quot; was induced by having received cookies while studying in a library (Study I) and by having found a dime in the coin return of a public telephone while making a call (Study II). In Study I, where the dependent measure involved volunteering in reply to a student&#x27;s request, a distinction was made between specific willingness to help and general willingness to engage in any subsequent activity. In Study II, the dependent measure was whether subjects spontaneously helped to pick up papers that were dropped in front of them. On the basis of previous research, it was predicted that subjects who were thus made to \\&quot;feel good\\&quot; would be more helpful than control subjects. Results support the predictions.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Alice M. Isen&quot;,&quot;Paula F.
