The science of happiness and a proposal for a national index.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;One area of positive psychology analyzes subjective well-being (SWB), people&#x27;s cognitive and affective evaluations of their lives. Progress has been made in understanding the components of SWB, the importance of adaptation and goals to feelings of well-being, the temperament underpinnings of SWB, and the cultural influences on well-being. Representative selection of respondents, naturalistic experience sampling measures, and other methodological refinements are now used to study SWB and could be used to produce national indicators of happiness.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;E. Diener&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2000,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;The American psychologist&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/wellbeing-science-happiness-proposal-index-diener/93acebd3c0125f5aa30a28fc32ca0b70/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037/0003-066X.55.1.34&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;55 1&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          34-43\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:2},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Positive psychology. An introduction.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;A science of positive subjective experience, positive individual traits, and positive institutions promises to improve quality of life and prevent the pathologies that arise when life is barren and meaningless. The exclusive focus on pathology that has dominated so much of our discipline results in a model of the human being lacking the positive features that make life worth living. Hope, wisdom, creativity, future mindedness, courage, spirituality, responsibility, and perseverance are ignored or explained as transformations of more authentic negative impulses. The 15 articles in this millennial issue of the American Psychologist discuss such issues as what enables happiness, the effects of autonomy and self-regulation, how optimism and hope affect health, what constitutes wisdom, and how talent and creativity come to fruition. The authors outline a framework for a science of positive psychology, point to gaps in our knowledge, and predict that the next century will see a science and profession that will come to understand and build the factors that allow individuals, communities, and societies to flourish.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;M. Seligman&quot;,&quot;M. Cs\u00edkszentmih\u00e1lyi&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2000,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;The American psychologist&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/psychology-introduction-seligman/5b14058c35ea539a907f69c933e10ffa/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037/0003-066X.55.1.5&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;55 1&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          5-14\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:3},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Positive psychology in clinical practice.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Positive psychology is the scientific study of positive experiences and positive individual traits, and the institutions that facilitate their development. A field concerned with well-being and optimal functioning, positive psychology aims to broaden the focus of clinical psychology beyond suffering and its direct alleviation. Our proposed conceptual framework parses happiness into three domains: pleasure, engagement, and meaning. For each of these constructs, there are now valid and practical assessment tools appropriate for the clinical setting. Additionally, mounting evidence demonstrates the efficacy and effectiveness of positive interventions aimed at cultivating pleasure, engagement, and meaning. We contend that positive interventions are justifiable in their own right. Positive interventions may also usefully supplement direct attempts to prevent and treat psychopathology and, indeed, may covertly be a central component of good psychotherapy as it is done now.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;A. Duckworth&quot;,&quot;Tracy A. Steen&quot;,&quot;M. Seligman&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2005,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Annual review of clinical psychology&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/positive-psychology-practice-duckworth/2bb7f4c937f953fab228ef18775d7952/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1146/ANNUREV.CLINPSY.1.102803.144154&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;1&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          629-51\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:4},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Culture, Emotion, and Well-being: Good Feelings in Japan and the United States&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;We tested the hypothesis that \u201cgood feelings\u201d\u2014the central element of subjective well-being\u2014are associated with interdependence and interpersonal engagement of the self in Japan, but with independence and interpersonal disengagement of the self in the United States. Japanese and American college students (total N = 913) reported how frequently they experienced various emotional states in daily life. In support of the hypothesis, the reported frequency of general positive emotions (e.g. calm, elated) was most closely associated with the reported frequency of interpersonally engaged positive emotions (e.g. friendly feelings) in Japan, but with the reported frequency of interpersonally disengaged positive emotions (e.g. pride) in the United States. Further, for Americans the reported frequency of experience was considerably higher for positive emotions than for negative emotions, but for Japanese it was higher for engaged emotions than for disengaged emotions. Implications for cultural constructions of emotion in general and subjective well-being in particular are discussed.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;S. Kitayama&quot;,&quot;H. Markus&quot;,&quot;Masaru Kurokawa&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2000,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Cognition and Emotion&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/culture-emotion-wellbeing-good-feelings-japan-united-kitayama/ac4ee7b7b0d3523ea7feb32c1ec8967a/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1080/026999300379003&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;14&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;124 - 93&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:5},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Psychological Capital and Well-being.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Although important and of undeniable significance, decades of extensive research on mental illness and dysfunctional behavior in psychology, sociology and other foundational behavioral science disciplines have generally ignored or failed to contribute to the better understanding of the role that human strengths, flourishing and optimal functioning have for overall well-being. Similarly, the study of work stress, burnout, conflict, dysfunctional attitudes, counterproductive behaviors and other negative constructs that have preoccupied organizational behavior and human resources management scholars and practitioners have also not necessarily shed additional light on the characteristics of exceptional performers or the dynamic processes that facilitate excellence in the workplace. This realization motivated positive psychologists and positive organizational behavior (POB) scholars to launch new and exciting streams of research that focus on positivity in its own right, rather than simply extrapolating existing mainstream research. This essay focuses on one of these streams of research, namely psychological capital or simply PsyCap. We use this stream of research as an example and illustration of positive research in terms of rigor and relevance. We present conceptual frameworks in which positivity, particularly PsyCap, can promote well-being, both at and beyond the workplace.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Carolyn M. Youssef-Morgan&quot;,&quot;F. Luthans&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2015,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Stress and health : journal of the International Society for the Investigation of Stress&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/capital-wellbeing-youssefmorgan/a44736c5b61654538261491f861f6db4/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1002/smi.2623&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;31 3&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          180-8\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:6},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Social Psychology&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Within the context of psychology, social psychology is the scientific study of how people&#x27;s thoughts, feelings, and behaviors are influenced by the actual, imagined, or implied presence of others.[1] By this definition, scientific refers to the empirical method of investigation. The terms thoughts, feelings, and behaviors include all psychological variables that are measurable in a human being. The statement that others&#x27; presence may be imagined or implied suggests that we are prone to social influence even when no other people are present, such as when watching television, or following internalized cultural norms. Social psychologists typically explain human behavior as a result of the interaction of mental states and immediate social situations. In general, social psychologists have a preference for laboratory-based, empirical findings. Social psychology theories tend to be specific and focused, rather than global and general. Social psychology is an interdisciplinary domain that bridges the gap between psychology and sociology. During the years immediately following World War II, there was frequent collaboration between psychologists and sociologists.[2] However, the two disciplines have become increasingly specialized and isolated from each other in recent years, with sociologists focusing on \\&quot;macro variables\\&quot; (e.g., social structure) to a much greater extent. Nevertheless, sociological approaches to social psychology remain an important counterpart to psychological research in this area. In addition to the split between psychology and sociology, there has been a somewhat less pronounced difference in emphasis between American social psychologists and European social psychologists. As a broad generalization, American researchers traditionally have focused more on the individual, whereas Europeans have paid more attention to group level phenomena (see group dynamics).[3]&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;M. Abd El-Hay&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2019,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Definitions&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/social-psychology-elhay/475df2bd788755759da2867e0d1f2654/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1007/978-1-4615-7694-5_10&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:7},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Psychology As The Behaviorist Views It&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Psychology as the behaviorist views it is a purely objective experimental branch of natural science. Its theoretical goal is the prediction and control of behavior. Introspection forms no essential part of its methods, nor is the scientific value of its data dependent upon the readiness with which they lend themselves to interpretation in terms of consciousness. The behaviorist, in his efforts to get a unitary scheme of animal response, recognizes no dividing line between man and brute. The behavior of man, with all of its refinement and complexity, forms only a part of the behaviorist&#x27;s total scheme of investigation.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;J. Watson&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2011,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/psychology-behaviorist-views-watson/eac1775d38045902b016977c6cc91a52/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037//0033-295x.101.2.248&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:8},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The feels good theory of pleasure&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Most philosophers since Sidgwick have thought that the various forms of pleasure differ so radically that one cannot find a common, distinctive feeling among them. This is known as the heterogeneity problem. To get around this problem, the motivational theory of pleasure suggests that what makes an experience one of pleasure is our reaction to it, not something internal to the experience. I argue that the motivational theory is wrong, and not only wrong, but backwards. The heterogeneity problem is the principal source of motivation for this, otherwise, highly counterintuitive theory. I intend to show that the heterogeneity problem is not a genuine problem and that a more straightforward theory of pleasure is forthcoming. I argue that the various experiences that we call \u201cpleasures\u201d all feel good.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Aaron Smuts&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2011,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Philosophical Studies&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/feels-theory-pleasure-smuts/9b0ee2e82d2257f88852b89df7cfeed6/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1007/S11098-010-9566-4&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;155&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;241-265&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:9},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;What (and Why) is Positive Psychology?&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Positive psychology is the study of the conditions and processes that contribute to the flourishing or optimal functioning of people, groups, and institutions. Instead of demonstrating that positive attitudes explain achievement, success, well-being and happiness, positive psychology merely associates mental health with a particular personality type: a cheerful, outgoing, goal-driven, status-seeking extravert.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Alistair Miller&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2008,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal of Philosophy of Education&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/critique-positive-psychology\u2014or-science-happiness-miller/d62d62567a0d5863b2ab121102527b5c/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1111/J.1467-9752.2008.00646.X&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;42&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;591-608&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:12},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Employee Positive Emotion and Favorable Outcomes at the Workplace&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;This paper draws on writings in psychology, sociology and organizational behavior to develop a conceptual framework that specifies how positive emotion helps employees obtain favorable outcomes at work. We propose that feeling and expressing positive emotions on the job have favorable consequences on: 1 employees independent of their relationships with others e.g., greater persistence, 2 reactions of others to employees e.g., \\&quot;halo,\\&quot; or overgeneralization to other desirable traits, and 3 reactions of employees to others e.g., helping others. These three sets of intervening processes are proposed, in turn, to lead to work achievement, job enrichment and a higher quality social context. A partial test of this framework is made in an 18-month study of 272 employees. Results indicate that positive emotion on the job at time 1 is associated with evidence of work achievement more favorable supervisor evaluations and higher pay and a supportive social context more support from supervisors and coworkers at time 2. But positive emotion at time 1 is not significantly associated with job enrichment at time 2.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Barry M. Staw&quot;,&quot;R. I. Sutton&quot;,&quot;L. H. Pelled&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1994,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Organization Science&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/employee-positive-emotion-favorable-outcomes-workplace-staw/8bda2d64bbbc5eb9890c7acd02838ccc/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1287/ORSC.5.1.51&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;5&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;51-71&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:13},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The Psychology of the Emotions&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;IN this book Prof. Ribot gives a very complete account of his subject. In the first part he deals with pleasure and pain and the general nature of emotion. He advocates a theory of emotion which he terms \u201cphysiological.\u201d Feeling is regarded as a primary aspect of mental life, closely connected with biological conditions; and the author seems to think that it is hopeless in this region of psychology, at any rate, to depend wholly on purely psychological methods, the subject only becoming intelligible by going beyond consciousness and treating it in its physiological relations. As part of this general theory Prof. Ribot adopts, with some qualification, the theory illustrated by James in the words, \u201cwe feel sorry because we cry, angry because we strike, afraid because we tremble.\u201d In the second part, dealing with the special forms of emotion, no attempt is made to give an elaborate classification; but the chief aspects of emotional life are described in the order in which they seem to have developed. In this part, and especially in the chapters on character and temperament, the author brings out the great value of pathology in the study of psychology.The Psychology of the Emotions.By Th. Ribot. Pp. xix + 455. (London: Walter Scott, Ltd., 1897.)&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;G. Arundale&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1898,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Bristol Medico-Chirurgical Journal (1883)&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/psychology-emotions-arundale/0bfa769fd650547e9b5fd7f8389c6f57/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1038/057150b0&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;16&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;259 - 259&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:14},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The role of positive emotions in positive psychology. The broaden-and-build theory of positive emotions.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;In this article, the author describes a new theoretical perspective on positive emotions and situates this new perspective within the emerging field of positive psychology. The broaden-and-build theory posits that experiences of positive emotions broaden people&#x27;s momentary thought-action repertoires, which in turn serves to build their enduring personal resources, ranging from physical and intellectual resources to social and psychological resources. Preliminary empirical evidence supporting the broaden-and-build theory is reviewed, and open empirical questions that remain to be tested are identified. The theory and findings suggest that the capacity to experience positive emotions may be a fundamental human strength central to the study of human flourishing.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;B. Fredrickson&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2001,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;The American psychologist&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/role-emotions-psychology-broadenandbuild-theory-fredrickson/f7343b806c1759bbb584074d5e4d45ac/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037/0003-066X.56.3.218&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;56 3&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          218-26\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:15},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;On emotion specificity in decision making: Why feeling is for doing&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;We present a motivational account of the impact of emotion on decision making, termed the feeling-is-for-doing approach. We first describe the psychology of emotion and argue for a need to be specific when studying emotion&#x27;s impact on decision making. Next we describe what our approach entails and how it relates emotion, via motivation to behavior. Then we offer two illustrations of our own research that provide support for two important elements in our reasoning. We end with specifying four criteria that we consider to be important when studying how feeling guides our everyday doing.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;M. Zeelenberg&quot;,&quot;R. Nelissen&quot;,&quot;Seger M. Breugelmans&quot;,&quot;R. Pieters&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2008,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Judgment and Decision Making&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/emotion-specificity-decision-making-feeling-zeelenberg/c9bcad6805d2562bace3553518d85f22/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1017/s1930297500000139&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:16},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Handbook of motivation and cognition : foundations of social behavior&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The apparent success of cognitive principles in accounting for several behaviors has led social psychologists to question the need for motivations and other \\&quot;hot\\&quot; dispositional constructs. In their place, they postulate nonmotivational \\&quot;cold\\&quot; cognitions. Behavioral variations between individuals are thus reduced to differences in information processing abilities, while biases and other apparently motivated behaviors are explained on the \\&quot;faulty computer\\&quot; model. However, as many cognitive psychologists now acknowledge this mechanistic theory fails to tie the processing of information to the performance of actions. In a creative attempt to bridge this gap, the editors and investigators have begun to challenge the prevailing hot/cold, either/or dichotomy. Instead, they propose the \\&quot;warm look\\&quot; - a synergistic approach to the roles of \\&quot;hot\\&quot; motivations and \\&quot;cold\\&quot; cognitions in the production of behavior. In their view, neither one alone is sufficient to explain social phenomena. In fact, outside of theory, the two are inseparable. This comprehensive handbook attempts an integration of contrasting approaches to behavior discusses the dual contributions of cognition and motivation to affective states, the development and evaluation of the self, and the setting and attainment of goals. Central themes include the notion of different public and private selves forming distinct influences on motivational behavior; the key role of affect in mediating social information processing; and the differences between informational and affective value, or between behavior geared to finding out versus behavior prompted by a desire to feel good. While much remains to be learned about the complex interplay of motivation and cognition, these studies demonstrate that the two can no longer be treated as separate, unrelated factors. Subjective states and goals clearly influence information processing, while the acquisition of information alters affect and behavior. An ambitious and original attempt to bridge the gap between thought and action, the Handbook is an indispensable reference for all social cognitive and developmental psychologists, investigators of personality and motivation, and advanced students in these areas.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;R. Sorrentino&quot;,&quot;E. Higgins&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1991,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Contemporary Sociology&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/handbook-motivation-cognition-foundations-behavior-sorrentino/4a4c4ff2f66d5b36ab55f1b1f86aa074/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.2307/2072281&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;20&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;793&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:17},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;What do facial expressions convey: feeling states, behavioral intentions, or action requests?&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Emotion theorists assume certain facial displays to convey information about the expresser&#x27;s emotional state. In contrast, behavioral ecologists assume them to indicate behavioral intentions or action requests. To test these contrasting positions, over 2,000 online participants were presented with facial expressions and asked what they revealed-feeling states, behavioral intentions, or action requests. The majority of the observers chose feeling states as the message of facial expressions of disgust, fear, sadness, happiness, and surprise, supporting the emotions view. Only the anger display tended to elicit more choices of behavioral intention or action request, partially supporting the behavioral ecology view. The results support the view that facial expressions communicate emotions, with emotions being multicomponential phenomena that comprise feelings, intentions, and wishes.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;G. Horstmann&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2003,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Emotion&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/what-expressions-convey-feeling-states-intentions-action-horstmann/f095ee2062255de68bd86eb8d88c4c4e/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037/1528-3542.3.2.150&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;3 2&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          150-66\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:18},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Overview of Behavioral Psychology&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Behavioral psychology as it exists today is a young discipline.1 Although its philosophical underpinnings have their origins in antiquity, most writers who review the historical development of the field begin their story about the turn of the present century.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;A. Poling&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1986,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/overview-behavioral-psychology-poling/6d7b6402faf451e08ddf5a69d729d76a/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1007/978-1-4684-5065-1_3&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;51-79&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:19},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;\u201cHappiness\u201d and \u201cThe Good Life\u201d as Motives Working Together Effectively&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Abstract Motivation lies at the heart of any inquiry into \u201chappiness\u201d or \u201cthe good life.\u201d Historically, the dominant perspective on \u201chappiness\u201d or \u201cthe good life\u201d treats them as the maximization of pleasure and the minimization of pain. This point of view, however, has come under increasing criticism among positive psychologists, and in this chapter we complement these recent perspectives. By applying principles of motivation science, we construct an alternative theory of the good life that emphasizes the importance of people having an effective organization of their value, truth, and control motives (Higgins, 2012). This working together among value, truth, and control motives creates the sense of an overall \u201cfit\u201d with one&#x27;s world that creates an experience of \u201cfeeling right\u201d about one&#x27;s life. Drawing on ancient wisdom and modern science, we argue that this perspective offers us a fuller picture of \u201cthe good life.\u201d&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;E. Scientific literature provides insights into what constitutes happiness, well-being, and a fulfilling life. Here&#x27;s how these studies contribute to our understanding:\n\n1. **Positive affective state enhances helpfulness**: Individuals in a positive mood, such as those experiencing the joy of consuming a favorite food like cheese, are more likely to be helpful and kind to others. This suggests that feeling good not only benefits the individual but also impacts their social behavior positively [(Isen &amp; Levin, 1972)](https://consensus.app/papers/feeling-helping-cookies-kindness-isen/918add22d7765176be5e98c096c4966e/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n2. **Subjective well-being and happiness**: Subjective well-being, or people&#x27;s cognitive and affective evaluations of their lives, plays a crucial role in what makes us feel good. Understanding the components of subjective well-being, such as adaptation, goals, and temperament, can contribute to our overall happiness [(Diener, 2000)](https://consensus.app/papers/wellbeing-science-happiness-proposal-index-diener/93acebd3c0125f5aa30a28fc32ca0b70/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n3. **Broadening the focus of psychology**: Positive psychology emphasizes positive subjective experiences, individual traits, and positive institutions, broadening the focus beyond the alleviation of suffering. Key elements like hope, creativity, and wisdom are central to feeling good and living a meaningful life [(Seligman &amp; Cs\u00edkszentmih\u00e1lyi, 2000)](https://consensus.app/papers/psychology-introduction-seligman/5b14058c35ea539a907f69c933e10ffa/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n4. **Cultural influences on well-being**: Cultural differences shape what makes us feel good, indicating that well-being is not only a personal experience but also a cultural construct. For instance, in Japan, positive emotions are more closely associated with interdependence, whereas in the United States, they are linked with independence [(Kitayama, Markus, &amp; Kurokawa, 2000)](https://consensus.app/papers/culture-emotion-wellbeing-good-feelings-japan-united-kitayama/ac4ee7b7b0d3523ea7feb32c1ec8967a/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n5. **Role of positive emotions in well-being**: Positive emotions play a central role in enhancing our well-being. Experiencing positive emotions broadens our thought-action repertoires, which in turn builds our enduring personal resources, contributing to a fulfilling and happy life [(Fredrickson, 2001)](https://consensus.app/papers/role-emotions-psychology-broadenandbuild-theory-fredrickson/f7343b806c1759bbb584074d5e4d45ac/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\nIn conclusion, the science of feeling good extends beyond mere chemical reactions in the brain to include psychological, cultural, and philosophical dimensions. Nevertheless, I can provide a general overview based on established psychological theories and research findings.\n\n### Positive States vs. Immediate Stimuli\n\n**Positive States**:\nPositive states such as happiness, contentment, or joy are generally more enduring emotional conditions. They can be influenced by a variety of factors, including one&#x27;s general outlook on life, long-term relationships, career satisfaction, and a sense of purpose or achievement. These states are typically not the direct result of a single stimulus but are built over time through experiences, thoughts, and behaviors that align with one&#x27;s values and goals.\n\n**Immediate Stimuli**:\nImmediate stimuli that produce &#x27;feel good&#x27; feelings are typically specific, short-term triggers that lead to a quick, often visceral reaction. Examples include tasting your favorite food, receiving a compliment, listening to a favorite piece of music, or experiencing a warm, sunny day. These stimuli can directly impact the brain&#x27;s reward system, releasing neurotransmitters such as dopamine and serotonin, which contribute to feelings of pleasure and satisfaction.\n\n### Mechanism by Which Stimuli Produce Positive Feelings\n\n1. **Sensory Pleasure**: This is the simplest form of pleasure, which comes directly from the senses (e.g., taste, touch, sound, sight, and smell). For example, eating a piece of chocolate can immediately stimulate the brain&#x27;s reward centers, releasing dopamine.\n\n2. **Social Interaction**: Positive social interactions can stimulate the release of oxytocin, often referred to as the &#x27;cuddle hormone&#x27;, which increases feelings of trust, bonding, and social connection.\n\n3. **Novelty**: New experiences or unexpected surprises can trigger the release of dopamine, leading to feelings of pleasure and curiosity.\n\n4. **Accomplishment**: Completing a task or achieving a goal can lead to a sense of satisfaction and elation. This is often associated with the release of endorphins and dopamine, contributing to what is sometimes called the &#x27;achievement high&#x27;.\n\n5. **Aesthetic Appreciation**: Encountering beauty, whether in nature, art, or music, can evoke a profound sense of awe and pleasure, often associated with increased activity in the brain&#x27;s frontal lobes, which are involved in emotional regulation and meaning-making.\n\n6. **Altruism**: Engaging in acts of kindness or helping others can produce a &#x27;helper&#x27;s high&#x27;, associated with endorphin release, which leads to feelings of happiness and well-being.\n\nEach of these mechanisms involves complex interactions within the brain and body, influenced by individual perceptions, past experiences, and personal values. While the immediate pleasure from stimuli is often short-lived, it can contribute to longer-term happiness when integrated into a balanced and fulfilling life. If you have specific aspects you want to delve into or need more detailed explanations, please let me know!"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": "update_time": 1710529393.1107135, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Emotional states and physical health.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Positive emotional states may promote healthy perceptions, beliefs, and physical well-being itself. To explore potential mechanisms linking pleasant feelings and good health, the authors consider several lines of research, including (a) direct effects of positive affect on physiology, especially the immune system, (b) the information value of emotional experiences, (c) the psychological resources engendered by positive feeling states, (d) the ways in which mood can motivate health-relevant behaviors, and (e) the elicitation of social support. As anticipated by the Greek physician Hippocrates, positive emotions and healthy outcomes may be linked through multiple pathways.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;P. Positive emotions are conscious processes that involve a variety of components, such as a pleasant experience, facial/body expressions, evaluations, and especially behavioural plans and activation states. People&#x27;s cognitive process is often accompanied by emotions, and the influence of positive emotions on cognitive activities has gradually become the focus of research in recent years. This study constructs a regulation model and an assessment model of positive emotions, and analyses the neural mechanisms of the effects of dopamine substances on human positive emotions.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Jie Yin&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2019,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Translational Neuroscience&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/study-progress-neural-mechanism-positive-emotions-yin/81d62d707adc575a836980f192b06f33/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1515/tnsci-2019-0016&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;10&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;93 - 98&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:2},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The neurobiology of positive emotions&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Compared to the study of negative emotions such as fear, the neurobiology of positive emotional processes and the associated positive affect (PA) states has only recently received scientific attention. Biological theories conceptualize PA as being related to (i) signals indicating that bodies are returning to equilibrium among those studying homeostasis, (ii) utility estimation among those favoring neuroeconomic views, and (iii) approach and other instinctual behaviors among those cultivating neuroethological perspectives. Indeed, there are probably several distinct forms of positive affect, but all are closely related to ancient sub-neocortical limbic brain regions we share with other mammals. There is now a convergence of evidence to suggest that various regions of the limbic system, including especially ventral striatal dopamine systems are implemented in an anticipatory (appetitive) positive affective state. Dopamine independent mechanisms utilizing opiate and GABA receptors in the ventral striatum, amygdala and orbital frontal cortex are important in elaborating consummatory PA (i.e. sensory pleasure) states, and various neuropeptides mediate homeostatic satisfactions.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;J. Burgdorf&quot;,&quot;J. Panksepp&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2006,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Neuroscience &amp; Biobehavioral Reviews&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/neurobiology-emotions-burgdorf/eec9b7bfa4855b878ed63d3b78f87a91/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1016/j.neubiorev.2005.06.001&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;30&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;173-187&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:3},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Pleasure as a sign you can attend to something else: Placing positive feelings within a general model of affect&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Positive feelings are considered within the framework of a general model of origins and functions of affect. This model treats affect as reflecting the error signal of a feedback loop managing rate of incentive-seeking (and threat-avoidant) behaviour. In this view, positive feelings represent a sign that things are going better than necessary and are presumed to induce coasting. A tendency to coast is seen as facilitating the shift of attention and effort to other behavioural domains, where they may be needed more or where unforeseen opportunities have arisen. Such a function for positive feelings would permit the person both to maintain satisfactory standing with regard to multiple goals and to take advantage of unforeseen opportunities, thus providing adaptive value. Comparisons are made to other recently developed ideas concerning the functions of positive feelings.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;C. Carver&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2003,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Cognition and Emotion&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/pleasure-sign-attend-something-else-placing-feelings-carver/f1387f6706c8518e95e5c2cf4e2415e9/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1080/02699930302294&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;17&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;241 - 261&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:4},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;What Good Are Positive Emotions?&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;This article opens by noting that positive emotions do not fit existing models of emotions. Consequently, a new model is advanced to describe the form and function of a subset of positive emotions, including joy, interest, contentment, and love. This new model posits that these positive emotions serve to broaden an individual&#x27;s momentary thought\u2013action repertoire, which in turn has the effect of building that individual&#x27;s physical, intellectual, and social resources. Empirical evidence to support this broaden-and-build model of positive emotions is reviewed, and implications for emotion regulation and health promotion are discussed.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;B. Fredrickson&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1998,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Review of General Psychology&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/what-good-positive-emotions-fredrickson/a535b0f0d83d5d868fe18409e2ee804d/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037/1089-2680.2.3.300&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;2&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;300 - 319&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:5},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Emotional states and physical health.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Positive emotional states may promote healthy perceptions, beliefs, and physical well-being itself. To explore potential mechanisms linking pleasant feelings and good health, the authors consider several lines of research, including (a) direct effects of positive affect on physiology, especially the immune system, (b) the information value of emotional experiences, (c) the psychological resources engendered by positive feeling states, (d) the ways in which mood can motivate health-relevant behaviors, and (e) the elicitation of social support. As anticipated by the Greek physician Hippocrates, positive emotions and healthy outcomes may be linked through multiple pathways.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Peter  Salovey&quot;,&quot;Alexander J. Rothman&quot;,&quot;Jerusha B. Detweiler&quot;,&quot;Wayne T. Steward&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2000,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;American Psychologist&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/states-health-salovey/8a0754db6cdf52f78c6d82ebb254a1fc/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037//0003-066X.55.1.110&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:6},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Positive Emotions at Work&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Positive organizational scholarship has led to a growing interest in the critical role of positive emotions for the lives of both workers and organizations. We review and integrate the different perspectives on positive emotions (i.e., positive valence, positive emotion regulation strategies, and positive adaptive function) and the four main mechanisms (i.e., cognition, affect, behavior, and physiology) that lead to positive organizational outcomes. There is growing evidence that positive emotions influence variables vital for workplace success such as positive beliefs, creativity, work engagement, positive coping, health, teamwork and collaboration, customer satisfaction, leadership, and performance. We additionally review dynamic features of positive emotions (i.e., intraindividual variability, reactivity, inertia, cycles, feedback loops) and their relation to psychological and work outcomes. Finally, we discuss additional questions and future directions for consideration.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;E. Diener&quot;,&quot;Stuti Thapa&quot;,&quot;L. Tay&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2020,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Annual Review of Organizational Psychology and Organizational Behavior&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/emotions-work-diener/8819cf4f1b0d5c10a78020bcbcf1daea/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1146/annurev-orgpsych-012119-044908&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:7},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Upward spirals of positive emotions counter downward spirals of negativity: insights from the broaden-and-build theory and affective neuroscience on the treatment of emotion dysfunctions and deficits in psychopathology.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;This review integrates Fredrickson&#x27;s broaden-and-build theory of positive emotions with advances in affective neuroscience regarding plasticity in the neural circuitry of emotions to inform the treatment of emotion deficits within psychopathology. We first present a body of research showing that positive emotions broaden cognition and behavioral repertoires, and in so doing, build durable biopsychosocial resources that support coping and flourishing mental health. Next, by explicating the processes through which momentary experiences of emotions may accrue into self-perpetuating emotional systems, the current review proposes an underlying architecture of state-trait interactions that engenders lasting affective dispositions. This theoretical framework is then used to elucidate the cognitive-emotional mechanisms underpinning three disorders of affect regulation: depression, anxiety, and schizophrenia. In turn, two mind training interventions, mindfulness and loving-kindness meditation, are highlighted as means of generating positive emotions that may counter the negative affective processes implicated in these disorders. We conclude with the proposition that positive emotions may exert a countervailing force on the dysphoric, fearful, or anhedonic states characteristic of psychopathologies typified by emotional dysfunctions.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Eric L. Garland&quot;,&quot;Barbara Fredrickson&quot;,&quot;A. Kring&quot;,&quot;David P Johnson&quot;,&quot;Piper S. Meyer&quot;,&quot;David L Penn&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2010,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Clinical psychology review&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/upward-spirals-emotions-counter-spirals-negativity-garland/c8c0b605bef65851a971c6ea7a69f669/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1016/j.cpr.2010.03.002&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;30 7&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          849-64\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:8},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The Negative Effect of Pursuing Positive Emotion and Its Psychological Mechanism&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Recent studies have found that the more positive emotion people pursue, the less likely they will feel happy. Its psychological mechanism may be:when pursuing positive emotion comes to be a major goal, people tend to(1) set a too high standard for happy emotion;(2) obtain happiness through ineffective ways;(3) monitor the process of getting happy instead of immersing in it. There are many questions should be further explored:(1) Revealing the consequences of pursuing positive emotion comprehensively;(2) The neural mechanisms of pursuing positive emotion&#x27;s negative effects;(3) The cross-culture differences of pursuing positive emotion;(4) To explore the way to gain positive results in pursuing positive emotion.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Li Aimei&quot;,&quot;Lin Xiaoping&quot;,&quot;Gao Jieyi&quot;,&quot;Peng Yuan&quot;,&quot;Xia Ying&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2015,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/effect-pursuing-positive-emotion-psychological-aimei/5e14d1e63f6e574ab711db6bdc135e51/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.3724/SP.J.1042.2015.00979&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;23&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;979-989&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:9},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;How Positive Emotions Build Physical Health&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The mechanisms underlying the association between positive emotions and physical health remain a mystery. We hypothesize that an upward-spiral dynamic continually reinforces the tie between positive emotions and physical health and that this spiral is mediated by people\u2019s perceptions of their positive social connections. We tested this overarching hypothesis in a longitudinal field experiment in which participants were randomly assigned to an intervention group that self-generated positive emotions via loving-kindness meditation or to a waiting-list control group. Participants in the intervention group increased in positive emotions relative to those in the control group, an effect moderated by baseline vagal tone, a proxy index of physical health. Increased positive emotions, in turn, produced increases in vagal tone, an effect mediated by increased perceptions of social connections. This experimental evidence identifies one mechanism\u2014perceptions of social connections\u2014through which positive emotions build physical health, indexed as vagal tone. Results suggest that positive emotions, positive social connections, and physical health influence one another in a self-sustaining upward-spiral dynamic.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Bethany E. Kok&quot;,&quot;Kimberly A. Coffey&quot;,&quot;M. Cohn&quot;,&quot;Lahnna I Catalino&quot;,&quot;Tanya Vacharkulksemsuk&quot;,&quot;S. Algoe&quot;,&quot;Mary M. Brantley&quot;,&quot;B. Fredrickson&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2013,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Psychological Science&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/emotions-build-physical-health-kok/6b3f8ad54875573a8a46f3c8d77aa8cd/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1177/0956797612470827&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;24&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;1123 - 1132&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:10},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;BRAIN MECHANISMS OF HAPPINESS&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Happiness is a kind of subjective feeling of positive emotions. Since the psychological process of reward is closely linked to pleasure, studies to elucidate the brain mechanisms of happiness have focused on the neural circuitry that processes reward information. Brain imaging studies have revealed that the orbitofrontal cortex, cingulate cortex, medial prefrontal cortex, insula, nucleus accumbens, ventral pallidum, substantia nigra, and ventral tegmental area are the key areas related to happiness. When we consider the brain mechanisms of happiness, we need to distinguish between the neural mechanisms for liking and wanting, and between those that encode and cause pleasant feelings. Among these brain areas, subcortical structures participate in \u201cwanting\u201d, while cortical areas participate in \u201cliking\u201d. Orbitofrontal activity has been shown to encode the subjective experience of pleasure. However, it is not clear whether orbitofrontal activity actually causes pleasant feelings. Since the neuroscience of happiness is still in the primitive stage, further experiments are needed to elucidate the brain mechanisms of happiness.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;S. Funahashi&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2011,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Psychologia&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/brain-mechanisms-happiness-funahashi/0ebc7f68c26e58c4a6189a5f3891f3e2/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.2117/PSYSOC.2011.222&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;54&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;222-233&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:11},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Working mechanisms in positive interventions: A study using daily assessment of positive emotions&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;ABSTRACT One commonly suggested mechanism in positive psychology interventions (PPIs) involves the elicitation of positive emotions. We examined (1) whether PPIs increase the intensity and variety of positive emotions; (2) which positive emotions are elicited by two different PPIs; and (3) the impact of positive emotions on well-being. In a randomized, controlled one-week intervention study, we compared the \u2018three good things\u2019 and the \u2018three funny things\u2019 intervention with a placebo control. We assessed the positive and negative emotions reported daily during the intervention, and the well-being and depressive symptoms directly before, after, and one week after the intervention. Results showed higher intensity and variety of positive emotions elicited by the PPIs, and increases in well-being could be explained by the intensity and variety of positive emotions. The study provides a model for how the mechanisms underlying PPIs can be studied and underlines the relevance of positive emotions in PPIs.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;F. Gander&quot;,&quot;R. Proyer&quot;,&quot;Eva Hentz&quot;,&quot;W. Ruch&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2020,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;The Journal of Positive Psychology&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/working-mechanisms-interventions-study-using-assessment-gander/37ccb5970ef554d0b9f791441d8bb5b6/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1080/17439760.2020.1789698&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;15&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;633 - 638&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:12},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The Undoing Effect of Positive Emotions&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Positive emotions are hypothesized to undo the cardiovascular aftereffects of negative emotions. Study 1 tests this undoing effect. Participants (n = 170) experiencing anxiety-induced cardiovascular reactivity viewed a film that elicited (a) contentment, (b) amusement, (c) neutrality, or (d) sadness. Contentment-eliciting and amusing films produced faster cardiovascular recovery than neutral or sad films did. Participants in Study 2 (n = 185) viewed these same films following a neutral state. Results disconfirm the alternative explanation that the undoing effect reflects a simple replacement process. Findings are contextualized by Fredrickson&#x27;s broaden-and-build theory of positive emotions (B. L. Fredrickson, 1998).&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;B. Fredrickson&quot;,&quot;R. We propose that feeling and expressing positive emotions on the job have favorable consequences on: 1 employees independent of their relationships with others e.g., greater persistence, 2 reactions of others to employees e.g., \\&quot;halo,\\&quot; or overgeneralization to other desirable traits, and 3 reactions of employees to others e.g., helping others. These three sets of intervening processes are proposed, in turn, to lead to work achievement, job enrichment and a higher quality social context. A partial test of this framework is made in an 18-month study of 272 employees. Results indicate that positive emotion on the job at time 1 is associated with evidence of work achievement more favorable supervisor evaluations and higher pay and a supportive social context more support from supervisors and coworkers at time 2. But positive emotion at time 1 is not significantly associated with job enrichment at time 2.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Barry M. Staw&quot;,&quot;R. I. Sutton&quot;,&quot;L. H. The broaden-and-build theory of positive emotions.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;In this article, the author describes a new theoretical perspective on positive emotions and situates this new perspective within the emerging field of positive psychology. The broaden-and-build theory posits that experiences of positive emotions broaden people&#x27;s momentary thought-action repertoires, which in turn serves to build their enduring personal resources, ranging from physical and intellectual resources to social and psychological resources. Preliminary empirical evidence supporting the broaden-and-build theory is reviewed, and open empirical questions that remain to be tested are identified. The theory and findings suggest that the capacity to experience positive emotions may be a fundamental human strength central to the study of human flourishing.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;B. Fredrickson&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2001,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;The American psychologist&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/role-emotions-psychology-broadenandbuild-theory-fredrickson/f7343b806c1759bbb584074d5e4d45ac/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037/0003-066X.56.3.218&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;56 3&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          218-26\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:15},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Culture, Emotion, and Well-being: Good Feelings in Japan and the United States&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;We tested the hypothesis that \u201cgood feelings\u201d\u2014the central element of subjective well-being\u2014are associated with interdependence and interpersonal engagement of the self in Japan, but with independence and interpersonal disengagement of the self in the United States. Japanese and American college students (total N = 913) reported how frequently they experienced various emotional states in daily life. In support of the hypothesis, the reported frequency of general positive emotions (e.g. calm, elated) was most closely associated with the reported frequency of interpersonally engaged positive emotions (e.g. friendly feelings) in Japan, but with the reported frequency of interpersonally disengaged positive emotions (e.g. pride) in the United States. Further, for Americans the reported frequency of experience was considerably higher for positive emotions than for negative emotions, but for Japanese it was higher for engaged emotions than for disengaged emotions. Implications for cultural constructions of emotion in general and subjective well-being in particular are discussed.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;S. Kitayama&quot;,&quot;H. The broaden-and-build theory suggests that this is because positive emotions help people build lasting resources. To test this hypothesis, the authors measured emotions daily for 1 month in a sample of students (N = 86) and assessed life satisfaction and trait resilience at the beginning and end of the month. Positive emotions predicted increases in both resilience and life satisfaction. Negative emotions had weak or null effects and did not interfere with the benefits of positive emotions. Positive emotions also mediated the relation between baseline and final resilience, but life satisfaction did not. This suggests that it is in-the-moment positive emotions, and not more general positive evaluations of one&#x27;s life, that form the link between happiness and desirable life outcomes. Change in resilience mediated the relation between positive emotions and increased life satisfaction, suggesting that happy people become more satisfied not simply because they feel better but because they develop resources for living well.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;M. As predicted, in a survey of over 600 European-, immigrant Asian-, and Asian American college students, positive emotions were associated with depression symptoms among European Americans and Asian Americans, but not immigrant Asians. Negative emotions were associated with depression symptoms among all three groups. We also found initial evidence that acculturation (i.e., nativity) may influence the role of positive emotions in depression: Asian Americans fell \\&quot;in between\\&quot; the two other groups. Cacioppo &amp; G. G. Berntson, 1994) proposes that positive and negative affect are separable and that mixed feelings of happiness and sadness can co-occur. The authors both replicated and extended past research by showing that whereas most participants surveyed in typical situations felt either happy or sad, many participants surveyed immediately after watching the film Life Is Beautiful, moving out of their dormitories, or graduating from college felt both happy and sad. Results suggest that although affective experience may typically be bipolar, the underlying processes, and occasionally the resulting experience of emotion, are better characterized as bivariate.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Jeff T. Based on the research available, here\u2019s how we can separate positive states and immediate stimuli, and discuss their mechanisms:\n\n### Positive States:\n\nPositive states like happiness, contentment, and joy are generally broader and more enduring than responses to specific stimuli. They can be influenced by:\n\n1. **Psychological Resources**: Positive emotional states enhance psychological resources like resilience, optimism, and self-efficacy. They may improve physical well-being and promote healthier behaviors [(Salovey et al., 2000)](https://consensus.app/papers/states-health-salovey/c9eb87b520b859cbb5f6e88c49c30ec1/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n2. **Social Connections**: Positive emotions strengthen social connections, which are crucial for emotional and physical well-being. They foster trust, compassion, and broader social networks, enhancing an individual&#x27;s support system [(Fredrickson, 1998)](https://consensus.app/papers/what-good-positive-emotions-fredrickson/a535b0f0d83d5d868fe18409e2ee804d/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n3. **Coping Mechanisms**: Happiness and other positive emotions can lead to better coping mechanisms for stress and adversity, promoting resilience and a more balanced life satisfaction [(Cohn et al., 2009)](https://consensus.app/papers/happiness-unpacked-emotions-increase-life-satisfaction-cohn/fb4111b0a50257cf8f565ea47813882e/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n### Immediate Stimuli:\n\nImmediate stimuli that produce &#x27;feel-good&#x27; feelings can range from sensory experiences to specific events. These reactions can be more fleeting than broad emotional states but are powerful:\n\n1. **Neurobiological Responses**: Immediate pleasant stimuli often trigger direct neurobiological responses. For example, eating delicious food or listening to music can activate the brain&#x27;s reward pathways, releasing dopamine and other feel-good neurotransmitters, which induce pleasure and satisfaction [(Burgdorf &amp; Panksepp, 2006)](https://consensus.app/papers/neurobiology-emotions-burgdorf/eec9b7bfa4855b878ed63d3b78f87a91/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n2. **Sensory Pleasure**: The direct sensory pleasure from stimuli such as tastes, sounds, or visual art is processed in the brain&#x27;s sensory areas and limbic system, leading to immediate positive feelings [(Carver, 2003)](https://consensus.app/papers/pleasure-sign-attend-something-else-placing-feelings-carver/f1387f6706c8518e95e5c2cf4e2415e9/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n3. **Evaluative Responses**: Our cognitive appraisal of a situation or stimulus can quickly lead to positive feelings. This evaluation depends on personal values, current mood, and contextual factors. For example, receiving a compliment or achieving a goal can immediately generate feelings of pride and joy [(Yin, 2019)](https://consensus.app/papers/study-progress-neural-mechanism-positive-emotions-yin/81d62d707adc575a836980f192b06f33/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n### Mechanisms:\n\n1. **Neurological Pathways**: Both long-term positive states and immediate positive reactions involve complex neurological pathways. The limbic system, particularly the ventral striatum and prefrontal cortex, plays a crucial role in processing positive emotions and stimuli [(Jie Yin, 2019)](https://consensus.app/papers/study-progress-neural-mechanism-positive-emotions-yin/81d62d707adc575a836980f192b06f33/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\n2. **Broaden-and-Build Theory**: This theory suggests that positive emotions broaden an individual&#x27;s thought-action repertoire, leading to the building of enduring personal resources, which in turn contribute to improved well-being and further positive emotions [(Fredrickson, 2001)](https://consensus.app/papers/role-emotions-psychology-broadenandbuild-theory-fredrickson/f7343b806c1759bbb584074d5e4d45ac/?utm_source=chatgpt).\n\nIn summary, while positive states are typically broader and more enduring, influenced by psychological resources and social connections, immediate stimuli induce &#x27;feel-good&#x27; feelings through direct neurobiological reactions and sensory pleasures. Both are integral to the human experience of positivity and well-being."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [100260]}, "citations": [], "gizmo_id": "g-bo0FiWLY7", "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4-gizmo", "pad": "AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA", "parent_id": "0e8c8232-84e1-4ccc-b69b-5e6c029272f3", "request_id": "864ec31aefb774e8-FCO", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "0e8c8232-84e1-4ccc-b69b-5e6c029272f3", "children": ["aaa25c47-3e62-4475-9283-53818e8a6a08"]}, "aaa25c47-3e62-4475-9283-53818e8a6a08": {"id": "aaa25c47-3e62-4475-9283-53818e8a6a08", "message": {"id": "aaa25c47-3e62-4475-9283-53818e8a6a08", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1710529561.286843, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Give me a list of sources and study to continue and support the idea purported in the article below: \n\nThe Science of Feeling Good\n\nEveryone wants to feel good. Pleasure is a key aspect of life, and human beings seek out what gives them pleasure. We are naturally attracted to what makes us feel good. \n\n\nTake my favorite food, cheese, for instance. Scientific studies have revealed that cheese contains a chemical called casein, known for its ability to induce feelings of pleasure. This chemical is so powerful that it triggers the same brain regions as opioids, potentially leading to addictive behaviors. Yet, my intention is not addiction, but rather, to experience the joy that comes from feeling good. Hence, my love for cheese. \n\nBut it&#x27;s not just about the cheese. I often find myself pondering\u2014what truly brings us that feeling of goodness?  What are the essential elements that guarantee a delightful human experience? Is it all about chemical receptors in the brain? Is happiness just a pill or does it encompass something deeper? Is the true science of feeling good science or just a philosophy or attitude that keeps the human mood in optimal condition? Let\u2019s explore what we know about the science of feeling good and its intersections with behavioral philosophy and psychology to get the bottom of the mystery humans have pondered and sought for millennia: How to feel good all the time and lead a happy and meaningful life. \n\nSee, happiness isn\u2019t only the joy of chewing on a cube of sharp creamy cheesy cheddar.
