["{&quot;items&quot;:[{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;What Good Are Positive Emotions?&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;This article opens by noting that positive emotions do not fit existing models of emotions. Consequently, a new model is advanced to describe the form and function of a subset of positive emotions, including joy, interest, contentment, and love. This new model posits that these positive emotions serve to broaden an individual&#x27;s momentary thought\u2013action repertoire, which in turn has the effect of building that individual&#x27;s physical, intellectual, and social resources. Empirical evidence to support this broaden-and-build model of positive emotions is reviewed, and implications for emotion regulation and health promotion are discussed.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;B. Fredrickson&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:1998,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Review of General Psychology&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/what-good-positive-emotions-fredrickson/a535b0f0d83d5d868fe18409e2ee804d/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037/1089-2680.2.3.300&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;2&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;300 - 319&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:1},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Emotional states and physical health.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Positive emotional states may promote healthy perceptions, beliefs, and physical well-being itself. To explore potential mechanisms linking pleasant feelings and good health, the authors consider several lines of research, including (a) direct effects of positive affect on physiology, especially the immune system, (b) the information value of emotional experiences, (c) the psychological resources engendered by positive feeling states, (d) the ways in which mood can motivate health-relevant behaviors, and (e) the elicitation of social support. As anticipated by the Greek physician Hippocrates, positive emotions and healthy outcomes may be linked through multiple pathways.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;P. Salovey&quot;,&quot;Alexander J. Rothman&quot;,&quot;Jerusha B. Detweiler&quot;,&quot;Wayne T. Steward&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2000,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;The American psychologist&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/states-health-salovey/c9eb87b520b859cbb5f6e88c49c30ec1/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037//0003-066X.55.1.110&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;55 1&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          110-21\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:2},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;What is shared, what is different? Core relational themes and expressive displays of eight positive emotions&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Understanding positive emotions&#x27; shared and differentiating features can yield valuable insight into the structure of positive emotion space and identify emotion states, or aspects of emotion states, that are most relevant for particular psychological processes and outcomes. We report two studies that examined core relational themes (Study 1) and expressive displays (Study 2) for eight positive emotion constructs\u2014amusement, awe, contentment, gratitude, interest, joy, love, and pride. Across studies, all eight emotions shared one quality: high positive valence. Distinctive core relational theme and expressive display patterns were found for four emotions\u2014amusement, awe, interest, and pride. Gratitude was associated with a distinct core relational theme but not an expressive display. Joy and love were each associated with a distinct expressive display but their core relational themes also characterised pride and gratitude, respectively. Contentment was associated with a distinct expressive display but not a core relational theme. The implications of this work for the study of positive emotion are discussed.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Belinda Campos&quot;,&quot;M. Shiota&quot;,&quot;D. Keltner&quot;,&quot;Gian C. Gonzaga&quot;,&quot;Jennifer L Goetz&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2013,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Cognition and Emotion&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/what-shared-core-relational-themes-expressive-displays-campos/2db7ff48187b51b8a72a127f6bb55dd7/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1080/02699931.2012.683852&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;27&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;37 - 52&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:3},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The broaden-and-build theory of positive emotions.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The broaden-and-build theory describes the form and function of a subset of positive emotions, including joy, interest, contentment and love. A key proposition is that these positive emotions broaden an individual&#x27;s momentary thought-action repertoire: joy sparks the urge to play, interest sparks the urge to explore, contentment sparks the urge to savour and integrate, and love sparks a recurring cycle of each of these urges within safe, close relationships. The broadened mindsets arising from these positive emotions are contrasted to the narrowed mindsets sparked by many negative emotions (i.e. specific action tendencies, such as attack or flee). A second key proposition concerns the consequences of these broadened mindsets: by broadening an individual&#x27;s momentary thought-action repertoire--whether through play, exploration or similar activities--positive emotions promote discovery of novel and creative actions, ideas and social bonds, which in turn build that individual&#x27;s personal resources; ranging from physical and intellectual resources, to social and psychological resources. Importantly, these resources function as reserves that can be drawn on later to improve the odds of successful coping and survival. This chapter reviews the latest empirical evidence supporting the broaden-and-build theory and draws out implications the theory holds for optimizing health and well-being.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;B. Fredrickson&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2004,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Philosophical transactions of the Royal Society of London. Series B, Biological sciences&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/broadenandbuild-theory-emotions-fredrickson/3b253c0f58425730b2b3606b2bef819b/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1098/RSTB.2004.1512&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;359 1449&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          1367-78\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:4},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Happiness Vs Contentment? A Case for a Sociology of the Good Life&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Despite the enormous growth in happiness research in recent decades, there remains a lack of consistency in the use of the terms happiness, satisfaction, contentment and well-being. In this article I argue for a sociologically grounded distinction between happiness and contentment that defines the former as positive affect and the latter as positive reflection. Contentment is therefore understood as a fulfilling relationship with the self and society (to borrow from G.H. Mead&#x27;s terminology) and happiness involves pleasurable experiences. There is a history of similar distinctions in philosophy and psychoanalysis, but much of the contemporary discourse fails to distinguish between individual and collective definitions of happiness. This article will argue that happiness and contentment ought not to be treated as competing approaches to the good life, but as complimentary forms of emotional experience. Further, I argue that the current interest in happiness can be linked to larger culture shifts involving neoliberalism and individualism.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;J. McKenzie&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2016,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal for The Theory of Social Behaviour&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/happiness-contentment-case-sociology-good-life-mckenzie/cf70b1b6acca51ba847d175af34fb615/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1111/JTSB.12098&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;46&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;252-267&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:5},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Happiness unpacked: positive emotions increase life satisfaction by building resilience.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Happiness-a composite of life satisfaction, coping resources, and positive emotions-predicts desirable life outcomes in many domains. The broaden-and-build theory suggests that this is because positive emotions help people build lasting resources. To test this hypothesis, the authors measured emotions daily for 1 month in a sample of students (N = 86) and assessed life satisfaction and trait resilience at the beginning and end of the month. Positive emotions predicted increases in both resilience and life satisfaction. Negative emotions had weak or null effects and did not interfere with the benefits of positive emotions. Positive emotions also mediated the relation between baseline and final resilience, but life satisfaction did not. This suggests that it is in-the-moment positive emotions, and not more general positive evaluations of one&#x27;s life, that form the link between happiness and desirable life outcomes. Change in resilience mediated the relation between positive emotions and increased life satisfaction, suggesting that happy people become more satisfied not simply because they feel better but because they develop resources for living well.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;M. Cohn&quot;,&quot;B. Fredrickson&quot;,&quot;Stephanie L. Brown&quot;,&quot;Joseph A. Mikels&quot;,&quot;A. Conway&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2009,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Emotion&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/happiness-unpacked-emotions-increase-life-satisfaction-cohn/fb4111b0a50257cf8f565ea47813882e/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037/a0015952&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;9 3&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          361-8\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:6},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;More than one kind of happiness: Can we recognize vocal expressions of different positive states?&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Several theorists have proposed that distinctions are needed between different positive emotional states, and that these discriminations may be particularly useful in the domain of vocal signals (Ekman, 1992b, Cognition and Emotion, 6, 169\u2013200; Scherer, 1986, Psychological Bulletin, 99, 143\u2013165). We report an investigation into the hypothesis that positive basic emotions have distinct vocal expressions (Ekman, 1992b, Cognition and Emotion, 6, 169\u2013200). Non-verbal vocalisations are used that map onto five putative positive emotions: Achievement/Triumph, Amusement, Contentment, Sensual Pleasure, and Relief. Data from categorisation and rating tasks indicate that each vocal expression is accurately categorised and consistently rated as expressing the intended emotion. This pattern is replicated across two language groups. These data, we conclude, provide evidence for the existence of robustly recognisable expressions of distinct positive emotions.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Disa Sauter&quot;,&quot;S. Scott&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2007,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Motivation and Emotion&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/more-kind-happiness-recognize-expressions-states-sauter/0df3aa54c64f555a89da93d5263ee666/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1007/S11031-007-9065-X&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;31&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;192-199&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:7},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Emotional states and physical health.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Positive emotional states may promote healthy perceptions, beliefs, and physical well-being itself. To explore potential mechanisms linking pleasant feelings and good health, the authors consider several lines of research, including (a) direct effects of positive affect on physiology, especially the immune system, (b) the information value of emotional experiences, (c) the psychological resources engendered by positive feeling states, (d) the ways in which mood can motivate health-relevant behaviors, and (e) the elicitation of social support. As anticipated by the Greek physician Hippocrates, positive emotions and healthy outcomes may be linked through multiple pathways.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Peter  Salovey&quot;,&quot;Alexander J. Rothman&quot;,&quot;Jerusha B. Detweiler&quot;,&quot;Wayne T. Steward&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2000,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;American Psychologist&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/states-health-salovey/8a0754db6cdf52f78c6d82ebb254a1fc/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037//0003-066X.55.1.110&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:8},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The Faces of Positive Emotion&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Although several theorists posit the existence of multiple discrete positive emotion states,1\u20134 much empirical research on the nature and consequences of emotion considers only one: happiness.5\u20138 Studies of the facial display of emotion have documented universally recognized expressions of sadness, anger, fear, and other negative emotions, but have not differentiated among positive emotions.6 The Duchenne smile, which includes contraction of the orbicularis oculi as well as the zygomaticus major, is generally considered the sole reliable expression of positive affect. The goal of this study was to establish the features of facial and upper-body displays participants associate with the experience of distinct positive emotions. Although the full data set explores displays of 17 positive and negative emotions, only the data regarding awe, amusement, and pride displays are discussed here.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;M. Shiota&quot;,&quot;Belinda Campos&quot;,&quot;D. Keltner&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2003,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/faces-positive-emotion-shiota/5a1a0a4a694b528cbb4d44b03da94e7f/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1196/annals.1280.029&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;1000&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:9},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Are The Very Happy Too Happy?&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Although positive emotions undoubtedly confer benefits, one can have too much of it. There is probably a point beyond which enjoyment interferes with realism, yet it is unclear where that point is. The original \u201cStates of Mind\u201d (SOM) model (Schwartz and Garamoni, 1986; 1989) proposed that a ratio of [positive] to [positive plus negative] affective/cognitive states [P/(P+N)] of about 0.62 is optimal, but previous research indicated that higher ratios may go with good mental health. The revised \u201cbalanced states of mind\u201d (BSOM) model (Schwartz, 1997) suggests a higher cutoff, with ratios above 0.90 being dysfunctional. This paper reports a study of 72 very positive subjects (mean ratio = 0.85) and assessed possible dysfunction by means of questionnaires, role-plays, and physiological responses to induced stress. Signs of dysfunction were no more frequent among the most positive subjects (ratios of 0.90 and above) than among moderately positive subjects. This suggests that there is nothing wrong with the high levels of happiness in present day society. As yet, it is still not established how much more happiness will be too much. One possibility is that standard cognition/emotion measures need to be revised in order to detect truly excessive positivity in a sensitive manner.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Elisha Tarlow Friedman&quot;,&quot;R. Schwartz&quot;,&quot;D. Haaga&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2002,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal of Happiness Studies&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/very-friedman/16a59b20cca85a31ab152a20a692d3ba/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1023/A:1021828127970&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;3&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;355-372&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:10},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The Benefits of Frequent Positive Affect: Does Happiness Lead to Success?&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Numerous studies show that happy individuals are successful across multiple life domains, including marriage, friendship, income, work performance, and health. The authors suggest a conceptual model to account for these findings, arguing that the happiness-success link exists not only because success makes people happy, but also because positive affect engenders success. Three classes of evidence--crosssectional, longitudinal, and experimental--are documented to test their model. Relevant studies are described and their effect sizes combined meta-analytically. The results reveal that happiness is associated with and precedes numerous successful outcomes, as well as behaviors paralleling success. Furthermore, the evidence suggests that positive affect--the hallmark of well-being--may be the cause of many of the desirable characteristics, resources, and successes correlated with happiness. Limitations, empirical issues, and important future research questions are discussed.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;S. Lyubomirsky&quot;,&quot;L. King&quot;,&quot;E. Diener&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2005,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/benefits-frequent-positive-affect-does-happiness-lead-lyubomirsky/f7a25f49b01f5633a4499b4a3700c47a/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037/0033-2909.131.6.803&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:11},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Sources of Happiness: A Comparison of Male and Female Scholars&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Happiness is a concept which mean many things to many people. Part of the challenge of a science of happiness is to identify different concepts of happiness, and where applicable, split them into their components. Happiness can be defined in terms of a mental state of satisfaction and contentment; positive feelings/emotions; a harmonious homeostasis; achievement and hope; and freedom from ill-being (Lu, Gilmour, &amp; Kao, 2001). However, happiness is not a static state. Even the happiest of people the cheeriest 10%feel blue at times. And even the bluest has their moments of joy. That has presented a challenge to social scientists trying to measure happiness. Happiness is a mental state of well-being characterized by positive or pleasant emotions ranging from contentment to intense joy.Happiness is defined (a) as a predominance of positive over negative affect and (b) as satisfaction with life as a whole (Argyle, Martin, &amp; Crossland, 1989). Philosophers have commonly distinguished two accounts of happiness: hedonism, and the life satisfaction theory. Hedonists identify happiness with the individual&#x27;s balance of pleasant over unpleasant experience whereas Life satisfaction theories identify happiness with having a favourable attitude toward one&#x27;s life as a whole. A third theory, the emotional state view identifies happiness with an agent&#x27;s emotional condition as a whole (Eid &amp; Larson, 2008). In addition, happiness is conceptualized better as a trait than as a transient emotional state (Veenhoven, 1994). Thus, to understand why some people are happier than others, one must understand the cognitive and motivational processes that serve to maintain, and even enhance, enduring happiness and transient mood (Lyubomirsky, 2001). Subjective Wellbeing researchers have progressed from early survey searches for \\&quot;objective\\&quot; external indicators (Andrews &amp; Withey, 1976) and scale development (Diener, Emmons, Larsen, &amp; Griffin, 1985) to explanations of psychological mechanisms of happiness (Lu &amp; Lin, 1998) and even to large-scale cross-cultural comparisons (Diener, Diener, &amp; Diener, 1995).Factors that affect happiness of a person range from internal sources to external sources, right from genetic influences to social situation, personality, momentary events and so on. Chance events like personal tragedies or illness might affect ones happiness but the effect does not remain long (Diener, 2000). Proximal environment like the social class, community, family and economic situation has their effect on well being of a person. At the same time, factors like hope and optimism can be learned to moderate one&#x27;s level of happiness (Seligman, 2002). There are three components of happiness: pleasure (\\&quot;the smiley-face piece\\&quot;), engagement (the depth of involvement with one&#x27;s family, work, romance and hobbies) and meaning (using personal strengths to serve some larger end). Of those three roads to a happy, satisfied life, pleasure is the least consequential and engagement and meaning are much more important\\&quot; (Davis, 2014).People vary in their perception of happiness at different stages of their life and education also plays a role in it. So in order to understand the phenomena from the perspective of research scholars and to compare their level of happiness across gender, the present study was carried out.MethodParticipantsA sample of 60 research scholars equally divided into male (n=30) and female (n=30) groups, were taken from Jamia Millia Islamia. They were enrolled in Ph.D programme in different departments of both science and social science streams. The age of the scholars ranged from 24 to 28 years.InstrumentsThe Subjective Happiness Scale: The scale was developed by Lyubomirsky and Lepper in 1999 and measures the extent to which an individual sees himself or herself as a happy or unhappy person. It comprises four questions and measures response on 7 point rating scale.Open ended questions on sources of happiness: Few questions were made asking about various sources of happiness. \u2026&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;M. A. Paul&quot;,&quot;Mudassir Hassan&quot;,&quot;Waheeda Khan&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2015,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Indian journal of positive psychology&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/sources-happiness-comparison-male-female-scholars-paul/b886248c623c50c09ea3e76441309487/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;6&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;303&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:12},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Happiness - An Evasive State of Mind&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The daily strive to get to work and back home through traffic congestions; passing the day without conflicts; improving the life style when money is short; overcoming medical problems; raising and securing the family, and tolerating unfulfilled dreams are only a portion of constantly bothering issues. No wonder then that in this chaotic reality and despite various joyful and satisfying moments, the majority of grown-ups claim that they are unhappy. Amazingly, however, there are always those who believe and declare that they are happy, which raises the question what is happiness and what is it constituted from. Google suggests that \u201cHappiness is that feeling that comes over you when you know life is good and you can\u2019t help but smile. It\u2019s the opposite of sadness. Happiness is a sense of well-being, joy, or contentment. When people are successful, or safe, or lucky, they feel happy\u201d. This description combines a number of positive experiences and feelings, that most likely affect our brain to release chemicals recognized as the \u2018good guys\u2019, in contrast to the \u2018bad guys\u2019, chemicals secreted in situations of sadness, agony, pain, failures, disappointments and frustrations that affect brain circuits associated with unpleasant emotions and thoughts. Although moments of satisfaction, joy and pleasure raise good feelings, these are usually temporary, whereas happiness in its broader essence reflects a positive state of mind based on numerous parameters that collectively raise a long-lasting contentment. When a person claims he is happy, he probably disregards his difficulties and concentrates on a particular issue that makes him feel good (e.g., love, professional success, good health, overcoming a major difficulty, listening to beloved music, winning in sport).&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Gurevitz M&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2022,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Annals of Depression and Anxiety&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/happiness-evasive-state-mind-m/196f661fad845a63b19f22d5517d2507/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.26420/anndepressanxiety.2022.1114&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:13},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Positive affect and health-related neuroendocrine, cardiovascular, and inflammatory processes.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Negative affective states such as depression are associated with premature mortality and increased risk of coronary heart disease, type 2 diabetes, and disability. It has been suggested that positive affective states are protective, but the pathways through which such effects might be mediated are poorly understood. Here we show that positive affect in middle-aged men and women is associated with reduced neuroendocrine, inflammatory, and cardiovascular activity. Positive affect was assessed by aggregating momentary experience samples of happiness over a working day and was inversely related to cortisol output over the day, independently of age, gender, socioeconomic position, body mass, and smoking. Similar patterns were observed on a leisure day. Happiness was also inversely related to heart rate assessed by using ambulatory monitoring methods over the day. Participants underwent mental stress testing in the laboratory, where plasma fibrinogen stress responses were smaller in happier individuals. These effects were independent of psychological distress, supporting the notion that positive well-being is directly related to health-relevant biological processes.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;A. Steptoe&quot;,&quot;J. Wardle&quot;,&quot;M. Marmot&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2005,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/affect-healthrelated-inflammatory-processes-steptoe/c74abbb6bfca5bc6bfe230f59474b94c/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1073/PNAS.0409174102&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;102 18&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          6508-12\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:14},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Mood and heuristics: the influence of happy and sad states on sensitivity and bias in stereotyping.&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The influence of mood states on the propensity to use heuristics as expressed in stereotypes was examined using signal detection statistics. Participants experienced happy, neutral, or sad moods and \\&quot;remembered\\&quot; whether names connoting race (African American, European American) belonged to social categories (criminal, politician, basketball player). Positive mood increased reliance on heuristics, indexed by higher false identification of members of stereotyped groups. Positive mood lowered sensitivity (d&#x27;), even among relative experts, and shifted bias (beta) or criterion to be more lenient for stereotypical names. In contrast, sad mood did not disrupt sensitivity and, in fact, revealed the use of a stricter criterion compared with baseline mood. Results support theories that characterize happy mood as a mental state that predisposes reliance on heuristics and sad mood as dampening such reliance.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Jaihyun Park&quot;,&quot;M. Banaji&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2000,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Journal of personality and social psychology&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/mood-heuristics-influence-states-sensitivity-bias-park/246a98ae1e2d584fa7dae7efc5f25c76/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037/0022-3514.78.6.1005&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;78 6&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          1005-23\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:15},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The neurobiology of positive emotions&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Compared to the study of negative emotions such as fear, the neurobiology of positive emotional processes and the associated positive affect (PA) states has only recently received scientific attention. Biological theories conceptualize PA as being related to (i) signals indicating that bodies are returning to equilibrium among those studying homeostasis, (ii) utility estimation among those favoring neuroeconomic views, and (iii) approach and other instinctual behaviors among those cultivating neuroethological perspectives. Indeed, there are probably several distinct forms of positive affect, but all are closely related to ancient sub-neocortical limbic brain regions we share with other mammals. There is now a convergence of evidence to suggest that various regions of the limbic system, including especially ventral striatal dopamine systems are implemented in an anticipatory (appetitive) positive affective state. Dopamine independent mechanisms utilizing opiate and GABA receptors in the ventral striatum, amygdala and orbital frontal cortex are important in elaborating consummatory PA (i.e. sensory pleasure) states, and various neuropeptides mediate homeostatic satisfactions.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;J. Burgdorf&quot;,&quot;J. Panksepp&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2006,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Neuroscience &amp; Biobehavioral Reviews&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/neurobiology-emotions-burgdorf/eec9b7bfa4855b878ed63d3b78f87a91/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1016/j.neubiorev.2005.06.001&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;30&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;173-187&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:16},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;The Undoing Effect of Positive Emotions&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Positive emotions are hypothesized to undo the cardiovascular aftereffects of negative emotions. Study 1 tests this undoing effect. Participants (n = 170) experiencing anxiety-induced cardiovascular reactivity viewed a film that elicited (a) contentment, (b) amusement, (c) neutrality, or (d) sadness. Contentment-eliciting and amusing films produced faster cardiovascular recovery than neutral or sad films did. Participants in Study 2 (n = 185) viewed these same films following a neutral state. Results disconfirm the alternative explanation that the undoing effect reflects a simple replacement process. Findings are contextualized by Fredrickson&#x27;s broaden-and-build theory of positive emotions (B. L. Fredrickson, 1998).&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;B. Fredrickson&quot;,&quot;R. Mancuso&quot;,&quot;C. Branigan&quot;,&quot;M. Tugade&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2000,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Motivation and Emotion&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/undoing-effect-positive-emotions-fredrickson/08ce9254e79359b2a532072598063b33/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1023/A:1010796329158&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;24&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;237-258&quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:17},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Is valuing positive emotion associated with life satisfaction?&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;The experience of positive emotion is closely linked to subjective well-being. For this reason, campaigns aimed at promoting the value of positive emotion have become widespread. What is rarely considered are the cultural implications of this focus on happiness. Promoting positive emotions as important for \\&quot;the good life\\&quot; not only has implications for how individuals value these emotional states, but for how they believe others around them value these emotions also. Drawing on data from over 9,000 college students across 47 countries we examined whether individuals&#x27; life satisfaction is associated with living in contexts in which positive emotions are socially valued. The findings show that people report more life satisfaction in countries where positive emotions are highly valued and this is linked to an increased frequency of positive emotional experiences in these contexts. They also reveal, however, that increased life satisfaction in countries that place a premium on positive emotion is less evident for people who tend to experience less valued emotional states: people who experience many negative emotions, do not flourish to the same extent in these contexts. The findings demonstrate how the cultural value placed on certain emotion states may shape the relationship between emotional experiences and subjective well-being.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;B. Bastian&quot;,&quot;Peter Kuppens&quot;,&quot;Kim De Roover&quot;,&quot;E. Diener&quot;],&quot;paper_publish_year&quot;:2014,&quot;publication_journal_name&quot;:&quot;Emotion&quot;,&quot;consensus_paper_details_url&quot;:&quot;https://consensus.app/papers/valuing-emotion-associated-life-satisfaction-bastian/9d0d05c55acd5c39a42fcb4385157006/?utm_source=chatgpt&quot;,&quot;doi&quot;:&quot;10.1037/a0036466&quot;,&quot;volume&quot;:&quot;14 4&quot;,&quot;pages&quot;:&quot;\\n          639-45\\n        &quot;,&quot;search_result_number&quot;:18},{&quot;paper_title&quot;:&quot;Assessment of Intraindividual Variability in Positive and Negative Affect Using Latent State-Trait Model Analyses&quot;,&quot;abstract&quot;:&quot;Intraindividual variability in positive and negative affect was assessed by the positive affect (Contentment, Joy, Vigor, Love, and Excitement) and negative affect (Depression, Hostility, Anxiety, Agitation, and Social Anxiety) subscales of the state version of the Comprehensive Personality and Affect Scales (COPAS) during a 3-week period. Using the latent state-trait model analysis, which takes both intraindividual variability and interindividual difference into account by controlling measurement error, it was shown that the variability could be measured reliably by the scores of theCOPAS. In particular, a total of 56.9% to 63.5% and 48.2% to 60.6% of the reliable interindividual difference in positive and negative affect, respectively,was attributed to the intraindividual variability.&quot;,&quot;paper_authors&quot;:[&quot;Tomoyuki Yasuda&quot;,&quot;C. Lawrenz&quot;,&quot;R. V. Whitlock&quot;,&quot;B. Three hundred and ninety-eight undergraduate students from Singapore participated in this study. First, states-of-mind ratio and positive automatic thoughts were positively correlated with life satisfaction and happiness, and negatively correlated with anxiety, depression, and anger. In contrast, negative automatic thoughts were positively correlated with anxiety, depression, and anger, and negatively correlated with life satisfaction and happiness. Second, the BSOM categories based depression-related automatic thoughts was able to significantly differentiate among levels of depression, happiness, life satisfaction, anxiety, and anger in ANOVA and in terms of variance accounted for as indicated by partial Eta squared. Third, the BSOM ratio was the best predictor for happiness and life satisfaction and second best predictor for depression, anxiety, and anger in terms of variance accounted for as indicated by adjusted R2, in comparison to the negative cognition model and positive cognition model. Fourth, both ANOVA results and multiple regression results showed that there is cognitive content-specificity for the BSOM based on depression-related automatic thoughts. {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1710529697.987587, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Here&#x27;s a summary of the findings and critical ideas from the studies and sources listed:\n\n1. **Fredrickson (1998)**: This study presents the broaden-and-build theory, suggesting that positive emotions like joy, interest, contentment, and love expand an individual&#x27;s attention and cognition, leading to increased creativity and problem-solving capabilities. These emotions also build lasting personal resources, contributing to emotional well-being and resilience.\n\n2. **Salovey et al. (2000)**: The research highlights the connection between positive emotional states and physical health. Positive emotions can improve health through various pathways, including direct physiological effects on the immune system, fostering healthier behaviors, and improving social support.\n\n3. **Campos et al. (2013)**: This study explores the distinct core relational themes and expressive displays associated with different positive emotions. It suggests that while all positive emotions share high positive valence, they differ significantly in their core relational themes and facial/body expressions.\n\n4. **Fredrickson (2004)**: The paper expands on the broaden-and-build theory, explaining how positive emotions broaden an individual\u2019s thought-action repertoire and build enduring resources, which in turn enhance coping mechanisms and overall well-being.\n\n5. **McKenzie (2016)**: The article argues for a distinction between happiness (positive affect) and contentment (positive reflection), proposing that happiness is associated with pleasurable experiences, while contentment stems from a fulfilling relationship with oneself and society.\n\n6. **Cohn et al. (2009)**: The authors demonstrate that daily positive emotions increase life satisfaction and resilience, underscoring the idea that in-the-moment positive emotions, rather than general positive evaluations of one\u2019s life, are crucial for happiness and well-being.\n\n7. **Sauter &amp; Scott (2007)**: This research suggests that different positive emotions have distinct vocal expressions and that these unique emotional sounds can be accurately recognized and differentiated by others, highlighting the complexity of positive emotional expression.\n\n8. **Salovey et al. (2000)** (second entry): This is a duplicate of item 2, reinforcing the relationship between positive emotional states and better physical health through multiple mechanisms.\n\n9. **Shiota, Campos, &amp; Keltner (2003)**: The study investigates the specific facial and upper-body displays associated with different positive emotions and finds distinct expressions for emotions such as awe, amusement, and pride, challenging the idea that there is only one facial expression for positive affect (the Duchenne smile).\n\n10. **Friedman, Schwartz, &amp; Haaga (2002)**: This study challenges the notion that there can be too much happiness. It found no evidence of dysfunction among individuals with very high positive emotion ratios, suggesting that high levels of happiness are not necessarily detrimental.\n\nEach of these studies contributes to a broader understanding of positive emotions, their distinctions, and their impacts on physical health, psychological well-being, and social interactions. They collectively underscore the importance of fostering positive emotions for enhancing life satisfaction, resilience, and overall well-being."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [100260]}, "citations": [], "gizmo_id": "g-bo0FiWLY7", "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4-gizmo", "pad": "AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA", "parent_id": "aaa27c7c-a605-4f30-8f97-71a51a5f0ee3", "request_id": "864ec9d33ecd374e-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "aaa27c7c-a605-4f30-8f97-71a51a5f0ee3", "children": ["aaa2acbb-c6c1-44c6-844b-8e4a67349850"]}, "aaa2acbb-c6c1-44c6-844b-8e4a67349850": {"id": "aaa2acbb-c6c1-44c6-844b-8e4a67349850", "message": {"id": "aaa2acbb-c6c1-44c6-844b-8e4a67349850", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1710530291.168403, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["The Science of Feeling Good\n\nEveryone wants to feel good. Pleasure is a key aspect of life, and human beings seek out what gives them pleasure. We are naturally attracted to what makes us feel good. \n\n\nTake my favorite food, cheese, for instance. Scientific studies have revealed that cheese contains a chemical called casein, known for its ability to induce feelings of pleasure. This chemical is so powerful that it triggers the same brain regions as opioids, potentially leading to addictive behaviors. Yet, my intention is not addiction, but rather, to experience the joy that comes from feeling good. Hence, my love for cheese. \n\nBut it&#x27;s not just about the cheese. I often find myself pondering\u2014what truly brings us that feeling of goodness? What are the essential elements that guarantee a delightful human experience? Is it all about chemical receptors in the brain? Is happiness just a pill or does it encompass something deeper? Is the true science of feeling good science or just a philosophy or attitude that keeps the human mood in optimal condition? Let\u2019s explore what we know about the science of feeling good and its intersections with behavioral philosophy and psychology to get the bottom of the mystery humans have pondered and sought for millennia: How to feel good all the time and lead a happy and meaningful life. \n\nSee, happiness isn\u2019t only the joy of chewing on a cube of sharp creamy cheesy cheddar. It is also the enduring feeling of goodness that comes from the sense that you\u2019re in a good place in your life right now. It\u2019s the feeling of goodness that comes from dwelling in a positive state. \n\nWhat We Know So Far:\nPositive states such as contentment, general happiness, and joy\n--------\n\nCan you use these studies to finish up this blog post above and end with a list of 5 science-supported methods of using immediate happiness-inducing stimuli to build long-lasting positive states such  as contentment, good physical and mental health, purposefulness, direction, etc., and spend particular time discussing the distinctions sited in McKenzie (2016)"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"request_id": "864ed90e18a0a25c-FCO", "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "4ec0b408-acec-4ed6-9ffd-29b7d2d0c71f", "children": ["60efbf63-309a-4c43-972d-469c6d107220"]}, "60efbf63-309a-4c43-972d-469c6d107220": {"id": "60efbf63-309a-4c43-972d-469c6d107220", "message": {"id": "60efbf63-309a-4c43-972d-469c6d107220", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1710530331.67054, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["Building on our understanding of the science of feeling good, we know that while the immediate pleasure from experiences like enjoying cheese taps into our brain&#x27;s reward system, true happiness extends far beyond these transient moments of joy. It encompasses enduring states of contentment, health, purposefulness, and direction in life.\n\nFrom the research findings summarized earlier:\n\n1. **Broaden-and-Build Theory (Fredrickson, 1998 &amp; 2004)**: This theory suggests that experiencing positive emotions broadens one&#x27;s awareness and encourages novel, varied, and exploratory thoughts and actions. Over time, this leads to building enduring personal resources, ranging from physical and social resources to intellectual and psychological capacities.\n\n2. **Positive Emotions and Health (Salovey et al., 2000)**: Positive emotional states not only enhance mental health but are also linked to physical well-being. They can lead to healthier lifestyles and may even have direct physiological benefits, such as on the immune system.\n\n3. **Distinctions of Positive Emotions (Campos et al., 2013)**: Different positive emotions serve different functions and lead to distinct types of satisfaction and well-being. For example, joy might lead to playing and creativity, while contentment might encourage reflection and appreciation.\n\n4. **Sociology of Happiness (McKenzie, 2016)**: Happiness (positive affect) and contentment (positive reflection) are distinguished. While happiness can be fleeting and dependent on external factors, contentment is more about a fulfilling relationship with oneself and society. This distinction is crucial as it underscores the different pathways through which we can cultivate a good life: one through seeking pleasurable experiences and the other through fostering a deep sense of satisfaction with life.\n\n5. **Expression and Recognition of Emotions (Sauter &amp; Scott, 2007; Shiota et al., 2003)**: The way we express and recognize different positive emotions can affect our relationships and social interactions, further influencing our overall well-being.\n\nBuilding on these insights, here are five science-supported methods to use immediate happiness-inducing stimuli to build long-lasting positive states:\n\n1. **Cultivate a Variety of Positive Emotions**: Engage in activities that foster a range of positive emotions. For example, engage in playful activities to experience joy, immerse yourself in nature to feel awe, and practice gratitude to feel more content. Diversifying your emotional experiences can broaden your thought-action repertoires and build lasting resources.\n\n2. **Practice Mindfulness and Reflection**: Spend time in self-reflection to understand what brings you genuine contentment, beyond mere fleeting pleasure. Mindfulness practices can help you become more aware of your internal states, leading to a deeper sense of contentment.\n\n3. **Build and Maintain Social Connections**: Foster relationships that provide support, validation, and love. Strong social ties can lead to enduring feelings of love and belonging, key components of long-term well-being.\n\n4. **Set and Pursue Purposeful Goals**: Having clear goals and a sense of direction can lead to feelings of success and accomplishment. Choose goals that are aligned with your values and interests to ensure they contribute to your overall sense of purpose and contentment.\n\n5. **Adopt Healthy Lifestyle Habits**: Regular physical activity, a balanced diet, and adequate sleep can improve your mood and energy levels, leading to more frequent and intense experiences of positive emotions, which over time contribute to lasting well-being.\n\nBy understanding the distinctions between fleeting happiness and deeper contentment, as highlighted by McKenzie (2016), we can strive not just for momentary pleasures but for a fulfilling and meaningful life. It&#x27;s about balancing the joy of immediate pleasures with activities and relationships that provide a profound sense of satisfaction and belonging. This comprehensive approach can guide us towards a life that is not only happy but also rich, purposeful, and rewarding."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [100260]}, "citations": [], "gizmo_id": "g-bo0FiWLY7", "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4-gizmo", "pad": "AAAAA", "parent_id": "aaa2acbb-c6c1-44c6-844b-8e4a67349850", "request_id": "864ed90e18a0a25c-FCO", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "aaa2acbb-c6c1-44c6-844b-8e4a67349850", "children": ["aaa2deb4-8e7a-44d3-bbfc-3f801d618a89"]}, "aaa2deb4-8e7a-44d3-bbfc-3f801d618a89": {"id": "aaa2deb4-8e7a-44d3-bbfc-3f801d618a89", "message": {"id": "aaa2deb4-8e7a-44d3-bbfc-3f801d618a89", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1710530455.254617, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["write 3 paragraphs that summarize the current knowledge and trends in the science of feeling good"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"request_id": "864edd0f79030d80-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "60efbf63-309a-4c43-972d-469c6d107220", "children": ["f3b02f87-d77f-4fcc-bad0-bf48f6ca1c17"]}, "f3b02f87-d77f-4fcc-bad0-bf48f6ca1c17": {"id": "f3b02f87-d77f-4fcc-bad0-bf48f6ca1c17", "message": {"id": "f3b02f87-d77f-4fcc-bad0-bf48f6ca1c17", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1710530483.248044, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["The science of feeling good, an area deeply explored within positive psychology, illuminates the multifaceted nature of happiness and well-being. Central to this field is the distinction between transient pleasures and enduring states of contentment, which has been crucially outlined in recent studies and theories. The broaden-and-build theory by Fredrickson emphasizes that positive emotions extend beyond fleeting moments, serving to expand our cognitive, social, and emotional resources, which in turn foster resilience and long-term well-being. Moreover, findings by Salovey et al. demonstrate the significant impact of positive emotional states on physical health, suggesting a bi-directional relationship between psychological well-being and physiological health. This body of work suggests that while immediate joy from stimuli like food or entertainment is valid, true, lasting happiness encompasses deeper, more sustained states such as contentment, purposefulness, and social connection.\n\nResearch has also delved into the nuances of positive emotions, highlighting the diversity and specificity of feelings such as joy, pride, gratitude, and love. Studies by Campos et al. and others underline that each positive emotion carries unique expressions and functions, contributing differently to our overall well-being. This specificity underscores the importance of cultivating a broad range of positive emotions to enhance various aspects of personal and social life. Furthermore, the work of McKenzie brings a sociological perspective, distinguishing between happiness as an immediate, affective experience and contentment as a reflective, evaluative state. This distinction is critical as it suggests different paths to achieving a fulfilling life: one through the pursuit of enjoyable experiences and the other through the development of a satisfying life narrative and social integration.\n\nIn light of these insights, current trends in the science of feeling good are moving towards a more holistic understanding of well-being, integrating emotional, cognitive, social, and physiological components. This comprehensive approach advocates for a balanced life that values both the pursuit of pleasure and the cultivation of meaningful relationships, purposeful goals, and a healthy lifestyle. As research continues to unfold, it is increasingly clear that long-term happiness and well-being are complex, multi-dimensional constructs that require intentional effort and a broad strategy encompassing various aspects of human experience. The ongoing exploration in this field continues to offer valuable insights into how individuals can navigate the pursuit of happiness in an increasingly complex and changing world."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [100260]}, "citations": [], "gizmo_id": "g-bo0FiWLY7", "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4-gizmo", "pad": "AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA", "parent_id": "aaa2deb4-8e7a-44d3-bbfc-3f801d618a89", "request_id": "864edd0f79030d80-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "aaa2deb4-8e7a-44d3-bbfc-3f801d618a89", "children": ["aaa2d9c6-cfa0-4cc6-83de-a86e1c10b828"]}, "aaa2d9c6-cfa0-4cc6-83de-a86e1c10b828": {"id": "aaa2d9c6-cfa0-4cc6-83de-a86e1c10b828", "message": {"id": "aaa2d9c6-cfa0-4cc6-83de-a86e1c10b828", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1710530820.813628, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["I&#x27;d like to read the full text of this article"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"targeted_reply": "McKenzie, J. They reuse hot air to dry clothes, which makes them more environmentally friendly and cost-effective in the long run, although they might be more expensive upfront. If you&#x27;re looking for a classic vented dryer, which uses a hose to vent out moisture and hot air, you might not specifically search for &quot;pompa di calore.&quot; Instead, you might look for terms like &quot;asciugatrice a scarico&quot; (vented dryer) or &quot;asciugatrice a condensazione&quot; (condenser dryer), depending on the type you want. \n\nIf you prefer the traditional, less energy-efficient type similar to many found in the U.S., you might lean towards a &quot;condenser&quot; or &quot;vented&quot; machine rather than one advertised with a &quot;pompa di calore.&quot; But if you&#x27;re open to newer, more energy-efficient technology, then an &quot;asciugatrice a pompa di calore&quot; would be a good choice."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [100260]}, "citations": [], "gizmo_id": null, "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4", "parent_id": "aaa2051c-725d-449b-8af0-f67509ba719e", "request_id": "85fc2aa5a8cb77fc-FCO", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "aaa2051c-725d-449b-8af0-f67509ba719e", "children": ["aaa22356-1d06-471b-a1ed-22ce3112586f"]}, "aaa22356-1d06-471b-a1ed-22ce3112586f": {"id": "aaa22356-1d06-471b-a1ed-22ce3112586f", "message": {"id": "aaa22356-1d06-471b-a1ed-22ce3112586f", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1709784288.994616, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["but how much longer on average do drying times increase for pompa di calore versus the classic American vented tumble dryer? These heat pump systems are different from the traditional vented drying systems commonly used in the US. The European style machines are typically more compact and energy-efficient due to this technology.\n\nHeat pump dryers in these combo units work by using a closed-loop heat exchange system to recirculate hot air within the drum, removing moisture from the clothes without venting hot air outside. This makes them more energy-efficient but also results in longer drying times compared to standard, vented dryers. This is a key feature of many European-style washer/dryer combos and a reason for their growing popularity in environments where space is limited and energy efficiency is valued, such as apartments or homes without easy external venting options."]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": true, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [100260]}, "citations": [], "gizmo_id": null, "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4", "parent_id": "aaa25e39-db4a-4a80-a45f-12a5c74a7bce", "request_id": "8607cb4f19cb74e2-FCO", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "aaa25e39-db4a-4a80-a45f-12a5c74a7bce", "children": ["aaa2a900-9084-44ce-9915-43f4f170c18e"]}, "aaa2a900-9084-44ce-9915-43f4f170c18e": {"id": "aaa2a900-9084-44ce-9915-43f4f170c18e", "message": {"id": "aaa2a900-9084-44ce-9915-43f4f170c18e", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1709785354.333306, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["a friend told me once, who use the euro style washer that his clothes never really felt dry. This is due to several factors:\n\n1. **Combined functionality**: Combos are both washing and drying in the same drum, which can lead to less effective drying compared to dedicated dryers.\n\n2. **Condenser drying**: Earlier models often used condenser drying rather than heat pump technology. In condenser dryers, the moisture is condensed into water and drained away, but this process is less energy-efficient and can be less effective in very humid conditions.\n\n3. **Load size and overloading**: Combos typically have smaller capacities than standalone machines. Overloading the machine can significantly reduce drying effectiveness, leaving clothes feeling damp.\n\n4. **Environmental factors**: The ambient air in colder, more humid climates like Minnesota can affect the drying efficiency of condenser and heat pump dryers alike.\n\nSince 2007, however, there have been significant improvements in washer/dryer combo technologies, including more efficient and effective heat pump (pompa di calore) systems. Guidelines for finding valid Wolfram Language interpretations of Entities, etc. \nL2: \nL3: If you need to write Wolfram Language code involving Entity or EntityClass expressions, NEVER assume that you can retrieve or deduce correct identifiers for entities, properties, etc. from your existing training. \nL4: \nL5: When writing code that requires retrieval of entity-property data from the Wolfram Knowledgebase, ALWAYS use chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.getSemanticInterpretationAPI first, with a simplified natural language input. This function can find Wolfram Language interpretations of\nL6: - Entities (examples: Empire State Building, caffeine, Taylor Swift)\nL7: - Well-defined, named EntityClasses (examples: UN countries, lanthanide elements, skyscrapers)\nL8: - Entity + EntityProperty expressions (examples: population of France, mass of Pluto, Asian population of San Francisco)\nL9: - Entity lookups (examples: 5 tallest buildings in Beijing, cities larger than 10M people, books written by Stephen King)\nL10: - Note that getSemanticInterpretation may be able to interpret quite complex entity-related inputs, involving both filters and requests for properties for example &quot;release dates of highest grossing movies in the 1970s directed by Steven Spielberg&quot;.\nL11: \nL12: To find the correct name of a specific entity, entity class, or property in a specific Wolfram Entity type, you may use the following, providing the type and a natural-language, non-camelcase name or phrase:\nL13:    chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.findEntityAPI\nL14:    chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.findEntityClassAPI\nL15:    chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.findPropertyAPI\nL16: \nL17: \nL18: ## Guidelines for using Entity data with chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.getWolframCloudResults\nL19: - A list of all EntityTypes may be retrieved with &quot;EntityValue[]&quot;.\nL20: - You may also retrieve all properties for a given type with:\nL21: EntityProperties[&quot;{{entity type}}&quot;].\nL22: - Prefer direct use of entities of a given type to their corresponding typeData function (e.g., prefer `Entity[\\&quot;Element\\&quot;,\\&quot;Gold\\&quot;][\\&quot;AtomicNumber\\&quot;]` to `ElementData[\\&quot;Gold\\&quot;,\\&quot;AtomicNumber\\&quot;]`).\nL23: - Prefer using &quot;Association&quot; in the third argument of any EntityValue calls. This will return a key-value association with Entities as keys. You generally should not request the &quot;Name&quot; property in such an Association, since it is present in the Keys.\nL24: - Wolfram Language visualization and other functions are designed to understand this data structure and automatically retrieve name, date, geographic, etc. information as needed from the associated entities. \nL25: - The Wolfram Cloud will automatically and efficiently batch requests for data; when possible, use lists of entities and/or properties in EntityValue calls instead of mapping over lists. For example, this:\nL26:    EntityValue[{Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;France&quot;], Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;Germany&quot;], Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;Spain&quot;]}, &quot;Population&quot;, &quot;Association&quot;]\nL27: is better than this:\nL28:    EntityValue[#, &quot;Population&quot;] &amp; /@ {Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;France&quot;], Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;Germany&quot;], Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;Spain&quot;]}\nL29: # \u30101\u2020getWolframAlphaResults query guidelines.txt\u2020file-Bvv5cOuKLkrkrKmc7BMrtF9X\u3011\nL30: getWolframAlphaResults guidelines:\nL31: - Translate non-English queries before sending, then respond in the language the user&#x27;s query was written in.\nL32: - Convert inputs to simplified keyword queries whenever possible (e.g. convert &quot;how many people live in France&quot; to &quot;France population&quot;).\nL33: - ALWAYS use this exponent notation: `6*10^14`, NEVER `6e14`.\nL34: - Use ONLY single-letter variable names, with or without integer subscript (e.g., n, n1, n_1).\nL35: - Use named physical constants (e.g., &#x27;speed of light&#x27;) without numerical substitution.\nL36: - Include a space between compound units (e.g., &quot;\\[CapitalOmega] m&quot; for &quot;ohm*meter&quot;).\nL37: - To solve for a variable in an equation with units, consider solving a corresponding equation without units; exclude counting units (e.g., books), include genuine units (e.g., kg).\nL38: - If data for multiple properties is needed, make separate calls for each property.\nL39: - If Wolfram provides multiple &#x27;Assumptions&#x27; for a query, choose the more relevant one(s) without explaining the initial result. If you are unsure, ask the user to choose. Then Re-send the exact same &#x27;input&#x27; with NO modifications, and add the &#x27;assumption&#x27; parameter, formatted as a list, with the relevant values.\nL40: - If you receive a 501 error and Wolfram Alpha provides &quot;Things to try instead&quot;, review those suggestions and try one or more of them, *exactly* as provided by the API, if they might provide a good answer.\nL41: - ONLY simplify or rephrase the initial query if a more relevant &#x27;Assumption&#x27; or other input suggestions are not provided.\nL42: # \u30102\u2020getWolframCloudResults query guidelines.txt\u2020file-jAt577A8QpOTIErsx25lbYTr\u3011\nL43: getWolframCloudResults guidelines:\nL44: - Always explain your chain of thought before writing any code. When composing your explanation, follow all the guidelines here regarding variable names, etc. even in your written response.\nL45: - Always think about what Wolfram Language functions may be most relevant and efficient for solving a given problem.\nL46: - The Import[] function is supported by this function, allowing you to import data from the web.\nL47: - Before writing any code requiring access to Entity, EntityProperty, EntityClass, etc. data, read the file &quot;Wolfram Entity Data&quot;\nL48: - Before writing any code involving Food and nutrition data, read the file &quot;Wolfram Food Data&quot;\nL49: - getWolframCloudResults will render and return URLs you can use to display in your responses; you do not need to Export visualizations as images or do any other kind of processing.\nL50: - If getWolframCloudResults return data-related fields in addition to the default &quot;output&quot; such as outputLength, firstOutputValue, etc., your response should focus on those additional fields and encourage the user to define further steps for analysis. In these cases, if &quot;output&quot; is an image URL it is likely to be an image of a truncated list or dataset, and not helpful to the user.\nL51: - Do not specify ColorFunction[], PlotTheme[] or related options in visualization code unless requested by the user. The Wolfram Language has sensible default values.\nL52: - Variable names must ONLY be lowercase letters or camelCase names. NEVER use uppercase single letters, snake_case names, or names containing any non-alphanumeric character, especially underscores. Examples: {{invalid name -&gt; valid name}, {C -&gt; c}, {county_population -&gt; countyPopulation}, {LCM_T1 -&gt; lcmT1}}.\nL53: - Use ONLY double quotes around all strings, including plot labels, etc. (e.g., `PlotLegends -&gt; {\\&quot;sin(x)\\&quot;, \\&quot;cos(x)\\&quot;, \\&quot;tan(x)\\&quot;}`).\nL54: - Avoid use of QuantityMagnitude.\nL55: - Apply Evaluate to complex expressions like integrals before plotting (e.g., `Plot[Evaluate[Integrate[...]]]`).\nL56: - Remove all comments and formatting from code passed to the \\&quot;input\\&quot; parameter; for example: instead of `square[x_] := Module[{result},\\\\n  result = x^2 (* Calculate the square *)\\\\n]`, send `square[x_]:=Module[{result},result=x^2]`.\nL57: # \u30103\u2020Wolfram Food Data.txt\u2020file-kI98s2K5Nx9fhlHbuT7gYZEn\u3011\nL58: - In general, to find nutrition for a food or a list of foods, use the Wolfram Resource Function &quot;NutritionReport&quot; with the output format &quot;ASCIITable&quot;. Always try this Wolfram Language approach before attempting a comparable query using Wolfram Alpha. Example:\nL59:      -- ResourceFunction[&quot;NutritionReport&quot;][&quot;100g rice\\n8oz chicken\\n1 glass wine&quot;,&quot;ASCIITable&quot;]\nL60: \nL61: - If specific properties are asked for, find the EntityProperty associated with the requested data using Interpreter and include it using the &quot;NutritionProperties&quot; option. Examples:\nL62:      -- ResourceFunction[&quot;NutritionReport&quot;][&quot;100g rice\\n8oz chicken\\n1 glass wine&quot;,&quot;ASCIITable&quot;,&quot;NutritionProperties&quot;-&gt;{EntityProperty[&quot;Food&quot;, &quot;AbsoluteTotalCaloriesContent&quot;], EntityProperty[&quot;Food&quot;, &quot;AbsoluteTotalProteinContent&quot;]}]\nL63:      -- For user queries about nutrition in a &#x27;piece&#x27;, &#x27;slice&#x27;, &#x27;scoop&#x27;, &#x27;stick&#x27;, &#x27;clove&#x27;, &#x27;plate&#x27;, &#x27;can&#x27; of a food or &#x27;bottle&#x27;, &#x27;glass&#x27; of a drink, FIRST go get the typical weight in grams for EACH of the foods or typical weight in mL for EACH of the drinks from your general knowledge. Do the same for sizes &#x27;small&#x27;,&#x27;medium&#x27;,&#x27;large&#x27;. Use them in your NutritionReport resource function input. Example:\nL64:      -- ResourceFunction[&quot;NutritionReport&quot;][&quot;2*26g bread\\n1*68g ice cream\\n3*28g ham\\n1*14g bacon\\n2*148g pizza\\n1*750mL wine&quot;,&quot;ASCIITable&quot;]\nL65:      -- If the information for a drink is not available in mL, convert it to grams. Example: convert 50mL champagne to 50g champagne.\nL66:      -- Disregard the preparation adjectives in ingredient names, such as &#x27;chopped&#x27;, &#x27;diced&#x27;, &#x27;sliced&#x27;, &#x27;scrambled&#x27;.\nL67:      -- When performing these actions, you do not need to explain every step of the process before sending calculations to Wolfram.\nVisible: 0% - 100%", "summary": null, "assets": [], "tether_id": null}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 0.0, "metadata": {"_cite_metadata": {"citation_format": {"name": "tether_og", "regex": "\u3010(\\d+)(?::(\\d+))?\u2020([^\u2020\u3010\u3011]*)[^\u3010\u3011]*?\u3011"}, "metadata_list": [{"type": "file", "name": "Wolfram Entity Data.txt", "id": "file-JSCY7TYYTEkJTsQOcqvvKiVC", "source": "my_files", "text": "\nL1: ## Guidelines for finding valid Wolfram Language interpretations of Entities, etc. \nL2: \nL3: If you need to write Wolfram Language code involving Entity or EntityClass expressions, NEVER assume that you can retrieve or deduce correct identifiers for entities, properties, etc. from your existing training. \nL4: \nL5: When writing code that requires retrieval of entity-property data from the Wolfram Knowledgebase, ALWAYS use chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.getSemanticInterpretationAPI first, with a simplified natural language input. This function can find Wolfram Language interpretations of\nL6: - Entities (examples: Empire State Building, caffeine, Taylor Swift)\nL7: - Well-defined, named EntityClasses (examples: UN countries, lanthanide elements, skyscrapers)\nL8: - Entity + EntityProperty expressions (examples: population of France, mass of Pluto, Asian population of San Francisco)\nL9: - Entity lookups (examples: 5 tallest buildings in Beijing, cities larger than 10M people, books written by Stephen King)\nL10: - Note that getSemanticInterpretation may be able to interpret quite complex entity-related inputs, involving both filters and requests for properties for example &quot;release dates of highest grossing movies in the 1970s directed by Steven Spielberg&quot;.\nL11: \nL12: To find the correct name of a specific entity, entity class, or property in a specific Wolfram Entity type, you may use the following, providing the type and a natural-language, non-camelcase name or phrase:\nL13:    chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.findEntityAPI\nL14:    chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.findEntityClassAPI\nL15:    chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.findPropertyAPI\nL16: \nL17: \nL18: ## Guidelines for using Entity data with chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.getWolframCloudResults\nL19: - A list of all EntityTypes may be retrieved with &quot;EntityValue[]&quot;.\nL20: - You may also retrieve all properties for a given type with:\nL21: EntityProperties[&quot;{{entity type}}&quot;].\nL22: - Prefer direct use of entities of a given type to their corresponding typeData function (e.g., prefer `Entity[\\&quot;Element\\&quot;,\\&quot;Gold\\&quot;][\\&quot;AtomicNumber\\&quot;]` to `ElementData[\\&quot;Gold\\&quot;,\\&quot;AtomicNumber\\&quot;]`).\nL23: - Prefer using &quot;Association&quot; in the third argument of any EntityValue calls. Examples:\nL62:      -- ResourceFunction[&quot;NutritionReport&quot;][&quot;100g rice\\n8oz chicken\\n1 glass wine&quot;,&quot;ASCIITable&quot;,&quot;NutritionProperties&quot;-&gt;{EntityProperty[&quot;Food&quot;, &quot;AbsoluteTotalCaloriesContent&quot;], EntityProperty[&quot;Food&quot;, &quot;AbsoluteTotalProteinContent&quot;]}]\nL63:      -- For user queries about nutrition in a &#x27;piece&#x27;, &#x27;slice&#x27;, &#x27;scoop&#x27;, &#x27;stick&#x27;, &#x27;clove&#x27;, &#x27;plate&#x27;, &#x27;can&#x27; of a food or &#x27;bottle&#x27;, &#x27;glass&#x27; of a drink, FIRST go get the typical weight in grams for EACH of the foods or typical weight in mL for EACH of the drinks from your general knowledge. Do the same for sizes &#x27;small&#x27;,&#x27;medium&#x27;,&#x27;large&#x27;. Use them in your NutritionReport resource function input. Example:\nL64:      -- ResourceFunction[&quot;NutritionReport&quot;][&quot;2*26g bread\\n1*68g ice cream\\n3*28g ham\\n1*14g bacon\\n2*148g pizza\\n1*750mL wine&quot;,&quot;ASCIITable&quot;]\nL65:      -- If the information for a drink is not available in mL, convert it to grams. Example: convert 50mL champagne to 50g champagne.\nL66:      -- Disregard the preparation adjectives in ingredient names, such as &#x27;chopped&#x27;, &#x27;diced&#x27;, &#x27;sliced&#x27;, &#x27;scrambled&#x27;.\nL67:      -- When performing these actions, you do not need to explain every step of the process before sending calculations to Wolfram.\nVisible: 0% - 100%", "extra": null}],
