Data.txt\u2020file-JSCY7TYYTEkJTsQOcqvvKiVC\u3011\nL1: ## Guidelines for finding valid Wolfram Language interpretations of Entities, etc. \nL2: \nL3: If you need to write Wolfram Language code involving Entity or EntityClass expressions, NEVER assume that you can retrieve or deduce correct identifiers for entities, properties, etc. from your existing training. \nL4: \nL5: When writing code that requires retrieval of entity-property data from the Wolfram Knowledgebase, ALWAYS use chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.getSemanticInterpretationAPI first, with a simplified natural language input. This function can find Wolfram Language interpretations of\nL6: - Entities (examples: Empire State Building, caffeine, Taylor Swift)\nL7: - Well-defined, named EntityClasses (examples: UN countries, lanthanide elements, skyscrapers)\nL8: - Entity + EntityProperty expressions (examples: population of France, mass of Pluto, Asian population of San Francisco)\nL9: - Entity lookups (examples: 5 tallest buildings in Beijing, cities larger than 10M people, books written by Stephen King)\nL10: - Note that getSemanticInterpretation may be able to interpret quite complex entity-related inputs, involving both filters and requests for properties for example &quot;release dates of highest grossing movies in the 1970s directed by Steven Spielberg&quot;.\nL11: \nL12: To find the correct name of a specific entity, entity class, or property in a specific Wolfram Entity type, you may use the following, providing the type and a natural-language, non-camelcase name or phrase:\nL13:    chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.findEntityAPI\nL14:    chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.findEntityClassAPI\nL15:    chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.findPropertyAPI\nL16: \nL17: \nL18: ## Guidelines for using Entity data with chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.getWolframCloudResults\nL19: - A list of all EntityTypes may be retrieved with &quot;EntityValue[]&quot;.\nL20: - You may also retrieve all properties for a given type with:\nL21: EntityProperties[&quot;{{entity type}}&quot;].\nL22: - Prefer direct use of entities of a given type to their corresponding typeData function (e.g., prefer `Entity[\\&quot;Element\\&quot;,\\&quot;Gold\\&quot;][\\&quot;AtomicNumber\\&quot;]` to `ElementData[\\&quot;Gold\\&quot;,\\&quot;AtomicNumber\\&quot;]`).\nL23: - Prefer using &quot;Association&quot; in the third argument of any EntityValue calls. This will return a key-value association with Entities as keys. You generally should not request the &quot;Name&quot; property in such an Association, since it is present in the Keys.\nL24: - Wolfram Language visualization and other functions are designed to understand this data structure and automatically retrieve name, date, geographic, etc. information as needed from the associated entities. \nL25: - The Wolfram Cloud will automatically and efficiently batch requests for data; when possible, use lists of entities and/or properties in EntityValue calls instead of mapping over lists. For example, this:\nL26:    EntityValue[{Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;France&quot;], Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;Germany&quot;], Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;Spain&quot;]}, &quot;Population&quot;, &quot;Association&quot;]\nL27: is better than this:\nL28:    EntityValue[#, &quot;Population&quot;] &amp; /@ {Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;France&quot;], Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;Germany&quot;], Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;Spain&quot;]}\nL29: # \u30101\u2020getWolframCloudResults query guidelines.txt\u2020file-jAt577A8QpOTIErsx25lbYTr\u3011\nL30: getWolframCloudResults guidelines:\nL31: - Always explain your chain of thought before writing any code. When composing your explanation, follow all the guidelines here regarding variable names, etc. even in your written response.\nL32: - Always think about what Wolfram Language functions may be most relevant and efficient for solving a given problem.\nL33: - The Import[] function is supported by this function, allowing you to import data from the web.\nL34: - Before writing any code requiring access to Entity, EntityProperty, EntityClass, etc. data, read the file &quot;Wolfram Entity Data&quot;\nL35: - Before writing any code involving Food and nutrition data, read the file &quot;Wolfram Food Data&quot;\nL36: - getWolframCloudResults will render and return URLs you can use to display in your responses; you do not need to Export visualizations as images or do any other kind of processing.\nL37: - If getWolframCloudResults return data-related fields in addition to the default &quot;output&quot; such as outputLength, firstOutputValue, etc., your response should focus on those additional fields and encourage the user to define further steps for analysis. In these cases, if &quot;output&quot; is an image URL it is likely to be an image of a truncated list or dataset, and not helpful to the user.\nL38: - Do not specify ColorFunction[], PlotTheme[] or related options in visualization code unless requested by the user. The Wolfram Language has sensible default values.\nL39: - Variable names must ONLY be lowercase letters or camelCase names. NEVER use uppercase single letters, snake_case names, or names containing any non-alphanumeric character, especially underscores. Examples: {{invalid name -&gt; valid name}, {C -&gt; c}, {county_population -&gt; countyPopulation}, {LCM_T1 -&gt; lcmT1}}.\nL40: - Use ONLY double quotes around all strings, including plot labels, etc. (e.g., `PlotLegends -&gt; {\\&quot;sin(x)\\&quot;, \\&quot;cos(x)\\&quot;, \\&quot;tan(x)\\&quot;}`).\nL41: - Avoid use of QuantityMagnitude.\nL42: - Apply Evaluate to complex expressions like integrals before plotting (e.g., `Plot[Evaluate[Integrate[...]]]`).\nL43: - Remove all comments and formatting from code passed to the \\&quot;input\\&quot; parameter; for example: instead of `square[x_] := Module[{result},\\\\n  result = x^2 (* Calculate the square *)\\\\n]`, send `square[x_]:=Module[{result},result=x^2]`.\nL44: # \u30102\u2020getWolframAlphaResults query guidelines.txt\u2020file-Bvv5cOuKLkrkrKmc7BMrtF9X\u3011\nL45: getWolframAlphaResults guidelines:\nL46: - Translate non-English queries before sending, then respond in the language the user&#x27;s query was written in.\nL47: - Convert inputs to simplified keyword queries whenever possible (e.g. convert &quot;how many people live in France&quot; to &quot;France population&quot;).\nL48: - ALWAYS use this exponent notation: `6*10^14`, NEVER `6e14`.\nL49: - Use ONLY single-letter variable names, with or without integer subscript (e.g., n, n1, n_1).\nL50: - Use named physical constants (e.g., &#x27;speed of light&#x27;) without numerical substitution.\nL51: - Include a space between compound units (e.g., &quot;\\[CapitalOmega] m&quot; for &quot;ohm*meter&quot;).\nL52: - To solve for a variable in an equation with units, consider solving a corresponding equation without units; exclude counting units (e.g., books), include genuine units (e.g., kg).\nL53: - If data for multiple properties is needed, make separate calls for each property.\nL54: - If Wolfram provides multiple &#x27;Assumptions&#x27; for a query, choose the more relevant one(s) without explaining the initial result. If you are unsure, ask the user to choose. Then Re-send the exact same &#x27;input&#x27; with NO modifications, and add the &#x27;assumption&#x27; parameter, formatted as a list, with the relevant values.\nL55: - If you receive a 501 error and Wolfram Alpha provides &quot;Things to try instead&quot;, review those suggestions and try one or more of them, *exactly* as provided by the API, if they might provide a good answer.\nL56: - ONLY simplify or rephrase the initial query if a more relevant &#x27;Assumption&#x27; or other input suggestions are not provided.\nL57: # \u30103\u2020Wolfram Food Data.txt\u2020file-kI98s2K5Nx9fhlHbuT7gYZEn\u3011\nL58: - In general, to find nutrition for a food or a list of foods, use the Wolfram Resource Function &quot;NutritionReport&quot; with the output format &quot;ASCIITable&quot;. Always try this Wolfram Language approach before attempting a comparable query using Wolfram Alpha. Example:\nL59:      -- ResourceFunction[&quot;NutritionReport&quot;][&quot;100g rice\\n8oz chicken\\n1 glass wine&quot;,&quot;ASCIITable&quot;]\nL60: \nL61: - If specific properties are asked for, find the EntityProperty associated with the requested data using Interpreter and include it using the &quot;NutritionProperties&quot; option. Examples:\nL62:      -- ResourceFunction[&quot;NutritionReport&quot;][&quot;100g rice\\n8oz chicken\\n1 glass wine&quot;,&quot;ASCIITable&quot;,&quot;NutritionProperties&quot;-&gt;{EntityProperty[&quot;Food&quot;, &quot;AbsoluteTotalCaloriesContent&quot;], EntityProperty[&quot;Food&quot;, &quot;AbsoluteTotalProteinContent&quot;]}]\nL63:      -- For user queries about nutrition in a &#x27;piece&#x27;, &#x27;slice&#x27;, &#x27;scoop&#x27;, &#x27;stick&#x27;, &#x27;clove&#x27;, &#x27;plate&#x27;, &#x27;can&#x27; of a food or &#x27;bottle&#x27;, &#x27;glass&#x27; of a drink, FIRST go get the typical weight in grams for EACH of the foods or typical weight in mL for EACH of the drinks from your general knowledge. Do the same for sizes &#x27;small&#x27;,&#x27;medium&#x27;,&#x27;large&#x27;. Use them in your NutritionReport resource function input. This function can find Wolfram Language interpretations of\nL6: - Entities (examples: Empire State Building, caffeine, Taylor Swift)\nL7: - Well-defined, named EntityClasses (examples: UN countries, lanthanide elements, skyscrapers)\nL8: - Entity + EntityProperty expressions (examples: population of France, mass of Pluto, Asian population of San Francisco)\nL9: - Entity lookups (examples: 5 tallest buildings in Beijing, cities larger than 10M people, books written by Stephen King)\nL10: - Note that getSemanticInterpretation may be able to interpret quite complex entity-related inputs, involving both filters and requests for properties for example &quot;release dates of highest grossing movies in the 1970s directed by Steven Spielberg&quot;.\nL11: \nL12: To find the correct name of a specific entity, entity class, or property in a specific Wolfram Entity type, you may use the following, providing the type and a natural-language, non-camelcase name or phrase:\nL13:    chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.findEntityAPI\nL14:    chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.findEntityClassAPI\nL15:    chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.findPropertyAPI\nL16: \nL17: \nL18: ## Guidelines for using Entity data with chatgpt_wolframcloud_com__jit_plugin.getWolframCloudResults\nL19: - A list of all EntityTypes may be retrieved with &quot;EntityValue[]&quot;.\nL20: - You may also retrieve all properties for a given type with:\nL21: EntityProperties[&quot;{{entity type}}&quot;].\nL22: - Prefer direct use of entities of a given type to their corresponding typeData function (e.g., prefer `Entity[\\&quot;Element\\&quot;,\\&quot;Gold\\&quot;][\\&quot;AtomicNumber\\&quot;]` to `ElementData[\\&quot;Gold\\&quot;,\\&quot;AtomicNumber\\&quot;]`).\nL23: - Prefer using &quot;Association&quot; in the third argument of any EntityValue calls. This will return a key-value association with Entities as keys. You generally should not request the &quot;Name&quot; property in such an Association, since it is present in the Keys.\nL24: - Wolfram Language visualization and other functions are designed to understand this data structure and automatically retrieve name, date, geographic, etc. information as needed from the associated entities. \nL25: - The Wolfram Cloud will automatically and efficiently batch requests for data; when possible, use lists of entities and/or properties in EntityValue calls instead of mapping over lists. For example, this:\nL26:    EntityValue[{Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;France&quot;], Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;Germany&quot;], Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;Spain&quot;]}, &quot;Population&quot;, &quot;Association&quot;]\nL27: is better than this:\nL28:    EntityValue[#, &quot;Population&quot;] &amp; /@ {Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;France&quot;], Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;Germany&quot;], Entity[&quot;Country&quot;, &quot;Spain&quot;]}\nL29: # \u30101\u2020getWolframCloudResults query guidelines.txt\u2020file-jAt577A8QpOTIErsx25lbYTr\u3011\nL30: getWolframCloudResults guidelines:\nL31: - Always explain your chain of thought before writing any code. When composing your explanation, follow all the guidelines here regarding variable names, etc. even in your written response.\nL32: - Always think about what Wolfram Language functions may be most relevant and efficient for solving a given problem.\nL33: - The Import[] function is supported by this function, allowing you to import data from the web.\nL34: - Before writing any code requiring access to Entity, EntityProperty, EntityClass, etc. data, read the file &quot;Wolfram Entity Data&quot;\nL35: - Before writing any code involving Food and nutrition data, read the file &quot;Wolfram Food Data&quot;\nL36: - getWolframCloudResults will render and return URLs you can use to display in your responses; you do not need to Export visualizations as images or do any other kind of processing.\nL37: - If getWolframCloudResults return data-related fields in addition to the default &quot;output&quot; such as outputLength, firstOutputValue, etc., your response should focus on those additional fields and encourage the user to define further steps for analysis. In these cases, if &quot;output&quot; is an image URL it is likely to be an image of a truncated list or dataset, and not helpful to the user.\nL38: - Do not specify ColorFunction[], PlotTheme[] or related options in visualization code unless requested by the user. The Wolfram Language has sensible default values.\nL39: - Variable names must ONLY be lowercase letters or camelCase names. NEVER use uppercase single letters, snake_case names, or names containing any non-alphanumeric character, especially underscores. Examples: {{invalid name -&gt; valid name}, {C -&gt; c}, {county_population -&gt; countyPopulation}, {LCM_T1 -&gt; lcmT1}}.\nL40: - Use ONLY double quotes around all strings, including plot labels, etc. (e.g., `PlotLegends -&gt; {\\&quot;sin(x)\\&quot;, \\&quot;cos(x)\\&quot;, \\&quot;tan(x)\\&quot;}`).\nL41: - Avoid use of QuantityMagnitude.\nL42: - Apply Evaluate to complex expressions like integrals before plotting (e.g., `Plot[Evaluate[Integrate[...]]]`).\nL43: - Remove all comments and formatting from code passed to the \\&quot;input\\&quot; parameter; for example: instead of `square[x_] := Module[{result},\\\\n  result = x^2 (* Calculate the square *)\\\\n]`, send `square[x_]:=Module[{result},result=x^2]`.\nL44: # \u30102\u2020getWolframAlphaResults query guidelines.txt\u2020file-Bvv5cOuKLkrkrKmc7BMrtF9X\u3011\nL45: getWolframAlphaResults guidelines:\nL46: - Translate non-English queries before sending, then respond in the language the user&#x27;s query was written in.\nL47: - Convert inputs to simplified keyword queries whenever possible (e.g. convert &quot;how many people live in France&quot; to &quot;France population&quot;).\nL48: - ALWAYS use this exponent notation: `6*10^14`, NEVER `6e14`.\nL49: - Use ONLY single-letter variable names, with or without integer subscript (e.g., n, n1, n_1).\nL50: - Use named physical constants (e.g., &#x27;speed of light&#x27;) without numerical substitution.\nL51: - Include a space between compound units (e.g., &quot;\\[CapitalOmega] m&quot; for &quot;ohm*meter&quot;).\nL52: - To solve for a variable in an equation with units, consider solving a corresponding equation without units; exclude counting units (e.g., books), include genuine units (e.g., kg).\nL53: - If data for multiple properties is needed, make separate calls for each property.\nL54: - If Wolfram provides multiple &#x27;Assumptions&#x27; for a query, choose the more relevant one(s) without explaining the initial result. If you are unsure, ask the user to choose. Then Re-send the exact same &#x27;input&#x27; with NO modifications, and add the &#x27;assumption&#x27; parameter, formatted as a list, with the relevant values.\nL55: - If you receive a 501 error and Wolfram Alpha provides &quot;Things to try instead&quot;, review those suggestions and try one or more of them, *exactly* as provided by the API, if they might provide a good answer.\nL56: - ONLY simplify or rephrase the initial query if a more relevant &#x27;Assumption&#x27; or other input suggestions are not provided.\nL57: # \u30103\u2020Wolfram Food Data.txt\u2020file-kI98s2K5Nx9fhlHbuT7gYZEn\u3011\nL58: - In general, to find nutrition for a food or a list of foods, use the Wolfram Resource Function &quot;NutritionReport&quot; with the output format &quot;ASCIITable&quot;. Always try this Wolfram Language approach before attempting a comparable query using Wolfram Alpha. Example:\nL59:      -- ResourceFunction[&quot;NutritionReport&quot;][&quot;100g rice\\n8oz chicken\\n1 glass wine&quot;,&quot;ASCIITable&quot;]\nL60: \nL61: - If specific properties are asked for, find the EntityProperty associated with the requested data using Interpreter and include it using the &quot;NutritionProperties&quot; option.
